reviews.review: A trip to the past. This museum was a real surprise. From 1578-1795 Catholicism in Amsterdam was ilegal but tolerated if practised privately. The museum includes a visit to the merchan´t house, with its kitchen still having the original dutch tiles, the sleeping quarters (bed boxes), etc and the church hidden in the attic of the house.

Church in an attic. Catholicism in 17th century Amsterdam was clearly tolerated although open practice of the faith may have been discouraged. Hence the family who owned this house (on the edge of the modern day red light district!) constructing a church in the attic. A fascinating insight into the life of the day and a more than interesting Tardis-like church with full altar, rows of seating and an organ. The exterior of the house holds no clue to the interior. Good commentary enhances one's understanding of life in 17th century Amsterdam.

Literally, a hidden gem. Beautifully restored, well worth a visit. This gives a wonderful glimpse into a functional merchant's home as well as a hidden church. The steps are narrow and somewhat steep, but the view of the upper floors of both the living quarters and the church are well worth the climb.
Surprisingly interesting history lesson.. Very interesting history of 3 adjacent buildings with a proper church stretching across the attic space of all 3. Well presented with excellent audio guides.
Nice tour . Nice tour of about 30 minutes. Even a special children's audio guide. The tour brought you through the house with the bedroom, kitchen etc and aventualy at the "church"!

A church hidden in your Attic!. This is a wonderful museum with more to see than you would imagine. There is a large organ and the pulpit is hidden inside the wood at the front at the "alter". Everything you would have in a traditional Catholic church is there but taking over the top three floors of the home. People came and went and carried on as if it were a regular church. This is a must-see in Amsterdam!

A Gem of a Museum. Suggested as a "good museum" and included in the Amsterdam card, this museum is a wonderful place to teach yourself about tolerance. On the top floor of this house is a church which was allowed to exist and prosper when the religion of the church was not allowed openly in the city. It is a wonderful surprise how lovely it is.

A wonderful surprise. This hidden church in the roof of an old canal house in the Red Light District is a beautiful and wonderful surprise. One of Amsterdam's hidden treasures and well worth seeking it out. The museum is well set up and informative. A few steps to climb but very manageable. Well worth a visit.

Worth a visit!. This was a very interesting visit. It is so well maintained and provided a great insight into how the members of this church would have worshiped. When we were visiting people were rehearsing for an event so we got to hear the organ played and a young woman sing Ave Maria which was a special bonus.

Hidden Gem!. I have been to Amsterdam several times now and each time there was one excuse or another for not making it to Our Lord in the Attic church, but this trip I made it a top priority and all I can say is that I wish I would have made it sooner. Chock full of history, this wonderfully restored canal house gives you a glimpse into the lives that have taken up residence here, specifically focusing on the 17th century restructure of the top portion of the house to contain a 3 story hidden place of worship for the local Catholics. The museum has really done an amazing job at explaining the history, showing how the rich once lived there and how the priest then lived simply, restoring the modest yet lovely church, and giving great views of old Amsterdam from the top of the house, it really is a can't-miss stop when you're in this amazing city!

Great history. The history behind this little church set in the attick of 2 homes is moving and thought provoking. Its a must see, there are some very narrow stairs so be careful if you have mobility problems.
A must see for tourists. This museum is a must see that shows the struggles of residents to continue their religion hidden in their homes.

Lots of steps. If you are interested in old churches, Catholic history, or early Amsterdam history, this museum is well worth your time.
Only drawback would be that there are a lot of narrow steps to climb, tour starts a floor underground and works upward a few floors. If you have trouble with climbing steps might just want to buy the postcard.

A good glimpse into history. This museum is excellent! Everything is authentic and you really get a good feel for what life was like in Amsterdam in the 17th century. The church is quite amazing. The docent was very interesting and quite happy to spend lots of time with us. We would highly recommend a visit.
a cultural must. in the heart of the redlight district this "hidden" church is a heaven of peace, very wel renovated its worth a visit for everybody!

Fascinating and Educational. The experience of the people in Amsterdam with regards to the Catholic and later Protestant Church has such a significant impact on who the Dutch are it was great to learn more and see this real life example of "hidden yet known" - tolerance and acceptance. And, on top of that it is a beautiful little church and the audio guide, the docents and the exhibits are all top notch.

Beautiful house-church. We were recommended this museum by our tour guide - as other reviewers have said, something of a hidden gem in that if no-one had mentioned it I certainly wouldn't have known it was there.The house-church itself was well worth seeing - absolutely stunning, and incredible that it exists in these town houses.The audio commentary was quite interesting but a bit on the long side, and the rest of the museum surrounding the house was good but didn't add quite as much as just seeing the church itself. Still very much worth a visit to see the church, but I wouldn't stay as much longer as the audio guide etc. seems to be pushing you towards, unless you're especially interested or have a lot of time.

A Hidden Gem. You'd walk past it! The facade of the museum tells you nothing! However, go in! Buy a museum pass (if you're into art/museums it really can save you a lot of euros!) and then enter...At first you're in the modern section of the museum. There's a audio-visual presentation. Then put on the blue overshoes to explore the place.This is a church ---The Lord in The Attic. In the 17th Century, the country was protestant. The catholics needed somewhere to worship. The government turned a blind eye to intimate churches being created within private houses ----but there was to be no sign of such a place from outside in the street.This museum takes you through the connecting houses and up into the Church in The Attic. As you proceed, you pass through kitchens, bedrooms and day rooms and you pass your audio guide over a connection point to receive an excellent commentary. Every now and then you can view the canal or the roofscape. I really don't want to spoil it for you!Would w go again? Yes!

Hidden Gem. We were recommended to visit this church before our visit to Amsterdam – usually referred to as The Church in the Attic. It was well worth the visit. It is well organised with free audio guide and over shoes to protect some of the old floors. It is interesting to see how “normal “life carried on in the lower floors while catholic worship was conducted in the attic and how these churches came in to being following the conversion of the Netherlands to Protestantism. This is one of many such churches dotted around the city. Well worth the visit.

The Church in the Attic. Great overview of the religious history of Amsterdam. The Catholics we suppressed during the early years. So they created little churches in their homes. Great museum. Be prepared to climb stairs.
Very sweet little museum. As a Catholic (very lapsed) I appreciate the insight into our history. Definitely recommend (although the location is a bit iffy...)

Astonishing - 3 Sep 2016. We had read about the hidden churches in Amsterdam and we were interested in visiting the Museum Ons'Lieve Heer Op Solder (Church in the attic). I have to stay that this place is absolutely stunning. You are given at no extra charge an audio guide. Also, be aware that there a lot of stairs to climb since it is after all a church in the attic. The museum is well designed and very interesting to go through. The church itself is still being used on some occasion for mass which is quite astonishing. There is also a cafe which is a bit too cold in terms of atmosphere but still we enjoyed a coffee there. Overall, highly recommended and a must see to understand what happened to Catholics in Amsterdam.

A hidden treasure. We followed Rick Steves' suggestion to visit this. The museum is so well designed with audio guides for the entire visit. There are a lot of small staircases to climb but the Catholic church hidden inside the canal houses is amazing to see.

A place of peace and history. This museum was absolutely fascinating. You are taken through the 17th century rooms to a church in the attics of 3 houses. We are not talking just a room with an altar, we are talking a fully functioning quite large Catholic Church complete with Organ, Sacristy and Confessional. I throughly recommend a visit, although the tea in the cafe is not very nice, the coffee is lovely.

A must go. A hidden treasure! A 16th century house with a church in the attic! Love that you keep finding more rooms, nothing hidden, great recreations. and great free personal audioguide so you can do the visit at your own pace.

Surprisingly good museum!. As I've been wandering around Amsterdam for nearly a week I was running out of things to do, so I visited this museum with a mindset that I've already seen the best museums in Rijksmuseum and Van Gogh Museum so this will probably be just okay. How wrong I was! This seemingly unassuming house houses a very charming church inside! The audio guided tour is extremely well done, telling the stories as you climb the house up to the altar without being long-winded. It was interesting to learn a bit of Dutch history here. Other than the church itself you get to see how the Dutch lives during the Golden Age in the multiple rooms and corridors inside the house. It definitely opened my eyes quite a bit! At the end of the tour you are told to go up to the second floor to check out a leaflet with a few words from the director of the museum. It was worth reading it in my opinion as the director explains how he thinks this church is the best example of Dutch tolerance.Overall I'd put this museum as being another must-see together with the Rijksmuseum and Van Gogh museum!

Don't leave Amsterdam without seeing this house church!. You might pass right by it if you don't know it is there. Actually, that is the whole point of this house church. The free audio guide explains that although the city government knew of its presence, it was just a regular house from the outside, and was therefore allowed to exist. You would never know the attic was a church until you went up yourself. The stairs were steep going up to the very top, but it was so worth it! They even gave us little booties to put over our shoes so as to help maintain the structure. The house has a rich history that is well described in the audio guide. The attic church is a feat of incredible architecture and engineering to utilize even the tiniest space in the most unconventional ways.
Interesting place to visit. We went our first day. Couldn't believe the home actually had the secret church. Awesome! You can take pictures!

Amazing little church and full of history. We nearly didn't go to this place but I am glad we did. It shows the tolerance of the Dutch people to have allowed this church to be hidden with a merchant's house. The world could learn a lot from this tolerance! The museum is very well organised and we took the free headphones and I am glad we did. Informative and interesting without being too heavy. Great cafe where we stopped for lunch.

Hidden Gem. A fabulous hidden gem, within Amsterdam's red light district. Audio tour was good and you could look around at your own pace, the 16th Century Church is wonderful and the story behind the building is a good insight to life of the well to do at that time. Well worth a visit.

Very nicely presented, but more for adults than children. Audio tour was great, interesting historical glimpse into the daily life of the well-off and the not-so-tolerant side of Dutch history. I was just a little surprised that it was lacking all the children-oriented stuff you seem to find in modern exhibits these days, as the museum is fairly modern and well-maintained.

AWESOME. This 16th Century Catholic Church in the Attic is a spectacular tourist attraction to see in Amsterdam. Three homes were put together to comprise this Church. The Catholic faith were not allowed to hold Mass publicly. So some people built churches in their homes. This is a prime example. From the outside it looks like a regular home, but once inside it's an amazing sight of workmanship and dedication. Very very interesting to see.

Fascinating - a must see!. I am not at all religious but this rather amazing church really grabbed my attention for the duration of our visit based on its history and architecture alone. The audio guide is better than most, and essential to fully experience the place. It is truly amazing that this building within a building exists on the top floor of the canal house without any hint from outside. From a construction standpoint alone it is fascinating but the history of how this church came to be is also very poignant.You will have to wear booties to protect the floor but you can wander around quite extensively - very little seems to be off limits! There are lots of stairs, sometimes steep and narrow.This place is one of Amsterdam's top "attractions" and for good reason - be sure to make time for a visit!
Museum Ons'Lieve Heer Op Solder. A little gem, probably easily overlooked but underrated. Not suitable for those with mobility issues.

A delightful gem. Fascinating place for lovers of history, architecture, religion, and so on. 10 euros for an adult to go in, no Over 65 reduction but on the usual Amsterdam cards schemes so you may get some discount if you have one of those. The audio commentary was much better than the usual ones - you just pointed your machine at each info point and then listened to it like a phone - no yucky headphones! Just enough info , with more depth if required. Lots of climbing narrow stairs which I found a bit difficult as I don't like heights or winding staircases although I don't have any physical disabilities. The cafe looked good, but as there's no air con in the building (and I didn't expect it in a building of such age) we left at the end of our tour and had a drink outside nearby. Free lockers in which to leave your bags. Toilets clean. I will definitely recommend as it's so unusual and different.

A hidden gem. Amazing church hidden in the upper floor of a traditional house. Interesting and different with a nice cafe too. Audio commentary very good. Well worth the 10 euros entrance fee. Not suitable for people with walking difficulties.

What a gem of a museum!. We had the Amsterdam city card, so we got free admission to this museum. I had read about it in a travel article and it was an interesting museum. In the 1600's, Amsterdam's Protestant community had kicked out all the Catholics from their churches so Catholics had to practice their religion in secret in hidden churches like this one which were built inside a group of canal houses. The museum provided an audio guide which explained the history and items on display. We had to wear booties over our shoes so we wouldn't damage the original floors. It's amazing that this church existed as a church for 200 years and as a building 150+ years after it stopped being a church.

Quite an experience. I agree with the latest reviewers that this is a must-see building. The included audio guide is a great improvement and the staff are also very helpful. Be aware that it will take around an hour to do all the rooms as this is not simply a one-room attic church "tour". Worth reminding visitors too that there are lots of stairs (and so people with walking difficulties cannot get this experience).

Fascinating,emotional, educational experience. A must see for everyone. The history behind this building is amazing. Don't want to go in to great detail and spoil it for people, go and experience it for yourself

Well hidden treasure!. A church quite different to any other, well hidden for reasons given at the museum and well renovated. The free audio guide was excellent information tool where you had options to listen to more about the contents in each room, i was really surprised by the foldout pulpit at the altar! Good for people interested in architecture and/or religion or looking for something quite unusual - well worth the 1.5 hour visit.

You just have to see it to believe it!. The Reformation forced various religions to "hide" their worship. And this is a beautifully kept example of how the Catholics in the 1800's hid their mass from the public. The Church is the top floor of a canal home. So glad I went there ... by the Red Light District, so approach with care if you have small children.

Even better than I had hoped. I've been eager to visit since first reading about the hidden church in my guide book back in January, but had no idea that the excellent self-guided audio tour would also include the restored rooms of the house beneath as well. We did experience a little difficulty with the pitch and narrowness of the many staircases to make it to the church on the top floors, but it was well worth the climb. As an added bonus, the 10 Euro admission price was included in our Amsterdam Museumkaart.

Hidden church from the street.. Amazing how these church's are hidden from the streets and built inside normal houses during the war so people could still prey, which was illegal back then. You can still go to normal services on certain days of the week.

What a Gem !. Found it hard to believe that such a beautiful chapel could be incorporated into a canal house and in the attic too ! Saw it with our Family - aged twelve to seventy five and all thought it was amazing.

A far more impressive museum than I thought it would be.. Although it costs 10 Euro to visit, I thought it was worth every bit. Very well laid out, superb hand-held device (Included in price) which provides a running narrative through the rooms and the changing Christian landscape of the Netherlands. The church itself is impressive for the number it can cater for (still functions as a real church on Sundays) and, yet, when looked at from the outside you cannot tell what lies within. Yes, this was as impressive as the two other famous museums in this city but in a different way. Do visit.

Hidden treasure. An often over looked museum is the Ons' Lieve Heer op Solder - Our Lord in the Attic. This is an authentic home with a hidden church built in the home's attic after Amsterdam became strictly protestant. The house, which is typical from the outside, was built in 1663. The church is located on the top 3 floors of 3 connecting houses. It is not necessary to be Catholic to enjoy the artifacts from this period and to appreciate the challenges of worshiping in your chosen religion. Located near the Old Church and the red light district, it is certainly worth 1 or 2 hours of exploration.

Secret church hidden inside canal houses. This secret church (now a museum) is completely hidden inside canal houses in the red light district. It was built and operated in secrecy by a wealthy businessman in the years that Catholicism was illegal. The interior church is surprisingly high and capacious (seats about 100), and very church-like, due to the hollowing out of a number of canal houses which sit side by side. This is the very next thing you need to see after the old favourites of Ann Frank House, Rijksmuseum, Van Gogh Museum, etc.

Gem. This really is a hidden gem that documents and displays so much of the city's history from centuries ago.To think that people had to construct houses of worship inside their own home to enable them to be able to pray is nothing short of remarkable.One would never guess from the outside of this small house that it accommodates this historic gem.

A delight - surprises through every door. It would be a mistake to think that this museum was only focused on the secret church - there is much more to it than that. It was in total a social history museum which led on the upper floor of one of the houses to a contemporary art work and a refection on toleration against the celebration of diversity. Altogether very engaging - has a good little cafe too.

Thrilled to find large church in the attic of canal house. We had a great trip to Amsterdam, but unfortunately the more famous museums and galleries had very long queues and, as we were there in March, it was a bit cold for outdoor queuing. But every cloud has a silver lining. We bought the Amsterdam City Card which included free entry to many other attractions that we probably wouldn't otherwise have seen. One of these was the "Our Lord in the Attic" church museum. I love the Amsterdam canal houses, so this was a great treat. The church was so much bigger than I expected .....and even after I had seen it, I still couldn't believe it was in the attic - impossible to tell from outside the house. But that was the reason it was built in the first place, in the 1600s, as Catholics had lost the right to attend mass. This museum is well worth seeing.
Excellent experience. Fascinating and historical museum. Thoroughly enjoyed. Enjoyed all the exhibits as well as seeing the beautiful church in the attic.

Hidden Treasure. There was no crowd when I was there and this surprised me. People really need to see this place (or similar places) and understand what religious discrimination is and why it is ridiculous. Forcing Catholics to worship in secret was a ridiculous idea, but this museum showed you it really happened in history. You don't have to be religious to visit this place. Indeed, its ultimate message is that we should tolerate, accept and respect other people's religious beliefs. A pleasant and thought provoking visit.

A real gem. Takes you by surprise how individuals were so resourceful in times of adversity.Well worth a visit and the information system is brilliant for going at your own pace.No need to book but really informative.

Amsterdam's history, politics, religion and humanity distilled into one fascinating building.. We visited on a Tuesday just after opening ,so there were only a few other tourists there. The museum is right on the canal side and easy to find since the addition of a new entrance. Step through the glass and tile reception, return the smiles and greetings from the staff; and step back in time to another word and another time.The 'Dear Lord' is a treasure trove for all kinds of visitors. Those who love architecture and the beautiful functionality of old Dutch buildings; those who relish history and like to follow countless footsteps over the 500 year old floorboards (you are given overshoes to protect the woodwork), and stand and look out on a view shared by those who lived there in times past. Romantics will be captivated by the hidden stairways and the clandestine meetings.The scale of the church in the attic is such a surprise, actually being across three attic spaces.The paintings are superb and there are clear and interesting explanations on the excellent audio commentary. The attention to detail in the restoration is superb , the colour of the paint, the hand woven rug, the bed linen and the artefacts found under the house all breath life into the experience, and let us see how the masters and maids used to live.There are things to consider before you go; if you are not good on your feet there are steep and twisty stairs to negotiate (especially if you go up into the organ loft and the warehouse) if you are tall, lots of spaces will require stooping a little and if you have young children they will probably not be as engaged as you are!If you are captivated, read Russell Shorto's book 'Amsterdam' or the novel 'The Miniaturist '.

It's just ok. In my opinion it was just ok.Of course it was interesting to see that catholic have to hide with their confesion, and it was interesting to see how it work, but in my opinion whole place was just ok. As the matter of fact it is normal, but small church inside. Of course it is interesting to hide it into a small building.

Unbelievable building. This hidden gem was recommended to us and it was a fantastic place to visit. The church is beautiful never mind the clever builder that created it. There are lots of steps in the old building so be aware. If you are able to visit I would certainly recommend this museum.

A Hidden Gem. You go into what looks like a normal row house on the block only to be shocked by the beauty in the attic. This hidden Catholic Church in the attic is just incredibly beautiful! You WILL BE SURPRISED by what you see!

A museum to see in Amsterdam. If in Amsterdam, this Museum is a must to see, the audio tour explains a lot about life in Amsterdam during the 17th and 18th century. We can see more about way of living, religion issues which bring more than just looking at paintings.

Very interesting. This was a really interesting visit - well worth seeing and not too expensive to get in. We had the recorded audio tour (included in the admission) which was okay, and it told you some of the basics you needed to know for the house to make sense. Things around the house and church didn't have labels as a consequence, which was quite nice and made it feel less of a museum. I liked seeing the everyday things like the kitchen with the scullery and toilet (same room), more than the church, but it's still quite amazing to see it at the top of a house.

Amazing. This was probably the real highlight of our visit. Although it was difficult to find since we did not realize it was a museum, having heard it referred to as "The Church in the Attic," it was worth the extra time. The audio tour was set up very well and easy to follow.
Very interesting tour. While not catholic, this is a wonderful tour. Very informative, but be prepared to climb up and down very narrow winding staircases.

Amazing and unique museum. If you're in Amsterdam, the Museum of Our Lord in the Attic is a must visit. I've never seen anything like it before. As a history teacher, I loved this museum, and my partner (who isn't even the biggest fan of history) said it was the second favorite place that we visited in Amsterdam. The tour takes your through both the house and the hidden church. There many stairs to climb but don't let that stop you from visiting this unique landmark. The audio guide lets you pick and choose what you would like to hear information about and if you'd like more information about any particular item or room. I've been to MANY historic locations, and this was one of my favorites.
Hidden Gem. Fascinating Catholic church hidden away in a 17th century canal house. It's a great opportunity to see an old canal house in addition to the church.

Amazing little church in a canal house. The museum is very well restored to the way this canal house and petite church would have looked in the 1600s when it was actually used regularly for services. The history behind why Catholics were resorting to churches in attics is well covered and it is interesting to see an example of a canal house. But obviously, the real attraction is the church, which is quite impressive. It looks just like a full sized church, but on a much smaller scale across three little floors in this house. The altar is lovely and the way the pulpit pulls out of one of the columns is ingenious. I really enjoyed the museum. It isn't huge so you can visit it in about an hour and it is right in the central part of the city, so very easy to fit in with other touristy type activities. The entrance fee of 10 euros seemed a little high, but you do get a free audio guide that works well and would be very necessary if you can't read Dutch or English.
Very interesting. I was surprised by this place I didn't expected it was so interesting.There are lots of stairs before you can reach the church.

Fine. This place is nice enough. But the audio tour goes on a bit too long for my liking. The place is interesting enough but I felt that it wasn't worth the money. Glad we had the museuumkart to avoid paying the asking price.

Church int the attic. 17th Century canal house dating from the time when Catholics were forbidden from openly practicing their faith, historic house with amazing church in the attic, a lot of winding, narrow stairs.

Very interesting museum, "Our Lord in the Attic". I'd heard about these hidden churches and seen a few documentaries about them. It was fun going through the house then heading up the stairs into this three story church. The audio guide is very helpful and is available in many languages. There are numerous very steep staircases. The museum also has a nice, bright lunchroom-- good for a cake and coffee with a beautiful view over the canal.

Hiding in plain sight. Amsterdam is a city justifiably famous for its excellent museums. While the obvious examples are clustered in landmark buildings dotted around Museumplein, some of the best are hidden in plain sight, in less obvious quarters. Indeed, Ons Lieve Heer Op Solder (Our Dear Lord in the Attic) is quite literally hiding in plain sight - in an unremarkable merchant house in a quarter better known for its nightlife.The museum itself is fantastically well-preserved canal house, and the audioguide brings to life the history of a seventeenth century merchant family. The technicalities of Amterdam's celebrated policy of 'toleration' are adroitly explained, and the hidden chapel on the top floors reinforces the point beautifully. For anyone interested in early modern history, culture or religion, this is a must visit.

One of the "hidden" Catholic churches of Amsterdam. Be prepared! There are lots and lots of stairs but it is well worth a visit to this hidden gem. The audio guide is a must and really brings the church and the home below it...to "life."

Fascinating Museum and Tour. Please make this museum a stop on your next visit to Amsterdam. The church is beautiful, the audio tour is free and really fun and informative. One of the main reasons we really loved the museum is that it felt more like it was just a church we visited: all the rooms, furniture, furnishings are ready to be experienced, sat on, leaned against, and even touched (most of the time). It was so immersive being in a place that old, where not everything was behind glass. Instead, the church is pretty much exactly the way it was back in the 15-18th centuries. Super cool. My 14 year old also really enjoyed the tour.

A different side of Amsterdam history. I wasn't sure what to expect but this museum is very well presented and my kids (9,11, 12) really enjoyed it. The museum presents life in a merchant's house in an interactive fashion and the rooms are well furnished so you can really get a sense of how they lived. They were also impressed with the actual church in the attic and the details - like the painted wood to look marble and the rush mats on the floor. Make sure not to miss the little video on how the priest sets up the hidden pulpit from under the alter. From either a purely historical perspective on the persecution of non-Protestant religions or a more Catholic experience, this museum is worth a visit.

History, religion and culture all in one. You learn so much about Amsterdam history, and the religious tolerance that is part of it, by visiting here. The audio guide does an excellent job of explaining why this magnificent, hidden church exists and why there were once so many others at least somewhat similar to it. If you have any interest in Amsterdam history, this is a must.

I never knew this existed. I have been to Amsterdam a few times and never once heard about this museum. It was my hotel who recommended it to me and I am so glad that they did! It's so interesting and so well preserved and restored. I rented the audio guide which was very informative and spent a good deal of time wandering around from floor to floor. This was such a wonderful find, such a hidden gem!
Hidden treasure!. Not only do you see and learn about the hidden cathedrals but you also get to see how a dutch house looked like a long time ago.

Amazing Church. This museum is a hidden gem and wonderful. The rooms are redone in the style of the original owners and the church is amazing. We would not have known about this if not for our tour guide and would definitely recommend it.

Interesting and easy to visit. A perspective on NL history and a look at how people lived.. Interesting and easy to visit. A perspective on NL history and a look at how people lived. We think of the Dutch as being tolerant of others and other religions especially. Interesting to see what persecuted religions incite their faaithful to do to be able to pracitce their faith.

Mysterious and beautiful. Your chance to visit a very old Amsterdam house with a mysterious secret. The church in the attic is so beautiful. You will also receive a free audio guide. Totally worth it.

Hidden Gem. If our friend hadn't told us about this little treasure we never would have found it. Absolutely fascinating! It will give you a real idea about what it was like during the reformation-- For Catholics and non-Catholics alike, a great history lesson.

A Hidden Jewel. A uniquely preserved 17th century house with a beautiful Catholic church in the attic. Follow a numbered audio tour using a hand held device available in several languages.Tips: Since you will be wearing rubber booties over your shoes to protect the floor, you may prefer footwear other than sandals. If your schedule permits you can attend Mass the first Sunday of the month in the winter and twice on Christmas eve (the latter requires a reservation ). Check website for more info.

A most special Church. Just steps from the Red Light District, is this very special church. No spoilers here, but do take the self guided, approx 60 to 90 minute tour with head set that is provided. Lots of stairs, some narrow and scary, but it works. Religion and history all rolled into one.

A good look at old Amsterdam. Thius house shows both the layout and use of an old Amsterdam house AND the role of house churches in Amsterdam. The church is a good example of a religious building and gives an insight into Amsterdam

Hidden Church. When I saw that there was a historic house with a church in the attic, I was very curious. Once there, I learned that after the Catholic churches were changed into Protestant ones, the only option was house churches. Some, like this one, are quite lavishly decorated. The rest of the house is also interesting and gives you a taste of life in Amsterdam centuries ago. You can pick up a free audio tour guide to learn more. Entry is free with a museumkaart.

A small marvel.. Many stairs and narrow corridors. Overcome these difficulties and you will be rewarded with historically furnished living rooms and, the high point (literally and metaphorically!), an entire church in the attic. A hidden jewel.

DO NOT MISS!. This museum isn't well know yet but will be. Provides a fascinating insight into the city's history. While this roughly translates into Our Lord in the Attic, this museum is not about Catholic religion. It is about history, values and beliefs.

Wonderful museum. I hadn't expected to love this museum but it's ended up being one of my favourites. Great place to visit if you have an interest in Amsterdam's history and a little more knowledge on the houses in Amsterdam and their uses.

A Must See!. I have been to this museum twice. Once in Oct. 2010 and then in April 2016. Back in 2010, the renovations had started and most of the contents was in storage. You could the see the church and you entered from a totally different place. It was interesting in 2010, but not visually attractive. Back to the present, this is an awesome museum! The church has been beautifully restored.There is a real reception area, a cafe, some educational space, and of course, a shop. There is a modern pre-museum area. It is here that you have to put on booties, to enter the museum. This is done to not wear out the flooring. You are given an audio tour device which really explains everything. There is a lot to be seen for such a small place. Plan for at least an hour to see this museum. This place is way more than a museum, it tells a story in visuals. I was so glad that we had the chance to go back and see this museum, after all the renovations were done. Do not miss "Our Lord in the Attic"! It should be mentioned that this museum is not handicap accessible.

a nice museum. Worth a visit as you get to hear the history behind the house and chapel. Situated in the Red Light area so seems a little out of place but is quaint and has sympathetically been restored.

Amazing and Historic. We learned a great deal about the hidden churches in Amsterdam by visiting this museum. The church in the upper floor was spectacular and yet from the outside and when initially entering you think you are entering someone's home. Everything has been kept in its original form complete with confessionals, hidden pulpit and change room. There a number of winding steps to get to the chapel and upper gallery but they are well worth the effort. The audio guide explains it all and is included in your entrance fee which was around 10 Euros. From the upper windows you can see the Old Church and St. Nicholas church which depicts the past and future of Catholic Churches.

A Real Treasure. This museum was extremely interesting. The audio tour was a great feature and helped you understand what you were seeing and how this church came to be. So glad we visited it. It's a definite must when you are visiting Amsterdam, well worth the price of admission.

Really Great Tour and Interesting Place. My wife and I had a lot of fun going through this tour because of how fascinating it was. Lot of language options for the tour, so you need not worry about that. It takes quite a while to go through if you listen to all the info at each of the stops. Wonderful rainy-day activity.

Must see. A Catholic church hidden in the upper floor of a house. This museum is a gem, and in my opinion a must see. This is an opportunity to learn how tolerance functioned then and functions now. You need the audio guide. Linger in the cafe to engage in a conversation on what you feel as you visit this site. We spent an hour disussing tolerance in our modern world, and what the past can teach. Everyone wants to visit the Frank house. I found this museum well organized, less publicized and every bit thought provoking as the Frank house.

Good find. Came here on a whim after seeing it highly rated on tripadvisor's things to do. Wasn't sure entirely what to expect but we really enjoyed it. The audio made it an informative experience and it was actually a very interesting museum. Would definitely recommend it- something very different and special in a tucked away spot- not what you would expect

Fantastic place. Very interesting little place. Felt it gave a good insight into Amsterdam houses but also the context of the chapel. Lovely little chapel too. Wearing overshoes seemed a little silly though!

Slice of Dutch history. Short walk from the Central Station on a canal, the museum is on three stories of a very ordinary looking building. It was interesting how they eliminated view obstructing support to configure the church.

A very unusual Church (but you wont know it from outside the building). The story behind this church is amazing and was the reason why my wife and I sought out this house to see it. We entered the building which was ultra modern without any idea of what we would later see.The church is totally contained within the building with absolutely no visible signs that a church was there.Well worth a visit to get the whole story. You should find it fascinating.

Hidden Gem in the Red Light District. This hidden church is well worth a visit if you're up for some culture during your Amsterdam trip. Reaching the attic where you find the secret church is truly stunning.
Very interesting!. This was well worth the time. Not as popular as AnneFrank House, so no line! I found it to be very moving.

Highly recommended and a must visit. This is not your usual church. Loved the Church in the Attic. Like what was mentioned by others, it's truly a hidden gem in the red light district. There's so much history in the place. The museum is well curated and happy to note that much effort has been put in to restore the place for visitors to understand and appreciate. There's a lovely cafe which you can grab a nice bite and drink.The Church in the Attic is really worth visiting!!
A must see. This is a really interesting place to visit, highly recommended. It's very modern when you first enter the place and it's really interesting!
Mrs Diane Fassoms. Brilliant loved it. Google maps send you all over the place. Ask a native they're super friendly and point you in the right direction. Nice bar a bit further down too.

The coolest museum in Amsterdam. Okay, the art museums are great, but they're swarmed over by a million people. This little museum is actually quite restful and you can go at an unhurried, relaxed pace. Massively preferable! It's a bit of a warren so I think it does take quite a bit of time to get round it, with the audio guide giving you plenty of information. It's really fascinating - not just the church, but a bit of history of Amsterdam, architecture, commerce...There are also these little stickers on some things which I think is part of the childrens' trail, so you can open some cupboards and doors and see secrets. Like jars with some herbs and spices in so your kids can have a fun game smelling cinnamon or pepper. Kids. Yes. Definitely not two full grown adults.Tot ziens Museum Ons'Lieve Heer Op Solder!

Super little gem in red light district . Very easy to find and so fascinating! Excellent audio tour - very descriptive and full of information about the houses and space. Just amazing how they cut out the framing of these houses and put this amazing church in the space. Also love the full access from basement to attic with furnishings. Really a special surprise and my favorite attraction so far in AMS.

Very interesting hidden gem.. I ran across this as something to try and it was way more interesting than I expected. I spent my time going slowly through every room and soaking up everything the audio tour had to say. The house has cool architecture and has been restored beautifully. That alone is worth a look see.But the church, it is truly a wonder. A review really isn't going to express it but it gives a really interesting insight into what people went through to follow their beliefs. I would rank this as one of my favorite things I did in Amsterdam during my stay.

Church in the Attic. This is a fascinating piece of history in the heart of the Red Light District. Not only do you see what a "house church" looked like when Catholicism was not able to be openly practiced, but you also get to see what an Amsterdam canal home would have looked like at that time. Definitely worth your time. Self-guided audio tour allows you to see it in your own time.

Not your average church. Having travelled a lot around Europe, I find I get "churched out" (meaning I'm done visiting churches after I see 2 or 3). I made an exception for this one because it seemed so different from other churches or cathedrals. It was well worth the visit. The audio guide is included with admission and is excellent. Also, you have to put on shoe covers to protect the floor which adds to the fun of the visit.

A Hidden Gem. Enter and step back in time. Not only is it so very interesting but so well done - short video clips can be viewed that go into detail about things such as the workings of the pulley system. Well worth a visit.

A hidden gem in the red light district. We usually don't like museums, but this one is really special and, as we think, a must see. The positive energy in this hidden church is wonderful and very high. We also recommend the new little cafe that belongs to the museum. You get great food plus friendly and helpful staff for a good prize. You even have a splendid view on the canal from the window seats. Perfect for a quiet and relaxed lunch break.

Hidden gem. This place was one of a number of secret Catholic churches in Amsterdam that were built around 1600 AD when practicing Catholism was forbidden in the Netherlands. The church was created out of the top three floors of three connected canal houses and is amazing. There are some very steep staircases to climb when touring the buildings but if you can manage to get up them, a modern addition has been added on to the back of the building so you are able to use regular stairs or an elevator to get back down. It is definitely worth the effort of getting up the original staircases to view the church at the top!
Urge at find. So pleased to find this delightful gem. Restored old house with a hidden chapel. Very understated gem perfectly restored and well presented. A must do in Amsterdam

Very interesting place to visit. The place is near to Oude Kerk. It's a 17th century canal house of a wealthy tradesman, a secret Catholic church and a museum all in one. The church is on the third floor, no elevator, so it is not appropriate for disabled visitors, I loved the virtual map in the museum which showed all the secret churches in Amsterdam in the 17th century. When you clicked on the mark you could see how the given church looked like in the 17th century and nowadays.

Six days in Amsterdam.. Typical house of that period in excellent condition, with a wonderful surprize awaiting in the attic. Stunning! Well presented to the visitor. Well worth the visit, thoroughly enjoyed it.

Hidden Gem. This hidden house church is barely noticeable which is by design. But inside is a full Catholic Church spanning several canal houses. It's pretty amazing how they could fit a whole church including an organ inside.Best church to visit in Amsterdam.

Much More Than You Would Expect. I thought of this as a little church in an attic, but it is much more. It is three houses joined into one with historical features and furnishings. It gives you an idea of how the middle class lived. They have added a modern visitors center and it is easy to find.

Fascinating. Not the most known attraction of Amsterdam, but perhaps the most fascinating. Thinking back of the time this has been build and the place and world people lived in, makes it a place to just dream away. Absolutely a must visit when in Amsterdam.

Do not miss this attraction while visiting Amsterdam, it is fascinating!. This is a most unusual museum. Back in the time of the Reformation, the Dutch government would not let religions other than the Dutch Reform Church practice openly. At that time the Dutch government confiscated the Catholic church buildings and synagogues. So people had to practice their faith wherever they could gather in private. There were many churches in homes established and Our Lord in the Attic is the oldest. It is just amazing! There are a lot of steps throughout the tour and climbing staircases so keep that in mind when you are considering going. Also on Sundays the attraction does not open until 1 PM.

A Hidden Gem. This is a very interesting museum. We learned a great deal about the history of the house and the church is amazing. It was a little hard to find but used the TripAdvisor map to help us!

Worth every penny . We had been meaning to visit this place for a long time. At first I thought that the price was too high for this hidden church. Little did I know that the free audio tour takes you through the whole 16th century house. It was like stepping into a Rembrandt painting. A hidden gem in all sorts of ways.
Very unique Museum. A very interesting and unique place to visit. I haven't seen anything similar before so it was definitely worth to visit. Highly recommended!

Ripped off. This attraction was interesting, however I was shortchanged by the attendant on the front desk. Gave him 50 euro for a 10 euro entry and was given no change, was told I only given him 10 euro. Be aware. I did challenge but as a single woman, got no satisfaction.This experience made it very hard to enjoy my visit to the museum

And now for something completely different.... A Church in your attic? Altar, pulpit, organ, pews, .. the whole works? In a 16th/17th century house on the canal? The history of why this should occur is fascinating and fully explained by a visit to this astonishing museum. It is very well presented and explained with very good audio. Architecture, social history and artifacts all beckon so definitely consider even if you are agnostic, pagan or of another faith.. Best if you like stairs. For me it is a "must see".
Fascinating, stepping into the history. Fascinating stories, lots to see from a traditional house to the church. Child friendly (ask about the lady bugs;).

stories behind closed doors. An interesting way to learn about a city's past. Free entrance with museum card btw. Gives you an idea of was happening in a city many many years ago. It was an interesting stop. Worth visiting.
A hidden church. Something to see! I enjoyed my visit. A perfect place to visit if you have just an hour before you have to go 5 minute walk from central station.

A cool hidden gem!. Another one of my most favorite places and spaces. It was like walking into another time period. The museum did a great job in restoring the house to it's prior glory and is so much more than the attic church (which in itself is spectacular). There is so much history and this was a fun way to learn a little more about Amsterdam's unique past. Make sure you get the audio guide and this museum is included in the Iamsterdam card!

Another View of Intolerence and A Slice of Amsterdam History. This was one of the more informative museums we have been at. The level of detail explained and shown, as well as the placing of the museum in the context of the time was very well done. Getting inside these large houses is interesting and seeing the alterations made at that time to accommodate a functioning and ornate Catholic Church was very interesting.

Lots to see and very thoughtful. The museum of Our Lord in the Attic is a preserved Catholic Church from the time when such things were illegal. If you can cope with the stairs, you'll enjoy the history, the enfolding personal stories and the well-preserved artefacts.The museum starts in a minimalist basement, but then it leads to room after room of history preserved from the time of religious persecution. The kitchens, the living rooms, the priest's room and most of all the church in the attic give a sense of how the "underground" Catholic Church continued to worship through a repressive regime. There's a reminder too that it wasn't just the Catholics that suffered: the Anabaptists, the Baptists, the Arminians and other non-mainstream religious groups had to find shelter in times of persecution, and Amsterdam was a place where non-conformity thrived.The details are fascinating, like the way the pulpit folds out from the altar and the time sacristy, and the use of the tiny space to accommodate so many people. It's all presented clearly with a good commentary and there's more to see here than you'd expect.

amazing place. You need to visit this church, aka Our Lord in the Attic. It was amazing. This was actually someone's home and they built a church in the top floor. An amazing piece of Amsterdam history really well preserved. And the free audio tour is a big plus.

That's what you have to visit!. Just renovated museum that reveals real dutch culture and history, that's definitely what you have to visit while being in Amsterdam. They have very helpful free audioguides there.

Beautiful Church in an Attic. I know that people flock to the Anne Frank House but you can see this place without a long line (I know, there are other reasons for visiting the Anne Frank House). This house is a restored museum that also gives history on how Roman Catholics practiced their faith during the Dutch Reformed period. The church itself is beautiful and is worth a visit in and of itself, but adding the historical significance of the of rest of the home really makes this a place to visit. They also have an attached museum and little restaurant.

One of the Best places i have visited in Ams. Its a secret Catholic church built inside two little adjacent houses. If you love churches, history and architecture, this is going to blow your mind. Small stairways to strange levels in the house, with rooms almost appearing out of nowhere is the norm. Its an adventure to explore this building and its former inhabitants.

A beautiful building with a fascinating history. Our Lord in the Attic is a unique attraction offering a fascinating insight into Amsterdam's history. It is very well presented and the historical interpretation is very good! I enjoyed the audio tour and thought they balanced the commentary well - giving the essential facts in the primary audio tracks and then offering you the option of hearing more if you choose. The audio devices were easy to use and convenient to carry with their neckstraps. The new, modern, minimalist visitor centre works very well - the contrast between it and the old building helps to emphasize the beauty and age of the old merchant's house. I loved the information about recent archaeological work on site and the wonderful display of artefacts found. The attic church itself is stunning! Viewing the whole building from basement to attic made me appreciate its importance as a home, business and church. We were also pleased with the price and found it good value for money. I put this attraction into my top 5 must sees for Amsterdam!

A must see!. We had this recommended by a guide in the Hague, and it did not disappoint. The audio guide is very good and takes you carefully from the front door of the building, up each floor to the hidden gem at the top of the house- the most beautiful little church. Very impressed, and well worth a visit even if you are not religious. The café is also very good with excellent apple pie.Very steep and narrow steps so not very good for the less nimble footed.

A lovely experience. Such an unexpected pleasure in the middle of the Red Light District. Really enjoyed this Museum. We had lunch afterwards at the Cafe and the food was delicious. If looking for a pleasant way to spend 1.5 hours this is a very lovely way to pass the time
Hidden Gem. This was very interesting, it showed a dutch house as it would have been. The surprise is when you go up to the attic. This was beautiful. I would recommend.

A real hidden gem. Decided to check this out after hearing and reading some positive things and have to say that the church more than met expectations. The presentation of information was very well handled using the combination of the audio tour and touch screens and as a result I feel like I learned a lot from visiting. The church and house itself are both bigger than I'd anticipated and are definitely worth a visit for those looking for something a little different in Amsterdam.
So interestimg. We visit test the church in he attic. It so unusual beautiful, with such an interesting history, near the red light district.

Church in the attic. This is a spectacular place its well set up, with lots of information and points of interest. The audio tour is a must to find out about general abut also specific history. When you get up into the church wow ! Amazing beautiful pick any description you wish. Everything is so good because of where it is and the fantastic condition of everything.Also if you get the chance try the traditional pea soup in the café-Amazing

Another must see museum attic church. Located 200m along the canal from the Oude Kerk is the hidden attic church 'On's Lieve Heer Op Solder'. Yep this is a definite must see in our list of Amsterdam highlights. It was included in our iAmsterdam pass. When entering take the stair or lift down stairs to enter the church and allow at least an hour for the self guided talking tour.

Interesting historical religious worship venue. The venue is in the red light district and you need to have good legs to walk up the stairs to see the church in the attic. Listen to the audio to bring the story of this church to life. It's free access with the iamamsterdam card.

An “Unforgettable” Find. The hidden church in the attic was an unforgettable find! Both a historical and architectural interesting home that had a story to tell on each floor. This home is the 2nd oldest museum in Amsterdam, with the surprise find of a Catholic church in the attic.Catholic masses were officially forbidden in the 17th century (from 1578), but the protestant governors of Amsterdam turned a blind eye, provided the churches were not recognizable on the outside. The church has a pipe organ, opposite the altar. The narrow passageways, stairways and tiny nooks lead one to uncover splendid works of art, ornate furniture and an atmosphere that will whisk you back in time. Camera, ability to negotiate steep stairs and good walking shoes are a must.

Wonderful house with astonishing hidden church. Make this a must. Clean white inviting entrance and as the well conceived exhibition unfolds, the story of hidden churches, and this hidden church comes alive. I loved the original oak staircase, the Delft tiles in the kitchen, as well as the extraordinary church. Good free audio guide. Spiffing cafe. Good location

Excellent museum!. This museum and house church was one we had heard about, but we ran out of time to visit on our previous trips to Amsterdam. This time we did not want to miss it and we are so glad that we didn't. The admission includes a free audio guide which takes you through the entire home. It explains the history and significance of the building and the opportunity it gave people to practice their religion. There are a lot of narrow and steep stairways, but you will not be rushed. It is a worthwhile stop.

Unique - one of the best museums in town!. This museum was one of the best of our visit - it let you see an old canal house on the first few floors, gave you a history lesson about Amsterdam and its religious residents, and let you visit the church of Our Lady in the Attic! Frankly, I have never seen anything like this, and the museum presentation is top quality. We found it totally enthralling and raved about it afterwards. Definitely visit!

Living in the 1700's and a hidden church.. Super well organized, audio guide, extra info. The tour contained both facts, interrupting comments and displayed items close up. The extra screens where there were more to tell. And the staff was friendly and helpful.

Eye opening museum. This is a place I had wanted to go long before I planned my trip to Amsterdam, the museum didn't disappoint. With an audio guide you walk through the old house and then up to the Catholic church in the upper floors. The place is an eye opening experience to how these house churches used to operate. Everything was well presented and the audio guide very informative. Highly recommend this museum.
Nice surprise. We had heard about these hidden churches while on our way to Amsterdam, but had no idea how elaborate they could be. Very interesting and informative audio guide.
Excellent. A very interesting time transported back into the 16-18th century in this well documented museum. The 10 euro price includes a free (and worthwhile) audio guide.
One of the highlights. Audioguided tour through one of de eldestst churches of Amsterdam.You cannot see the church from the outside.You get acquainted with the way of living in the 17th century .

AN INTRIGUING SURPRISE. I found this place by chance a few years back when seeking to navigate myself through the streets and along the waterways of Amsterdam without a map. Best that way, if you know about the path of the sun or how the city is a series of half circles extending away from the old harbour.No I was not looking for God or the Red Light District but found them both in a sort of quiet unity. From its birth Amsterdam has been a Protestant city. They did not want discord and were to varying degrees tolerant of other peoples beliefs. But they objected to hearing them pray. It was the Roman Catholics that they could not stand the ringing of bells, Latin chanting and possibly the smell of incense, so the old Burghers decided that such people had to hide away from the general public,This house, recently extended is one such place. The rooms are small as was typical. Hidden away are Priests holes as found in England. Great to climb the stairs and wonder how people lived in such small places, until one thinks carefully about the tiny rooms of modern English starter homes.Carry on climbing the stairs and then be amazed at a complete Church built from papier-mâché and timber. The surfaces are marbled. Everything one sees is of a miniature Catholic church. High up towards heaven the small congregation could sing their hearts out.Close by is a much larger church, In front of its entrance please seek out a brass plaque and admire the picture you see. It could be a message for the traveler of other heavenly pleasures. But then for me what is known as the Redd Light district is a water way with some splendid elegant houses. A good place to live one might think.A place for the intrepid traveler not to miss.

Better than I expected. This is a perfect choice if you want to feel real feel of ancient life of Amsterdam. Audio guide is so great and it leads you through time like you were there. It describes beginning of Christianity religion and efforts of one man to inveigle people to understand it and accept it.

Well presented. . This is a well organized, interesting museum. The audio tour is perfectly balanced, i.e. just enough detail. The staff are friendly too. There is a good sized cafe as well. Very worthwhile.

What a Change!!. We visited this Museum 5 years ago. What a Change!!The new entrance, ticket area elevators and cafe, were terrific, also very nice locker area with very clean WC. They now ask for you to wear bootie like covers over your shoes, good idea because the day we were there it was quite damp and rainy. They have rush mats in one area so to damage those, and of course other areas, it was a good idea. My only complaint, was a German Tour Group - was visiting and their Guide (not sure if she was affiliated with the Museum or was from and outside Tour Group, was very noisy, She spoke so loudly and spread her small group out to you had to go around them at each location. Also you receive, Audio headset, which was very informative and yet the Tour Group was SO LOUD - it was necessary to put your hand over your ears to hear the comments offered on the audio guide!! You need to be rather mobile to visit (with all the narrow stairs - which can be expected - would be very difficult to see all that is offered. Would definitely recommend this lovely well preserved Museum.

Outstanding / a must see. The house alone is a great representation of Dutch architecture of its era but the "church in the attic" is a sight to behold. Overlooking the bigotry of the time, the dedication of the people that built these churches is remarkable.
Really cool and interesting museum. A very interesting museum. Showing how the houses looked in the 1600s. The church in the attic is surprisingly large. Very well done interactive tour.

A hidden gem!. This is an amazing museum situated in the red light district, but well worth a visit. At first glance it appears to be a couple of typical Amsterdam town houses, however it is not until you have climbed lots of wooden stairs that you arrive at the hidden gem - a church built across the attic space of 3 houses. Known by the English name of The church in the attic. This came about when Catholics were banned from openly celebrating mass in the 1600 & 1700's but a blind eye was turned if it wasn't seen publicly! This is an incredible piece of building work & architecture & needs to be seen to appreciate just how hidden it is. Well worth climbing the stairs to the top of the building!

fantastic gem in the "red light district". We were staying in the red light district in Amsterdam and on our way to visit the Rijksmuseum when we passed this museum and almost missed it. That would have really been a waste as this is a very interesting and unique museum showing a full and complete Church in the attic. On the way to the attic you pass various rooms in their original state and with the original furniture. The audio guide is available in various languages and give a interesting tour through time and explains what you see in each room and places it in context. All together really a museum that i recommend visiting.

Amazing. I loved this little hidden paradise! Not too busy with that many tourists, and definitely worth a visit! We probably wouldn't have found it and visited it if it hadn't been for the iAmsterdam card, where it's included. We had an audioguide and it was so interesting to learn about history and about the church. Will definitely recommend going there.
Amazing. This is a must see canal house. The church in the attic is amazing and the interactive guide helps to understand the era and detail of the house. Free with Amsterdam card.

A must see!. What a spectacular renovation to an incredible historic site! This museum is an absolute must see for its history to Amsterdam and religious tolerance not to mention the fascinating place it is. It is a self guided museum, but you are provided with a good mobile hearing device that gives detailed information as you navigate a well planned route. Museum Ons'Lieve Heer Op Solder (Our Lord in the Attic) is wonderful! Do not miss it!

Different and Unusual Tourist Treasure. I had never seen anyting like this before. This is a church within a house, hidden from public view so people could practice their religion without persecution. Just so different and unusual,.... its a must see. Great little snack bar on the lower floor with wonderful cake, so you can rest and recharge.

Hidden gem in the red light district. From the outside a normal old house on the 'gracht' as so many in Amsterdam. But you will be surprised when you enter the building via the new entry. Hidden inside the building is a complete church from the 17th century when catholics had to wordhip in secret. A must see in Amsterdam

Amazing this survived. Remarkable church, in a small house across 3 floors. It's nice to see the attention to detail when they restored it and this place gives you a good feeling around the development of churches in Holland throughout the centuries.

what a great museum ! very interesting. I was presently surprised by this small great museum about a hidden church is a 17 th century house, both house and church a very interesting , love it ! never been there in 30 years living in Amsterdam.. glad that I went !

A tour of the last surviving secret Catholic church in Amsterdam.. For about 200 years Catholics (along with Jews, and many Protestant denominations) were not allowed to openly worship in Amsterdam. Because of this, churches were created in homes. As long as this worship was keep private it was tolerated. This museum not only includes the beautifully restored church, but gives a glimpse of what Dutch life was like in the 1600-1800s.

Interesting museum/church, not so crowded as many other big museums. We came here on a rainy day and liked very much this hidden gem. It is modern and at the same time gives an insight into former times. There is an audio-guide in different languages and you can choose yourself, how detailed you like your information.

Incredibly interesting and well done museum. Museums in Holland are magic. So well done. So well though out. So creative.This museum is the same.Preserving one of the hidden Catholic churches, you can walk into the old canal house, see how the residents lived and then see the hidden church - totally preserved.It is a really special place - tucked away one on of the red light district/old city centre canals.I loved seeing how people slept and how they cooked and how this seemingly small house could house hundreds of people each week at it's congregation.Amazing.

Very educational and interesting. There was much more here then I expected. The history of the house and the times the church was built here was very instructive. They went out of their way to explain the religion as well as the history it took place in. Very well done.

Newly improved and more accessible with nice cafe. Since we were last here the Lord in the Attic has been renovated and extended making it more physically and intellectually accessible. At the same time it has lost a little of its former mystique of being a hidden place.The audio stations work well. There are more parts of the place to explore too, the priest's Definitely worth a visit. And stay to have a light lunch in the clean and bright café.

unique in the city and even in the world. very realistic contact with a 16 th century house, the story of the house and familiy and a well kept secret church in its Original state. the audio guide is superb and very complete and detailed;one would never forget this visit; count at least one hour for this visit. enjoy a beer or drink in one of the local "brown pubs".

A hidden gem!. This attraction is very unexpected being in the red light district! It is known as the church in the attic and looks like the usual canal side town house. It was certainly well hidden and was ingenious in it's construction. It is up a series of very steep stairs but certainly well worth the climb. The story is told through a free audio guide and you can just listen to the basic story or you can listen to some more in depth information. The church was constructed in 1663 when it was prohibited to celebrate mass, hence the secrecy behind it.
Church in the attic.. This was a hidden church from the time it was forbidden to celebrate a Catholic Mass in The Netherlands. Nowadays it's a museum.

Different from everything I have ever seen!. I won't spoiled this museum for you, but my experience was: the receptionist at the hotel I was told me about this museum and I went to check without searching any info online. In the entrance I was like "what the hell am I doing here.....", but then knowing the place piece by piece I was amazed!! So worth it!!!Take the audio guide!! I think the ticket is around 9, 10 euros!

Wonderful find.. By far the most sophisticated/professional visitor experience I have ever encountered. Very informative audio guide and small video presentations in very discrete and reverential positionings. A building with a fantastic story to tell, well told.
Beautiful. from streetside you don't expect such a unique church, its really astonishing, every minute worth visiting it

Interesting peek into Dutch life. A very interesting museum at the edge of the red light district. Beautifully presented, the audio equipment was great and very necessary to enjoy the experience. The 'house church' on the top floor worth seeing.

First Sunday of the Month! . We had the incredible opportunity to be in Amsterdam on the first Sunday of the month. On that day the Sunday morning church services are open to celebrate the mass. Very moving experience to think back on the history of this church while worshipping. Also open to tours at other times for a fee. No cost for our mass attendance. There was a little room that served coffee to church goers for free....pastries at a fee.
Really interesting!. Very interesting visit! You walk upstairs through old rooms until you arrive at the church at the attic. Which is impressive and really nice. Definitely worth a visit!

Our Lord in the Attic is not to be missed.. The history of the entire house, including the 'hidden' chapel in the attic amazing. My husband was very surprised by this attraction, as he only expected to see a 'chapel' and not all the floors of the house.

Much better than I expected. Not just a church in the attic of an old canal house but also an historic look at how the house would have been used. The church and attic on the top floor are the main attractions but whilst getting there you get the opportunity to see the insides of a canal side house. The automatic guide was an added bonus and helped to explain the history. The café is also very good and reasonably priced.

Must see place in Amsterdam. True piece of the history of Amsterdam. I always take my friends there when they are coming to visit Amsterdam. Everybody enjoys it as it is very interesting place. I can say it is a must-see place in Amsterdam after Rijks and VanGogh
Interesting. Lovely to see this museum. It gives a good view on how cristianity was practised in these days. The old house is a good example for the houses in Amsterdam

Church in the Attic!. Good insight into life as a Catholic once the Reformists took control. This house has been maintained as a house to show domestic life and the determination for a man to transform his attic into a church which still celebrates mass.

Very interesting. the house has been renovated to its former state. The audio guide is essential and easy to use in order to understand the trouble the owner went through to have the chapel in the attic.

Interesting museum/church. Very well done exhibits in this house/church. It has recently been redone with new exhibits and audioguides.The church in the attic is well described and really incredible. Well worth the visit.

Most Interesting Church I Have Ever Toured. This hidden church is the most interesting church you will ever tour. The visit exceeded our expectations - very interesting and informative. The church itself is beautiful. We just loved our visit here!

Interesting and surprising. When we entered the Museum we thought at first there wasn't much to it. Then the tour began, and we discovered there was so much more to it than was on the outside. Lots of crooked staircases and small rooms (and I have no idea how anyone fitted into those beds), until we got to the top where the Church is hidden. A really nice and interesting experience.

Beautiful hidden church. One of our favorite stops in Amsterdam - this museum is a treasure. The house and church tour are very well done via the audio guide, and the church itself is a gem. Get the Museumkaart at the beginning of your trip to the Netherlands, and for one price gain admission to all museums.

You must see this piece of Amsterdam history. My teenage sons said this was their favorite activity in Amsterdam. We learned so much about he history of Amsterdam just by walking through this one museum. The guided audio-tour was well done and offered useful and interesting information. At this museum you can get a feel for how the wealthy, the not so wealthy, and the clery lived in the 1600's. Also, you could appreciate the importance of religous freedom to this country.

Best small museum in the city. Recently undergone a total refurbishment creating a visitors entrance in the next door building thus sparing the old house. Be ready to be surprised by ally the detail of the old bedrooms, kitchen, reception rooms but most of all the incredible hidden church. Make sure you get an audio or a guided tour to get all the extra information of this incredible piece of Dutch history. Interesting even for the Dutch themselves as it explains so much of our current culture. Blown away.

Our Lord in the Attic Museum - Well done renovations. We were very impressed with the renovations which were completed to this museum In September 2015. There is now a new reception area, an improved audio guide and toilet facilities. Previously, if you had "the urge" you had to get a token and visit the toilet at the bar down the street.This museum, which was a hidden Catholic Church, is located in the attic of a canal house, and has a very interesting history. The house itself is beautifully restored - as is the church - and the audio guide provides a snippet of the Catholic and Protestant religious history in Holland. This is a very enjoyable museum which is located in the heart of the Red Light district.

Hidden church. The hidden church of Our Lord in the Attic. Well it was hidden for years albeit an open secret within tolerant Dutch society. Not hidden any more - the stonking great museum banner outside gives it away somewhat. I visited last time I was here but a lot of work was being done, so it was great to see this amazing museum finished - and well worth seeing again

Hidden Gem. This museum isn't obvious either in all the tourist info that we read prior to, or during our visit, nor is its location one that you would likely just happen across, but it really is a hidden gem and very much worth a visit. It is all very well laid out and the history is explained very well via headphones (in your language of choice). We really enjoyed our visit and can highly recommend it!
Beautifull. A little hidden gem in the city centre of Amsterdam. Great history and beautifull renovated the place. It's over 350 years old and the history of the church is vey interesting.
A must see. A fantastic glimpse of history - very well presented - a real church in the attic of an old canal house.

Amazing - total surprise. From the outside this looks like a quite boring museum - don't be put off. The "hidden" church inside is just amazing. Amsterdam seem to like to clad the outside of interesting buildings in nasty modern cladding (Anne Frank the same) but the interior is another story.

Very different and interesting museum. This is a very interesting little museum. The audio guide was very good and available in multiple languages. The church is very nicely restored. There is not enough here to spend all day there but is a great way to spend 2 hours or so. Adult entry was €10 which I think was pretty reasonable. There are free lockers for you to keep your bags and coats in. Just be aware there are a lot of very steep, narrow stairs.

City Break. Fantastic 'Hidden Church of Amsterdam', Our Lord in the Attic naturally involves lots of stairs but is well worth the effort, nice coffee shop to recover energy in; very helpful staff, informative and friendly, situated in the middle of the Red Light District it is an unexpected find but worth searching for.

incredible hidden Gem. This was an amazing place to see. We didnt plan on visiting this but heard it was worth it so we went. The guide you carry is filled with info on all items around the museum. you just swipe when you want to hear about them. the old architecture and church are still in tact and are a sight to see how they have stood for so long. Make sure you pay attention to the areas where they have taken back years of paint in various areas to see what the finishes were like.
