A hidden gem of a museum. I hadn't heard of this museum until I read about it in a magazine provided in our hotel room (Hello Amsterdam-have a read if you come across it). It's located in the red light district a short distance from the Ouide Klerk (which is also worth a visit). The tour is very interesting and the free audio guide is very informative. We visited on a Sunday and while it was busy, it wasn't over crowded. A lovely cafe on the premises too.

how can we get along with those who don't believe what we do. Wonderful gem of a museum (Catholic mass is held the first Sunday of the month in the morning in Dutch) that teaches how the Dutch could be religiously tolerant in an age where this was not the norm. The audio guide was very helpful with stories of the times, the people, and the things in the museum. It was wonderful to be able to climb up to the second balcony above the sanctuary and get a bird's eye view of the chancel area.
Beautiful piece of history. Nothing left to say that hasn't already been said about this extrordinary place. If in Amsterdam don't miss your chance to visit!

Lots of narrow stairs. Fun museum, much of the walk through is the historic house, many well restored rooms with a good audio description for each room.The Church itself is beautiful, and well worth the long climb to see. The history is fascinating and well explained in the audio guide.I would not recommend this museum to people who can't climb stairs. Many of the staircases are narrow and steep.

An interesting insight into how people lived. An interesting museum - lower floors showing how a wealthy merchant lived in the 17th century whilst the attic is a hidden catholic church. Very informative audio guide included in cost of entry. Make sure to go up to the two balcony floors from the upper of which can be see the original pulley wheel for winching goods up from the street.Pleasant cafe. Given the steep and narrow staircases this is not an attraction suitable for anyone with mobility issues.

Hugely affecting museum though. Though - sadly the chapels are inaccessible to the disabled. The chapel is squirrelled away in the roof. Hidden to preserve the Catholics who worshipped there.However the new addition of a museum/gallery which is light and beautiful is accessible. The welcome is genuine, the displays fascinating and the cafe serves excellent coffee.

Great 'museum'/ experience. Thoroughly enjoyed. This is somewhere that both my wife and I wanted to visit. The layout of the tour is great, the key facts had been picked out perfectly and the audio guides told you everything that you need to know, without it being 'too much'. Definitely worth the money... even better if you have the I Amsterdam cards like we did :)

Unique experience. The English translation for this museum is "The Church in the Attic." In the 1660's, Holland announced that its official religion was the Dutch Reformed Church (Protestant), and while other religions were not illegal, they couldn't be practiced in public. A number of faiths constructed clandestine churches, and this one has survived and been renovated to splendid condition. Its a normal Amsterdam building of the time, except that the top three floors have been converted into a church, invisible from the street. The museum includes very interesting trips into some of the "normal" rooms of the period (kitchen, formal room, bedrooms), and then the church. They have a very good audio guide in multiple languages, and you can explore the whole thing in an hour. We really enjoyed it. It isn't one of the places you hear about, but well worth your time.One more thing. Be sure to go to the very top, where the large pulley wheels that operate the exterior hoists are--they are cool to see!

Far better than you'd think. I'd seen this place on TV and in pictures and wanted. To visit for years. It didn't disappoint.The audio guide us very good and the museum is a must in my opinion.It isn't easy to get round due to the stairs so not good for the infirm. I didn't see a lift.
Surprise to find this church.. An interesting place to find new insight into the religious and political history of Amsterdam. You see how people tried to keep their beliefs while under persecution.

May Have Been our Favorite Visit in Amsterdam. A fascinating place to visit. The name was intriguing, but the visit was amazing. After the Reformation Catholic (and other religions) were banned in the Netherlands. Dozens of Catholic Churches existed in the attics of follower's homes. This is one of the few surviving examples. It's been well restored, with care, and the self guided tour is well done. It's a fascinating visit to the17th century home of a cloth merchant, in it's own right, but the top three floors are a restored church shows another perspective on life in Amsterdam during the Reformation.

Must see and experience. Learned so much about Amsterdam's history from my visit here. Not only do you get a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to visit a typical Amsterdam canal house here, but you get to experience stepping in a well-preserved / restored "hidden church". Back in the 16th-18th centuries, Catholics were banned from displaying ostentatious gestures of their religion due to the dominance of Protestanism. However, since the owner of this canal house was wealthy and had business ties with the city, he was allowed to convert the upper floors of his house as a secret sanctuary for practicing Catholics. The audio-guide was free and expertly narrated. Don't miss the attic and the hidden pulpit. I used my Museumkart here. Virtually no lines. 5-7 minute walk from Central Station. Lovely canal-side location, tucked in the middle of the Red Light District. Highly-recommended!

A hidden gem in Amsterdam. A complete church hidden under the roof of one of the canal-warehouses. A leftover from one of the more stormy periods in Dutch religious life. One has to see the wonders od this little church to believe it. Getting there is already a true adventure via hidden staircases and small passages. You have got to see to believe it.
Hidden Church. Wonderful museum. Self guide audio tour was very helpful. Fascinating look at not only the church but also the house of a 16th century merchant.
Fascinating. A fascinating little museum in the Red Light museum with a "surprise" church buried in the top floors of this historic canal house. Very well documented explanations.

Very surprising. The museum of Our Lord in the Attic (Ons' Lieve Heer op Solder) is one of those things that may not be at the top of people's to-do lists in Amsterdam, if at all. Although we knew of it, it wasn't on ours. We went in because we happened to be in the area and had some time that we hadn't planned out. It was definitely worth it!There are four great reasons to go inside this museum:You get to see what it was like inside a seventeenth century Amsterdam house of belonging to a family of modest means. Experience what its like climbing the tiny winding steps and living in the intimate spaces of a canal house, and peek inside cabinet beds and cozy tiled kitchens. Behold the church in the attic. Although there are pictures online, they really do not prepare you for what its like when climbing through the rest of the dimly lit house, you finally arrive at the very beautiful little church built within the attic. It really is surprising and simply stunning. Have a seat in the pews and take it all in. Learn some fascinating and well explained history of the house, church, and its inhabitants, and also about Dutch attitudes and tolerance regarding religion in the 17th century. Audio guides are included in the museum price. Lastly, take pictures! The space within the house is minimal and fills up quickly, and you'll want to be mindful of others, but if you are lucky, you can take some wonderful portrait photos in the beautiful Vermeer-like light that comes in through the windows. Also, there are terrific views from this house, so grab some shots of the canal and surrounding houses from here. Views you can't get any other way. Really, this was a high point of our trip. A genuine surprise. Although its €10 per adult, we felt it was worth the price and a better value than some of the other attractions you'll find in town. Admission is also free with the museum and I Amsterdam cards. In short, if this isn't on your to-do list, put it there. I think you'll be glad you did.

A religious experience.. Told about this by a friend and glad I listened.Access to the chapel is via the modern centre across the alley. Worth buying ticket before visit. Can get busy.The audio-guide is handy and activated by posts on each room. Information centre provides an overview of the site and then leads to the actual house by a tunnel. The first few floors are reconstructions of the living quarters over the years and are an interesting insight to life in old Amsterdam. The jewel in the crown is the chapel itself. After the relative austerity of the living area, the chapel is a stunning revelation. The work required to create the chapel in secrecy is astounding and it is a wonderful sight. The stairs and layout are a bit convoluted and it is hard to visualise the house layout. A bit more information and graphics in the information centre would be useful.Tip: Visit the nearby Protestant church in it's austerity to accentuate the effect of the chapel itself.T & S.

A fascinating view of the 16th century Catholic house church. This beautiful home tour tells the story of hidden church in wealthy home. You don't want to miss it. Plan on 1 hour t 1 hour and 1/2. Really well worth it.
Interesting and Unusual. Clear insight into the way Amsterdam coped with unofficial toleration in the seventeenth century. Well organised museum with useful audio guides

Well worth a visit. A beautiful museum/house which tells many interesting stories. The audio guides are within the entrance price of 10 euros for adults, 5 for teenagers. The 'house' shows how life was like in earlier centuries and is well-described. The jewel in the crown is a church built within the upper floors of the house which was used as such for over 200 years. Some of the stairs are steep. The new museum areas are crisp and minimalistic. The café is lovely and reasonably priced. Lovely staff here.

Well worth a visit!. Visited this museum as part of our iAmsterdam cards, went in with minimal expectations - I literally thought it'd be steps up to a little attic with a few information boards. Wow, how surprised we were - there is a wealth of information, history and culture. It's a great museum, and it's hard to get your head around how on earth it all fits in to the building! The audio tour was great, and allows you to take it all in at your own pace. Definitely recommend!

a catholic church in a canal house. recently visited the museum our lord in the attic also known as the church in the attic. being raised catholic I found it very interesting to see what extent people would go to to keep their faith going it is a great museum to visit about an hour and a half or so with a self listening hand held device as you pass through the museum. very nice!

Nice little museum. We spent an hour trying to find this museum because our map had it positioned between two alleys in the red light district. It is, but it has a modern facade facing the canal. Still, got an education looking for it! The audio guide and wander through the building gives you a good idea of life in the 16th/17th century. Worth a visit if your maxed out on artwork.
Worth a visit. Small but very interesting house which gives a feel of how living was 300-400 hundred years ago plus the surprise of just how impressive the hidden chapel is .
Great. Beautiful museum. Free entry with the museumkaart and I'm glad I visited. Went at 10am when it opened and it wasn't busy. The audio guide is good.

Wonderful & Unexpected . Using our Iamsterdam card this was included and oh my it was anazing, Havin used the audio tour for the first time in my life in any museum I was honestly blown away by the history of this wonderful gem, The staff were excellent too.Do not miss this place if your in town.

Great View Into Hidden Churches. It looks like just another house on the outside but inside is a two story church. It is amazing to see the lengths people had to go to practice their faith. It is in the red light district but you can get in before things get too seedy. This museum ended up being a highlight of our trip to Amsterdam.
Wonderful Self-Guided Tour. Great tour giving the history of the chapels and why they were necessary. Able to go at your own pace, with narrative available in many different languages.

Interesting, beautifully restored hidden church. This is a period house in a smartened up location in the Red Light District. The lower floors have been well restored and give a good idea of a house from that period. The most fascinating part of the building is the conversion of the top three floors to a Roman Catholic church, dating from the seventeenth century, when Catholics were permitted to worship but only in private. The restoration is beautifully done and even though I knew what to expect, the change from a house to a church was genuinely surprising.

Very nice museum. What is important in this museum is not the content (of course is important as well), but, overall, the method, how the owners have described and developed a museum from an anecdote (to have a cgurch in the las floor of the house) to write an speech very well recounted, very well explained each detail, so you can see not just the question of the religion but also understand the epoch in which the owners lived. Very nice display of the speech

Excellent audio guide to wonderful place. We all enjoyed this tour, even my disengaged, tech-obsessed teenage daughters! The house has been beautifully presented/restored and well organised so that you walk round in an ordered fashion. The audio guide was excellent and gave all the information and was very interesting. It was a really unique place and very calm in the middle of chaotic Amsterdam. Really enjoyed it.

Nice change from the typical museums. Slightly hard to find, but ask around.
Free audioguide. Very informative and educational about the religious tolerance and also typical daily Dutch life in the 1600's. areas slightly cramped (obviously) , but not stiffling during the time of my visit.
I would say it is a must see when in Amsterdam

Very nice museum. Interesting insight on how people lived and also practiced their catholic faith a few centuries ago. Concise and short descriptions.
Beautiful rooms, not overcrowded.
Beautiful trompe-l'oeil columns
I really enjoyed visiting this museum
Allow a good hour

Great museum!. The staff were very helpful about providing information not only about this museum, but about other attractions in the city as well that had to do with religious prosecution throughout history. The church was stunning inside the canal house, and provided a guided audio tour as well to learn more about that specific time in history when it served as a church.

Worth to see. It's a very interesting museum in the heart of Amsterdam. They can suggest you audioguides in your language and you can hear the most interesting story about this church inside the house
A unique place. Very interesting piece of history. Well designed and unique. located close to the center of Amsterdam. Be there an hour before they close
Very interesting, small museum.. Although we had read about this place we were still amazed at the size and beauty of the secret church. The audio tour was very informative.

Amazing. I'd read about this and while not really into museums this is amazing! If you get the chance to go please do,it's a great way to spend an hour or two. 10 euro entry right in the red light district .

Wonderful!!. We visited here having spotted it on Tripadvisor. Wow! We had the most amazing morning here. The audio guide is great and the building is beautiful. We would definitely recommend to anybody visiting Amsterdam. €10 entry and a few windy stairs but totally worth every step.

Extremely surprising. The audio guide is easy to use- you point it at a button at various locations though the house and then follow the commentary at your own pace. It is very informative about the life of 17th C merchants. Nothing can prepare you for the scale of the Church! An incredible feat of faith. We were very interested too in the explanations as to how they brought up linen from barges on the canal below - you can still see the wheel that turned the pulley system. The little dark apartment on the ground floor was a stark contrast to the fine merchant's house.

This "attic" is definitely worth your time. A couple of members of my party weren't sure they would get anything out of this museum: they so did. It's inspirational. The tour itself is nicely done, with an individual audio commentary included in the ten-euro entrance price. This means you can go around at your own pace and take time to look at the things you want to look at. You start on the lower levels of a canal house and gradually work your way up to the top -- via some very twisty and turny staircases along the way, it has to be said (take that into account).When you see the "attic", it takes your breath away. That people made this, and kept it secret, is a testament to human determination. Don't miss the folding pulpit video! These guys out-IKEAd IKEA a couple of centuries ago.The sunny and sweet cafe is a great place to re-group after the tour, take a sandwich and some coffee, and talk about what you found the strangest / oddest / most remarkable aspect of the experience. You won't see anything like this anywhere else, and that's why it's worth your time in Amsterdam.

Small museum Well worth it with the audio. You work your way up through these old buildings to come to this magnificent small 'secret' place of worship. Well explained in the extremely helpfull audio.

Immersive Experience. Walking through the 17th century house not only allows you to see the hidden church for yourself, but shows you how people lived in an Amsterdam canal house when the church was first being used. It was immersive, informative, and impressive.

Most Unique Experience/Tour on our trip to Amsterdam. The museum was so well curated/produced. Take the time to do the free audio tour. Who knew that people back in the day had to hide the fact that they were Catholics. Apparently many people built churches in their attics - but this one luckily was saved vs. renovated to make room for some modern living area.All the details and the history behind this unique museum was well-maintained and produced. Truly a must-visit!

A Great Surprise. We came across this wonderful piece of religious history in Amsterdam by learning about it from a Rick Steeve's video. It is quite inspirational to see, to understand the determination of people of faith to worship under oppressive circumstances.

A resonant experience. Some museums can leave you elated, perhaps because of a specific focus, or the taste of an individual collector; others worthy but weary, however interesting the highlights: Van Gogh v Rijksmuseum, perhaps. This hidden church in a merchant's houses falls squarely in the first category; I haven't been this impressed by a historical attraction in a long while. The short version of the audio guide - I passed on the additional detail - is perfectly pitched, and the final comment from the museum's Director quite moving. If a paper copy's not available onsite, make sure you read the short speech on 'Voices of Tolerance' by Russell Shorto, given there on 22 September 2015; it might even change your life a little! Oh, and the cafe is a calm place to reflect upon what you've just learned.
A must visit. Well run and very ionteresting place. Need to be agile to get up the stairs. Good place to eat a snack.
Genuine place of worship. Great way to spend an hour or two on a rainy day, the church is actually in the attic of three houses and is a sight to behold. well worth a visit.

Unique location. This museum used to be a hidden church in the old centre of Amsterdam. It's definitely worth a visit: you'll be hard pressed to find a museum like it and it gives you a good perspective on the history of Amsterdam. Also, in a very convenient area and no ridiculous queues like at other museums.

Hidden gem . Well what can I say go see this church , it's a look back in history . The experience doing the tour has left a sadness in me to see what Catholics people done years ago to keep there faith and there church . This place was amazing . Only €10 and worth every penny .

Very well presented. The museum is great, the audio presentation takes you through the exhibits at your pace. It is hard to describe or quantify, you really have to experience it, not only from the religious aspect but the historical aspect of the life in the 17th Century fascinating is the only word to describe it
Such a surprise. The WOW factor was the revelation towards the end of the visit of this amZing space built within the attic of the house. Make sure you see the video of the hidden pulpit.

Interesting History. I must have passed by this place ten times without realizing it, it's located outside the red light district and a popular street of "coffee shops" but stepping inside was like being transported into a different world. There are free audioguides for every language that guide you through this 400 year old house that blends together Dutch history and it's foundation of tolerance. I found the museum very enjoyable and informative. Student discounts offered.

great visit - what a surprise. had used tripadvisor to look for "must do things in amsterdam" .. this didn't disappoint .. great visit, myself and partner are not religious but if you like a museum\old history this definitely is a must .. it is in the red light district and on the side of the canal behind one of the main churchs in the area .. from the outside it is a very modern looking museuem with a glass and very white frontage and reception area .. what you find behind and above it is unbelievable .. fascinating to say the least (partner preferred this one to the Anne Frank visit. 2o euros for both of us but very well spent. ..

A must-see tucked away. Excellent time capsule in Amsterdam's history. Dating back hundreds of years, see how the arrival of the protestant church affected the catholic faithful and a wonderful example of how people lived centuries ago.

For something completely different. A complete church hidden in the attic of a house, it doesn't get more interesting than that. We didn;t know what to expect but were very positively surprised. Even for non-religious people
Amazing little place to walk around. Great little museum hidden in red light district, great audio guide and easy to self-guide. Cafe is great too - thoroughly recommend.

a blast from the past. If I haven't been told and guided by my friend about this, I probably wouldn't have known or found it. It's a very interesting place to visit as if you've travelled back in time.
This is a must-see in Amsterdam!!. What a beautiful building and fascinating story. You must make the time to see this on your trip to Amsterdam.
Lovely. Took a bit of locating. Even the information bureau hadn't heard of it! Excellent small museum with a clever guide system. Unusual and well worth the visit!

Clever mix of ingenuity and resources and history. Facinating example of an original building to view the archtecture, the historical changes in the way of life of Amsterdam, the ruling and religious parties. The society and cultural influences in the furniture and use of the building, not least of course the attic! Very absorbing and a must do if you visit

Loved it! Best audio/secret church. A great audio guide accompanys this surprisingly large museum, where church services were hidden away and houses were knocked through to house pipe organs 😊. Highlight of my week of museums and a nice surprise. I'm not even religious!

Not to be missed!!!. If visiting Amsterdam, make sure to visit Our Lord in the Attic! The museum is very well organized and extremely informative. Needless to say, it's also beautiful! My husband & I traveled with our 3 children (ages 3, 2, & 6 mo). Even my kids enjoyed it. There were a lot of stairs, but that's expected in Amsterdam. Enjoy!

Well worth a visit . Very interesting step into the history of Amsterdam. Amazing hidden church in the attic, but also the rest of the museum is a history lesson in how people have lived and bred over the centuries. View from the top floors are great, if you would like to see over the rooftops off old Amsterdam.

Pleasantly Surprised. Wasn't sure what to expect apart from a church in an attic, but it was so much more!From start to finish i was intrigued, interested and surprised with the fantastic audio commentary and the amazing house!I learnt so much about life in the Dutch Golden Age and the Amsterdam of old. Highly recommended for anyone interested in Amsterdam history and an immersive view into the past.
Good to see. Small, less visitors, good audio guide and an interest story. Easy understandable way catholic church work in the 1800 century in Amsterdam
Superb!. Extremely well preserved 17th century house, with its own catholic church inside, Top rate audio guide, in every languagesA model in Amsterdam museum

So much more than a church - fantastic attraction about Dutch life in the Golden Age. I wasn't sure of what to expect. We thoroughly enjoyed this attraction. It is a brilliant historical insight into Dutch life in the Golden Age. Very much recommended.

Interesting. A real pleasure to find this museum right in the red light district. Good audio guide, helpful staff and an interesting part of Amsterdam's history I didn't know much about. The balconies require a bit of a head for heights!

Very interesting church.. We checked out TripAdvisor and this church had some good reviews so we thought we'd check it out. It seemed a little disappointing at first but then we reached the attic. Definitely worth the visit even if you're not religious.

A truely memorable experience. This museum is beautifully presented with visitors allowed to wander round with an audio tour at their leisure. You get a real feel for how people lived and how the church in the attic was used. A remarkable place. Recommend the museum café for a reflective coffee with views across the canal.

Interesting museum . We met 2 ladies in a pub who worked here & recommended that we visit.We were not disappointed There was no queue to get in & it cost €10 each.On the top floor there is a hidden church [catholic] where the locals would worship years ago.Gives a good insight into the way of life back in the day.

A hidden gem..literally. we went to the museum as an afterthought...killing time before leaving for home on our last day but I am so glad that we did. I am not religious at all but found the building and its history absolutely fascinating...well worth visiting.

Wonderful opportunity to see a 17th century Amsterdam house with "hidden" church in the attic. We love exploring historical places. This provided plenty to interest us with a very good audio tour as part of the entrance ticket price. The house has some well preserved original features with contemporary furniture to help set the seen plus parts that have been recreated or restored carefully to the original colours/styles. We visited the cafe at the end of our tour and had good value and very tasty beer, soup and cheese and ham toasties

Tardis like building. Interesting place to visit with very good interpretation of the building. The building has been preserved as it was 400 years ago and tells a fascinating story of the lengths people will go to for their religion.

Unmissable!. This is a fascinating glimpse into Amsterdam's past. Beautifully updated, with an excellent audioguide, it is both a look into the life of a wealthy linen mercant but also the opportunity to see an amazing hidden Catholic Church hidden in the top three storeys of his house. Also excellent cafe and small shop.

A gem of a place. Recently updated and modernised, this is a must-see museum. Fascinating in terms of the history of the city and the architecturally clever way in which the buildings and hidden church were constructed.

Great window into Amsterdam history. Wonderful little museum that tells the story of how Catholic Amsterdam families worshiped in secret within the cramped confines of an average city house. Lots of restoration has taken place, but this is still a delicate building and a small museum, so do not expect to be wowed by the interpretive displays. The joy of this place is more about standing in the footsteps of the people who used this space so many years ago. The audio tour is also pretty good. You get to learn about a traditional dutch row house as well as religious history of Amsterdam.

Fascinating. We were told about this place by our accommodation owner. Otherwise we probably would have missed it. What an experience. The skill in the construction was amazing and it was an excellent insight to the history of Amsterdam
Worth a visit!. Interesting and very nicely set up. Audio tour is very entertaining. Staff very friendly. Second floor on new addition is not worth going up for.

How people lived in the 1660's. This is definitely worth a visit as it is all so well presented. The free audio guide (state of the art) gives great detail so worth the eductional opportunities. There are some wonderful seventeenth century delft tiles around the house.There are lots of narrow staircases which cannot be avoided.
great place. take the audio tour, it is a great experience such a surprise in the attic. but be careful lots of stairs to do, but quiet enough to take your time around there.
Wow!. The front of the church is very deceiving, you would never guess what is inside. Hence the story of how the church began. Well worth a visit!

Geweldig klein museum - huis. The museum represents both a hidden church (below the ceiling) and an old house in the centre of Amsterdam. Nice to see how people lived then and how things were organised around the "church". People still get married here or rent the place for baptizing their child, which makes it more lively.

Amazing what one can hide in an attic. Had not heard a lot about this attraction but was interested when introduced to the possibility of seeing a chapel hidden within a roof space. Glad we took the time to go here, was a great way to spend an hour in Amsterdam. The museum itself is modern and very clean. Well laid out and the use of free audio guides results in an easy and informative experience. The price was reasonable for entrance. Free lockers and cloakroom area to leave bags and coats. It is a bit tricky to realise where the museum is as there is nothing that actually states 'Our Lord in the Attic' instead look out for 'Ons' Lieve Heer op Solder'

Newly renovated - well worth a visit. This is a very atmospheric canal house, with furnished rooms on the lower floors and a hidden Catholic church in the attic.After the Reformation in 1578, Catholics were no longer able to conduct mass in public buildings, so hidden churches such as this one were contstucted in private homes.There is an excellent audio guide and a short introductory film before entering the historic rooms. The new entrance (via the house next door) provides additional space for a cafe, small shop and cloakroom - a great improvement.There are great views out over the canals and Amsterdam skyline from the windows on the top floor.

An interesting historical building, beautifully renewed. This 17th century canal house was recently renewed and renovated and is now well worth a visit. After the Reformation in 1578, Amsterdam became a Protestant city. In typical Amsterdam style, other religions were tolerated just as long as they kept themselves to themselves and worshipped only in private houses. Hence this Catholic church was constructed in the top floors of several interlinked canal houses.The rooms throughout the house are very atmospheric - kitchens lined with blue Delft tiles, bedrooms with closet-beds and a beautifully furnished parlour. At the top of the house is the church, complete with organ and altar. There are several big windows at the top of the house with great views out over the canals and the Amsterdam skyline.The new entrance to the historic house with the church in the attic is through a modern entrance next door. This provides extra space for cloakrooms, a small shop, a bright and welcoming cafe and extra exhibitions. A good audioguide is provided (available in many different languages) and a short informative film is screened before entering the house itself. When returning back into this basement room there is a window to view the foundations of the house - proof that the whole city really is built on timber piles. No wonder so many canal houses look a bit tipsy!All together an informative experience and a tribute to Amsterdam's history of tolerance. Amazing to see the interactive display showing just how many 'secret' places of worship (not just Catholic) were scattered across the city.This museum is open at 10.00 on Monday mornings - a quiet time, when not much else is open, so a good time to visit.

Fascinating Museum. The museum is well worth a visit. It is very well curated, giving the visitor an excellent audio-tour detailing the history of the house and its occupants. You will learn about the historical context of the secret Catholic churches in the Netherlands. The museum also talks about household life during the period. It takes roughly 45 minutes to do the tour. Be advised there are very steep stairs to climb in order to tour the house.

a hidden gem. This historic place is great for a quick but really interesting visit. It is not a traditional museum where you are going to read many boards about items behind glass. This place has a gorgeous warm feel to it, a beautiful interior that is interesting to explore, set on several levels in a town house style building. I loved the place and actually found it refreshing on a tourist level - interesting, beautiful, easy to take in, and not overloaded, although there is a place when travelling for this too. There are audio guides that will make the meaning out of this place, don't miss this or you might miss the whole purpose of the place.

Fascinating museum. Others have described the museum. I just ant to add that this and the City Museum were our favorite places to view on this trip. The living spaces are so interesting, and th church is jaw dropping. The structure is VERY difficult to,tour becaus of the extremely steep and narrow staircases, but if you are spry, it is not to be missed.

Context for Amsterdam's Famous Tolerance. Amsterdam is a city known for tolerance, and perhaps no museum in the city helps to put this into perspective like the Our Lord in the Attic Museum. At a time when Catholicism was illegal, wealthy canal house owners banded together to create a secret church in their attics. Officials probably knew, but they chose to turn the other cheek. The idea that this city once banned a religion and now accepts everyone openly and on his/her own merits provides valuable context for this unique city. This museum helps to demonstrate the roots and origins of Amsterdam's modern day tolerance. It's a special place that evokes special feelings. Although not one of the larger tourist attractions in the city, it really shouldn't be missed.

Unique to Amsterdam. This museum is worth going to. It is very interesting and it is easy to get a very good view of the entire thing in about an hour. It is in a not great part of town but just go during daylight as it is an area with many tourists. You won't see a museum like this anywhere else. Very specific to Amsterdam.

Just that little bit closer to Heaven. The main living area of this house is very dark but once you ascend to the top floor the light shines in to reveal a very different setting. You would not think it was part of the same building.

hidden gem. we went here only as it was part of package deal and was passing. Glad we did. FREE audio guide, informative, well preserved and decorated in all rooms we were allowed in. Best out of all the museums we went to....I hate religion!

Interesting as parat of the history of the churches in Amsterdam. This is a multi-story building with winding staircases, taking you from the ground floor to the area where services were held privately. There is some interesting early furniture in the priest's quarters and in the kitchen; and lots of period Delft tiles on the kitchen walls.

Authentic recreation of life in 17th century Amsterdam. This museum gives great insight into what it was like to live in Amsterdam in the 17th century. The dimly, lit corridors, authentic furniture and narrow stairs help to recreate this world. Then to finally arrive in the attic and see the church is an amazing experience. The audio tour is included in the entrance fee, it is excellent.

Make sure you visit!. I had read about this in a guide book and recommended it by a friend. Finding it wasn't particularly easy as it's signage is nice and subtle, possibly in keeping with its overall history. I thoroughly enjoyed learning about early Amsterdam and looking through the wonderful artefacts. Make sure you visit here!

Give yourself a few hours.. We came here on a recent trip as a place I would like. I LOVED it.You turn up, pay 10 Euros and walk into a very clinical and sterile white room. At that point I was ready to leave. But then you watch an introductory video and get transported into a 17th century Catholic hidey hole and the journey is fantastic. You are furnished with an audio guide that you really do need in order to fully appreciate the history of this gem. This is not just a place of worship. It is a guide to old Dutch life and society. It is a study of faith. It is a picture postcard of beauty. It is an art gallery. My favourite part was the main chapel. You can see on the balustrade, the different colours that it has been painted over the years. There is an awe-inspiring painting of the Baptism of Jesus behind the altar and I will leave you to find out where the pulpit is. Very economical in those times!After you exit the main building you have the option of visiting a museum with unusual artefacts and art which I recommend. All in all a beautiful place to visit.

Very nice House! You will get experience a lot about Dutch house from 17th Centuries with only one of this house.. I did not expect the experience from this house. It look simple. But inside many rooms to visit. I think we spend nearly more than one hours. My friend from Amsterdam explained me a lot about the Amsterdam people and the house. I think i get many experiences from this place. My boyfriend from Zoetameer also never been there. He was also satisfied visiting there.

Fascinating slice of history. When the Catholic church was banned, this hidden church offered a place to worship. Given the number of people it could hold, and who must have been easy to see entering and leaving, one suspects it was an open secret. A tribute to Dutch tolerance, in other words: "You're not supposed to have a church, but go ahead anyway."

Great experience, renovated new spaces make it easy to experience this gem. I highly recommend this church. It is very unique to Amsterdam and quite and amazing experience. There are a lot of stairs (like the rest of the city) but it really takes you back.

Fascinating . The only reason we didn't give this a 5 is because we enjoyed a couple of other places slightly more. Nonetheless, we absolutely loved this museum. The audio tour is free which is unusual for Amsterdam. Very informative. Its just absolutely fascinating to see how this huge church was constructed in the roof of a seemingly small building. How deceptive! The history behind it is well explained and engaging. Not only do you learn about the church, but also about the owner of the house and his family. The audio tour also includes optional information on the paintings.Such an incredible construction. Definitely worth a visit.

Great place to visit even if you are not the holy person. Great place to visit , you are allowed to find your own way round with a head set provided to give you the detail on lots of the information within the building ...

Enjoyable and informative museum and Church visit. We spent about an hour exploring the Museum and Church in the Attic while visiting Amserdam. It's easily located in the canal area red light district.. Learned the historical significance of the hidden churches and also glimpsed what life in early Amsterdam might have been like as the house and furnishings provide great insight. We learned something about tolerance and recommend cpvisit. Some of the stairs are very narrow and steep, so all parts might not be available to mobility impaired. We found this attraction very worthwhile

Impressive must-see (and free audio tours). The actual three-tiered church is quite something and very much worth a stop. It's right in the heart of the old town, so chances are you'll be in the area during your visit. Plenty of background tells you why they had to build the church in the attic, and what was very neat was how you are guided through the actual house, set up as it would have been hundreds of years ago.

Unusual and surprising. I did not know what to expect but this beautifully preserved 17century Canal House is a really good example of life in the Golden Era of Amsterdam and the beautiful hidden church in the attic is breathtaking!

Unmissable, unique and moving landmark. Under the roof of an antique merchant's house of the 16th century, split on several levels, an entire church lies hidden. It was built to shelter Christians' gatherings and cult during protestantism. It is something unique, never seen before and definitely unmissable.

Interesting. Part of an informal walking tour we were on. I recall the red light district being very close by. Very well restored and the audio tour was informative in english. Lots of stairs to climb and they are very tight and winding.

Amazing history. We were amazed to discover this museum and the history it represented. Had no idea about the religious divisions and how long the issues lasted. You would have no idea this church was there from the outside of the building.

Beautiful attraction which is off the beaten path. The Lord in the Attic is a beautiful church with an incredible history hidden inside one the the multi-story homes found throughout Amsterdam. In the 1500's Catholicism was outlawed however the Dutch allowed the religion to be practiced as long as it was done privately. At one time there were many such churches but now this is one of the few remaining. It is a must see attraction..if just from a historical perspective. A great rainy day activity.

Hidden in plain sight in the Red Light District. What a wonderful and unique surprise! If you are in Amsterdam for any length of time, be sure to put this little church on your to do list. You will not be disappointed. Don't stay away because you may be thinking it's just like the rest of the churches you have seen. It is NOT. Make sure you use their audioguide. It is well done and very informative. This is not a place for handicapped individuals or those unable to climb stairs. Some doorways are a little confined, and the stairways are narrow and steep. While in there, take time to study the architecture. What an amazing feat. As they say..."out of necessity." If you plan on visiting other museums in Amsterdam, purchase the Museum Card as it eliminates standing in line.

Little known attraction, but truly deserves a visit. This was one of the recommended visits in our guide book, that immediately did not attract our attention - but a visit was made and it was well worth our time. Nestling in the Red Light district, it can easily be missed but do not make that mistake. Not one of the big museums, but an intriguing exhibition that is almost unbelievable from the outside. A real history eye-opener that is both moving and amazing to view - you will not be disappointed if you pay this museum a visit. No queues when we were there, so you can just turn up and get in without any hassle. One of our favourite visits during the week in Amsterdam.

Beautiful . This little church and museum is just lovely. It really is worth a visit. As you go through the house towards the chapel you are transported back in time. When we were there the crib was up. The engineering of it and the size is remarkable. Highly recommend. It is situated on the edge of the red light district.

A pleasant surprise. I was a little skeptical after having seen so many churches in Europe. Once you have seen one, you've seen most (with the exception of the bone chapel outside of Prague). However this was different enough to be interesting and offered more than I was expecting. I certainly stayed there longer than I would have guessed prior to my visit and would recommend it if you only want to see one church in Amsterdam.

More than just another church. Also known as 'Ons' Lieve Heer op Solder" which shows as a separate listing on Trip Advisor. I thought we were just going to see a tiny church restored in the attic of a house. Pleasantly surprised to discover much more with the original decor of the houses below that combined their roof space to make the church. Authentic and original furnishings including staircases, wall hangings and wallpaper. Whilst lights were all now electric, they had minimal light to reflect the candle light to give you a feel for the 'lighting' of prior centuries. Audio guides are a part of the price but with steep staircases, not recommended for those who may need assistance walking.

This was a highlight of our five day trip to Amsterdam.. Don't attempt this if you are feeble or less than nimble, as there are multiple staircases, some quite narrow, to climb--but what a treat! Good audio-guides available. The preserved historic house is almost as interesting as is the church. Rick Steves' CD about Amsterdam covers this gem, and was the reason we decided to put it on our list.

Absolutely Stunning!. We weren't aware of this place until we arrived in Amsterdam and we where so glad we found it. The museum had not long been renovated and is very modern. The electronic system for listening to information around the museum was also very modern and easy to use. But most importantly the place is gorgeous! It is definitely worth a visit, or two.

Fabulous surprise. This is a small gem. An instructive audioguide provides a rich history of the creation of this house of worship during a period of religious suppression. The steps are well worth the climb!

A secret Catholic Church in the attic of a canal house. This church is in the attic of a canal house. It has been preserved likes in your from as it would have been during those times (the church with pews and an alter). The typical decor from a canal house and from catholicism church of the era. The tour audio guide to explain everything (in different languages explains every detail).

Got to go!. We stumbled across this museum whilst on a walking tour and decided to pay it a visit. What a fantastic place. Whilst it looks fairly ordinary from the outside, the surprises when you go in are amazing. There is a very good audio guide, built in to the price of €10 - well worth the money. We spent around 90 minutes in the museum and it was time well spent. Probably the highlight of our trip!

A must-see.. No description of this museum does it justice. The church is an architectural feat, the history of the entire house deep. I appreciate very much how meticulously the space has been restored and the attentiveness to its sacred place in history. The included audio guide is enlightening without being overwhelming or boring. My curiosity was piqued at every turn. I'd certainly suggest a visit to anyone able to climb many stairs (some of them steep) who is interested in this unique period of Amsterdam history.

Serenity in a chaotic neighbourhood. Quite a fascinating small museum. Besides the highlight of the museum, the hidden church, the audio tours provides interesting information on the history of the house and its various functions through the ages. The friendly cafe is a nice place for a drink and a snack overlooking the canal. A small jewel in the middle of the notorious and tourist-packed red light district.
a must-see. Great little compact church , ingeniously put together, very much like Amsterdam itself.It could be a problem getting around if it got crowded.

Unexpected delight!. We wanted to see the church in the attic, but this museum offers so much more. The "house" consists of 3 houses, 1 large and 2 small and the visit includes so many rooms, giving a real glimpse of life in days gone by. Each time you turn a corner or ascend/descend a staircase there is another room to see! it is very interesting and good fun. The audio guide is great. This is another brilliant museum in Amsterdam.

Worth a visit. This was worth a visit. Basically, during the reformation Catholic worshippers had to go "under ground" or in this case "above ground". All the fancy trimmings in the Catholic churches were destroyed. This little Catholic church was constructed in the top floors of a canal house. It's worth a peak as long as you can traverse the narrow, twisting stairs to the top. The entrance was via a tunnel that connected the house to a museum next door.

Very well curated audio guide. Excellent museum well presented and explained. It was nice and quiet when we visited, which is good in such a small museum with so many small rooms. A really good value 10 euros.

Historically enlightening. For an American, this house offers an unique glimpse of history: the persecuted Catholic, instead of the persecuted Protestant. In addition to the religious historical value, the architecture also demonstrates development over almost 200 years.

Highly recommended. Although I noticed a review which criticised the entry fee (10 euros), in my opinion the fee was totally justified. This building is a hidden gem. The restoration is excellent and audio tour very informative. The top three floors of the house were converted into a chapel which is absolutely amazing. Make sure you visit!

Hidden Church Museum. Deep inside a house sits a full Catholic church that was used in the 17th century during the Protestant reformation. The museum provides an audio guide to help you understand the conditions that led to the hidden church and what life was like in the house. I would like to go back again and have a guided tour and there is just so much to see and absorb and the audio guide was a bit awkward to use albeit excellent content.
Very Worthwhile. A really unique experience and a story that should be better known. Left this until late in the trip as an add on -- very glad that we were able to fit it in.

Absolutely yes. We visit this strange,curious church just because we had the iamsterdam city card,but it's a place to see in Amsterdam, the audio guides that the museum provides you are perfect to bring you into the world of the old city.Don't miss it.

Don't miss Our Lord in the Attic!. Our Lord in the Attic was by far one of my favorite activities in Amsterdam! The audio tour is extremely well done and the points of interest through the museum are easily followed and very well done! Allow yourself an hour and a half or so and don't miss this beautiful and really interesting piece of Amsterdam's history!
A piece of history. This hidden treasure is well worth visiting and shows a chapter of Dutch history not widely known. Shows the power of the human spirit. Glad to have seen this.

Amazing. This is a typical merchant house of the golden age. When the Catholic cult was forbidden many rich catholics used to offer their house as churches.
This is one of these. It's well conserved and well explained by the audioguide.

Fascinating piece of history. We found this fascinating piece of history hidden in Amsterdam, and would recommend it to anyone who is interested in churches, or history. Set in an ordinary street in the Red Light District, it is a well preserved church, built 1663 in the attics of three houses when Catholics faced persecution . The furnishings and silver are beautifully kept and we enjoyed an unhurried visit. I would definitely recommend a visit.
Intruiging & interesting. worth a visit to find out more about the history of Amsterdam, probably best for adults ( not so good for kids )

Stunning!. Not a churchgoer but a must see. Need to be fully fit though..a lot of steep stairs..lovely quirky place and, I'm sure, if you are of the faithful a special place to worship..I'd combine it with a visit to the Old Kirk..nearby

Must take a tour to see it. I was disappointed that you must buy an expensive and LENGTHY tour to see this church. We only had about 45 min free before an appointment, so was disappointed to miss out on this. Admission fee also seemed very steep to enter a church.

Life in XVII century. This small museum shows how people lived in Amsterdam in the golden age: XVII century: saloon full of great paintings, beds with lot of pillows, rather primitive kitchen, not mentioning bath and WC... Also the hidden church is very beautiful. Great place.

An interesting attraction which isn't too touristy.. For many years Roman Catholics were forbidden to practice their religion in The Netherlands so this church was hidden from authorities at the top of a canal house. It has been preserved as it would have been during those times and is extremely well set out and organised. It displays chalices, candelabra, priests clothing/robes, etc, as well as the church with pews and an alter. There is a wonderful audio guide to explain everything.The other interesting aspect was being able to venture inside a Dutch canal house and view the interior. There weren't too many tourists to spoil the visit.

Way more than you expect. The museum preserves a house-church for 17th century Catholics which, while not illegal was best kept out of sight, out of mind. For 10 euros, it was actually a great exploration of 17th century Dutch home and business life, as well as home worship for a minority group. It's also kinda funny going to a museum about a church...in the Red Light District. Hang on to your admission ticket, it gets you discounted admission to the Bijbelsmuseum (Bible Museum) and two others.

Unbelievable. We went here on our last morning. It's in the heart of the Red Light District and is so quirky. Amazing that a hidden Catholic Church would be in the attic. Such a wonderful place to find. Go and see as you get the chance to see how a 17th Century canal-side house would have been. Fascinating.

Very special place. This is a very special place to visit. In the time that the catholic church was prohibited this church was build secretly in an old building all the way upstairs...they could easely transfor it if somebody found out, they thought about everything. Being here really helps you think about the time when choosing your religion wasn't something normal. I think this is a very special place to see when visiting Amsterdam, not to mention the location of this museum..in the middle of the red light district...with a lot to see, too many good restaurants and bars and a lot of fun around you.
.Little known treasures.. Guide from Red Light tour told us about this place. Worth seeing. Would have never found it if he hadn't pointed it out to us.

Incredible site. This is a wonderful place to visit for anyone interested in history, religion, Amsterdam and architecture. The museum is very well staffed and a wonderfully run. It is amazing to wander your way up through this beautiful old canal house and see what awaits in the attic. Truly incredible!

Amazing. Go right when they open. I did not expect this exhibit to be as amazing as it was. You are able to see the entire house and the chapel. It is so interesting and a beautiful example of a house church. I recommend going as soon as they open, we were 1 of 4 ppl there due to our early arrival and took amazing photos. When we left it was crowded. This is NOT to be missed!!

So cool! . Worth a visit! It's crazy to me hoe people had to hide-at least here they were able to hide in plain sight-what type of Christianity and even religion in general they practiced. Go and see how lucky we are today!
Excellent experience. This was a real gem and really transported you back in time. I haven't been to a museum like it, and the location of the museum makes it all the more unusual.

A great slice of the history of Amsterdam. A very interesting museum, providing a fresh perspective on the meaning of religious tolerance, and faith. It is also a fascinating insight into a period of Amsterdam's long history.

Do not let the word "attic" fool you. Attic the church might be located, but the museum spans the entire building, showing you how the people in the pass lived and prayed, how they hid from the authorities. It was informative and a great place to explore the nook and cranies of the house.

Visit this place before most of the other sights in Amsterdam. Visit here early in your stay as it gives you a great idea of a merchants house from the golden age with the added twist of having a catholic church in the attic. Its beautifully kept and the audio guide was well done and informative.

Tolerance or discrimination?. A hidden church for the Roman Catholics, built during the era that protestantism ruled Holland. Freedom of conscience was granted, but "other" religions should not be adhered in public. Not only is this beautiful restored place an example of such a church, but also of a merchant home in the Golden Age. A little bit to the north is a good microbrew pub "De Prael"

When "freedom of faith" means "only in private". After the protestant reformation in the 16th century this catholic church functioned for more than 200 years in a private home. This site has recently - as many other Dutch attractions - been renovated in a fine way. The audio tour is recommendable.

Definitely worth a visit. This museum shows how life could have been in Amsterdam back in the day. The audioguide is excellent, the rooms are well decorated, the history is great and the church is amazing. The museum offers so much more than just the church though, and I recommend taking time to listen to all the audio in the different rooms. One of my favorite museums!

So amazing !! A beautiful little find in the Red Light District. Great audio tour, highly recommended!. Hardly expected this to be as good as it was! So intricate and lovely. Very glad we found it. Lots to look at and very informative audio tour.
something different. Felt more like a church not museum. Outside looks ordinary building but in the inside the church part is very intresting and beautiful. Not hard to find.

Wonderful preserved house and attic Church. The very modern interior of the museum all in blinding white hides a beautifully preserved period house with original artefacts on display. All very quaint and fascinating to walk around. You feel you have been transported to the past. The church in the attic is its stunning centrepiece and is a real sight to behold. The audio guides are a must and are very interesting. Great you can snap pictures too. Nice cafe too.

A wonderful connection with the past. This was nothing like I expected. I thought that I would find a small altar in a dark attic, but nothing prepared me for this. It is breathtaking and beautiful. The audio tour provides a very good commentary, with nice optional "side-lights" if you want to know more. The history of the house and it's owner are also well covered. Highly recommended, but note - several narrow stair-cases to negotiate.

A nice low-key experience. This is a secondary museum that's still interesting if you want to get a glimpse at Dutch life in the 17th and 18th century, and get that clandestine feel as you ascend to the secret(-ish) church in the attic. It's particularly recommended if you want to get a bit of a break between more intense visits, as it only takes around an hour and isn't crowded at all.If you want to take pictures, be aware that most of the rooms are quite dark and mobile phones will struggle with the low light conditions.

Beautiful, good information. This museum can be done relatively quickly, in about an hour. There is a lot of good information given by an individual audio tour. There are options for getting more information on specific items, like paintings, within each room. Being inside the church and even just the house itself is an awesome experience. My favorite part was being in the attic above the sanctuary and being able to see the wheel for the pulley system. Actually getting to be in a canal house and seeing how it would have been set up far in the past was great as well.

An amazing story!. You will not be prepared for what is inside this church-in-a-house. Amazing. There is an audio device that explains each of the exhibits and it was very helpful. We had just an hour before closing, and that was ALMOST enough time to see everything at a reasonable pace. You enter and get tickets at what looks like a gift shop with large, modern windows--we wandered around for some time with an incorrect address before we found it.

Our LADY In the Attic. I have been here several times and I could swear it called our LADY in the Attic, not Our Lord in the Attic? Anyway, this place is a real gem, not to be missed. Tucked away in the red light district, and for some reason a bit off the radar, but really interesting, and well worth a visit.

small miracle in the red light district. when the Catholic faith was not acceptable in this Protestant country (17th century) chapels and churches were hidden away and disguised as canal houses. The attic of two adjacent canal houses in the red light district accommodates a wonderful Baroque Catholic church...a MUST SEE to believe it.t

Must visit if Catholic. A great little museum that looks into the time of the 18th century. You get an understanding of Amsterdam's pragmatism and its liberalness. The new place next door is a great addition.
It is a disappointing that it no long holds regular mass and they changed the candles to electric

Recommended visit if you mhave an hour to spare in central Amsterdam. Unexpected value and interesting visit to town house near Red Light District. Very good audio guide system and flexible closing hours (we were late)

Charming hidden attic church. This clandestine hidden church seems so unlikely from the street sitting as it does within the red-light district. But there is a fascinating and unexpected story behind the facade. The staff were very welcoming and knowledgeable. This is a place to linger, to reflect on what appearance is and to dream.

A little gem. We visited at 4pm and wondered whether we had enough time to view but the museum staff said 45mins-1hr was long enough. We stayed 1.25hrs and could have stayed another quarter of an hour. So allow an hour and a half. Visiting at this time of day is also quite atmospheric, wandering around the house as dusk falls.There are lockers for your belongings (this is a small space) and toilets. Steep stairs (with some shallow treads) to negotiate. The free multimedia tour is really good.A fascinating insight into hidden Catholicism in the 17thC.

Interesting, but not done real well. This is a very interesting place to visit. It was a secret church established in the 1600's inside buildings that don't look like a church. Inside it is surprising how they sculpted a sanctuary. However, you walk around in shoe coverings and a head set. When I went at the end of 2014, it was under renovation and construction, so it was very disappointing. Hopefully when it's finished, they will give it due respect and have made an excellent exhibit out of these brave people who dared to worship when it was against the law.

Fantastic museum. Beautifully restored and presented 'house church' with a great story attached. Really well worth a visit, even if you are not interested in the religious history the building is amazing and the way the space was created fascinating.

fascinating history and great tour. I really loved this museum -- so much I went back again! It was the best audio tour I did in Amsterdam. It is about a hidden Catholic Church that people went to when Catholicism was outlawed in the Netherlands. You can do it in about an hour.

not too many tourists and the best audio tour in Amsterdam. This museum is in a secret Catholic Church in the attic of several houses. At times in Dutch history, the Catholic Church was outlawed and Catholics met in secret in private homes. This stunning beautiful church is worth the visit. The audio tour explains every detail of the building, the typical decor of the era(s) and the features of the church in the attic. The tour can be done well in about an hour.

A must see. I knew nothing about this hidden gem prior to my visit, in fact I would have walked by it and not noticed. However, what a find. A 17th century merchants house with a fantastic history. The tour was an audio guide which gave a good insight into the life of the household. The surprise at the end, a church in the attic, stunning. Not to be missed.

A beautiful peek in historic Dutch life, and hidden religion. Not too touristy (yet, and hopefully stays this way). The free audit tour provides you with a very interesting story about this house and its history. You get an idea of how people lived in this area, how they managed to hide their Catholic gatherings. It taught me a lot about my own city! Not to be missed!

Interesting find on the canals. The house itself gives you a feeling of how Dutch merchants lived during the Dutch Golden Age, and the chapel in the attic is an interesting peculiarity. The price is not too expensive either and there are free audio-guides in quite a few languages. If you want to know how a Dutch house's interior looked like and if you want to do something different, I suggest you to invest one hour of your holiday in this little museum.

Journey back in time. It's a very interesting museum that takes you back in the old days.... You probably already walked past this museum but didn't have a clue that there is one... ^^ You get an audio guide that takes you through the building and tells you the history. It's worth a visit.

Hidden Gem. Tucked away on the edge of the Red Light District is this hidden gem of a museum. Another don't miss place that doesn't get a lot of traffic. Make sure you get the audio set, its well worth it.
This is a must see.. Our family ranks this as the #1 site to see in Amsterdam and for some reason not that many people go to see it.
What an amazing place. My sister had recommended that we went to this church and she was 100% right. There was a multistory church that was totally beautiful.
Do not miss this. At first it is a fabulous chance to see inside a 17th century house, then you go into the attic. I'd seen the pictures but it didn't prepare me for the wow factor
Jaw dropping. A must do. You learn so much about the people of Amsterdam and their culture on a visit to this beautiful church. Another great recommendation from That Dam Guide.
Very special. I can't say I think it's a must see, but it is truly unique a museum and very well organised. Thus recommended.

Museum not to be missed. This was a great museum that captures a lot of Amsterdam's history. I finally understood what fueled the rise of Calvinists. Absolutely fascinating site. Plus you get a really good idea of how a canal household looked like during that time.
My favorite sight!. Don't miss this fascinating building - a wonderful mixture of centuries, unfolding tales, juxtapositioned functions.

Hidden gem. My brother-in-law got married here over 13 years ago. That was my first meeting with this church/museum. Since then I visited it several times with friends to show how far Catholics had to go to be able to practice their belief ina protestant part of Holland, way back.

Hidden gem. Beautiful story of tolerance and ingenuity of people in Amsterdam in the times when tolerance was just a term. The church for catholics in the protestant country and in the same time the shop and the house for the merchant family. Nice example why this is so open country for people of different beliefs and life choices. Do not miss it!

A Little Treasure. The reason I went is I knew where it was and there was just enough time to see it before the cruise ship sailed. We made a great choice; the house is truly delightful. First there is the house with all the twists and turns, brought to life by the stories in the audio guide and topped off with the truly amazing church in the attic The audio guide which is easy to use is included in the admission price The staff is exceptional Then there are extra exhibits in the new wing The house has an amazing story and the exhibits are so well curated Great washrooms

Amazing museum.. A great museum showing the way people lived at this time. After an interesting but steep climb up through the house an amazing church hidden away at the top. Not for the elderly or people with walking difficulties. The stairs are VERY steep and narrow.

Fantastic. The house/church were under a slight renovation when I went in August 2015 but no part of the house or church is off limits. Very cool! Audioguide is provided and very helpful and if you have the IAmsterdam card you get entry at no cost. Definitely worth a visit if you are going to be in the Red Light District.

Fascinating look at hidden church. This museum/attraction has been updated recently, and it's now a five-star attraction in my book. Wonderful audio tour is included. We even ate at the cafe, a nice convenience when you have a short time in Amsterdam and so much to see!

A Historical Building as Witness of practised Tolerance. In this building - which is a Museum now - there is a hidden church in the attic. The City of Amsterdam became Protestant in the 8o-year war. Basically practising any other religion in public was forbidden, however tolerated behind closed doors. The rich German merchant Jan Hartman built the hidden church in 1663 at the top of this house which he owned. There is so much to see in this Museum and feel very close how life was in the 17th century in Amsterdam.

Literally a Hidden Gem . It was not easy to find as it is not a big building or full of tourists queuing but it is definitely a must see if Amsterdams story and culture is to be known. If you don't have much time to visit The Amsterdam museum, this would be an even better substitute.
Unexpected jewel in Amsterdam. Fascinating insight into the theological history of Amsterdam with this well layed out museum. Well worth a trip.
Amazing!. What an experience! I thought this was one of the best tours we did in Amsterdam. To see the church in the attic was unreal and touching..

A secret find.. Wasn't sure if I wanted to visit but turned out to be the highlight of my amsterdam visit. Loved the audio aspect of tour as learnt so much, it was so interesting and breathtaking when you see how the internals of the houses was transformed into a church. You could so easily walk by this museum especially as distracted by so much else of what is going on around in the Red Light District . A real find and a must visit.

Beautiful hidden little church. This was an unplanned stop off, a passer by mentioned it so we thought we'd check it out. The church is intimate and beautiful, no longer functioning as a place of worship but well done and refurbished to the original spec. Lady Chapel and Sacristy are intact, with a small number of original liturgical vestments on display. Explains how the underground Catholic community were able to practice their faith. Teenager in tow, didn't find it as interesting as us...

Makes your heart soar to the heavens. Been here earlier, maybe 2x, about 10 or more years ago. Visited today with tour group, if you have 10+ people, you can arrange via website. Enjoyed renovated entrance with small gift shop. Tour guide was outstanding, Arjan V., sharing so many details of museum that you otherwise might miss. They still have Mass here maybe once a week, and you can arrange for weddings and maybe other functions. Don't miss this small museum if you are touring Amsterdam.

Charming glimpse of history. If you like to learn something of the history of a place you are visiting, then this is the place for you. It tells the story of a wealthy catholic trader who builds a secret place of worship for local Catholics in the top 3 floors of his house. The audio tour is first rate, and although you are expecting it, the attic church is still quite shocking and magnificent. The church was one of over 30 similar secret places of worship which were allowed to function undercover. Ironically it became redundant when religious tolerance meant the large St Nicholas Church was built nearby. Ironic because St Nicholas is the patron saint of prostitutes and this is on the edge of the red light district. Recommended.
Really amazing place. I was expecting a mini church in a top bedroom. This is a full scales church across three floors of two house. Best part of our visit.

It just got better the more you went up.... Not usually a great fan of RC Churches, but this church in the attic is both brilliant to see as a visitor and also asks some compelling questions about tolerance and attitude (and also where the money lies...)Had to walk through the red light district to get at it (a bit of Amsterdam I just didn't fancy at all) but once through (it was lunchtime so not that much to see really) then the museum was just brilliant

Most beautiful secret church in Amsterdam. The church dates from early 17th century when city’s Catholics were allowed to practice only in private. This used to be a clandestine church which occupies the loft in a wealthy merchant’s house. It is very compact and well decorated. The tour of the church is very interesting and aided through an effective audio guide. I will recommend a visit to this church if you are in Amsterdam.

Well worth a visit!. I had been before but visited this small (but only in size!) and not internationally known museum jus a few weeks after Queen Maxima re-opened it. Rather ironical that such a religious place should be in the Red Light district!
Vaguely interesting for an atheist.. Spent a few minutes in here as part of a walking tour. Fairly interesting history and architecture for a pit stop.

Fascinating hidden church. This museum was fairly low on my list of museum visits I wanted to make in Amsterdam and I went on my last day in the city. It was one of the best museums and is definitely not one to be missed. The free audio guide was excellent and you are encouraged to go round the house at your own pace. The three uppermost floors, where the unexpectedly large hidden church was built is indescribable and full of surprises. A complete gem.
surprise. we were really surprised to see this church in an attic, our friend told us how it was hidden. Well worth a visit

Atheist, but found it very interesting. I want sure what to expect from it initially, but found the story of its history very interesting.The museum it's self takes you up through the houses, climaxing as the hidden church and then back via a different route.There can be some quite steep stairs and you'll have to ware show protectors but it's well worth it I'm my opinion. I highly recommend the free audio guide, and just taking your time.

This is so nice. Living in Amsterdam doesn't mean that you have visited all the museums. Euhh, sorry for that. But sometimes i have the urgency to visit one. I went with the lady to this place full of history. It is a little hidden church in the middle of the red light district. They build it secretly in the past, because that was in a period that the government had forbidden certain religies. It is so nice to walk overthere, you feel the past.
Unexpected museum. A full audio tour lwad us around thw whole house and church. From the outside you would not known it was there
Very Special to visit.. In the middle of the famous red light district a Catholic church that had to go into hiding when the Protestant religiun dictated so. 17th Century all around.

Don't miss this. This is a hidden gem that should not be missed when visiting Amsterdam. It was a church created in the roof of some houses which enabled worshippers to continue worshipping in secret when various religious clampdowns had occurred. Some of the rooms that you pass through are quite small, and at times you feel a bit like an explorer. If you have younger children, make sure you ask for the children's activity pack as it really helps to engage the child's imagination.

Terrific, for many reasons!. Luckily for me this gem opened the day I was leaving Amsterdam. Apparently closed for sometime for renovation, this is a must see in Amsterdam for many reasons. Not only is it a beautiful old townhouse on the canal in the old town, but the church on the top floors was amazing. At the time the church was built, Catholic were not allowed to celebrate Mass but the merchant who owned this home constructed a church on the top floors of his town house so that locals could attend Mass. Imagine a church in someone's home! And a beautiful home, at that!

Surprising!. We didn't really expect too much besides seeing a church at the top of this old canal house but it turned out to be a really excellent tour. They give you a free headset (you pay to enter) and it takes you from the basement to the top describing everything along the way. It was wonderful and I highly recommend it.

An unexpected delight!. See this place in real life is magnificent. The restoration to the home and the commentary that was provided with the headset, far out shined the Rembrandt House. This is an absolute "must see".

A Hidden Treasure. This Museum is a great opportunity to see and hear about the history of the Reformation and its impact on the Dutch people. As well as holding a hidden Catholic Chapel on the top floor the building looks as it did in the 17th century and you learn all about the life of a Merchant family. Great audio tour and beautiful building.
A hidden gem!. Make a little time for this beautiful hidden church, which really takes you back in time. Just fascinating.

Amazing!. Do not pass this museum up! The history of this building, the historical artifacts, the condition of its contents make this museum a real attraction. The religious history are additionally intriguing. Also, there was no line for this museum. It is less expensive than most museums (9 euros) and its on the IAMAmsterdam card.

Quick visit to the Museum Our Lord in the Attic. We weren't planning on visiting this museum while in Amsterdam because we didn't think we would have time; we were only there for two days. But we came across it by chance and decided to stop by. They were closing in half hour so we quickly went through the museum with the handset guided tour in English and were glad we did. The history behind this place is very interesting. Highly recommended.
