One of the top sights of Amsterdam .... so why doesn't it get more publicity? My wife happened to notice a small entry in the guidebook, so we thought we'd take a look. It's an extremely interesting building, with a number of rooms to visit. The audioguide is included in the price, with a fairly comprehensive, but not over-long, commentary. The church is the highlight, and it was far larger, and more impressive, than we thought it would be. The stairs are fairly steep in places, though we had no problems, and we're in our 70s. On the way out there's a modern part (actually in the building across the alleyway which runs alongside the house) with a nice cafe and clean modern toilets.Despite the lack of publicity, there were a fair number of visitors the day of our visit, so clearly it's well known.A slight negative : at some points there are video displays, and these are placed alongside the audioguide "scanning" points. It might have been better if they'd been a bit further away, so that those watching the videos didn't block access to the audioguide points.

Worth going to visit. This is a lovely well maintained museum, with a minimum of restoration. The house is kept as it was, and it is a marvel. You walk through a fairly plain house and come into the chapel it's breathtaking, and the new visitor centre is nice.

What a wonderful place to visit.. This sounded a very interesting place to visit and we were not disappointed. Great way to see round an old Amsterdam canal house and a really wonderful surprise in the attic. Be prepared to clamber up steep stairs, but really is worth the effort.

Hidden gem. I had to find this museum twice, because the first time, it was closed to the public while Queen Maxima was visiting for its grand opening after some major cosmetic work. It was worth going back for. It is just as surprising and gratifying as the photos suggest. You not only see the hidden church, with its organ, concealed pulpit, and all necessary articles for worship, but you see the matrix, the home of a merchant and his family. It is a little tricky to find, but not disappointing once you are there.

Worth a look……………Just. For the entrance fee it was only ok €20 for 2 they have spent a lot of money on the building next door to give you an underground access . The history of the situation is one thats repeated all over the world but there can't be many like this ! Its worth a look it was a shame the rest of the house has little character .

Awe-inspiring hidden church. Our Lord in the Attic Church or Amstelkring was established in 1663 as a safe haven for Catholics to worship together at a time when their worship services were illegal in Amsterdam. We visited in April, 2015 while renovations were still underway, but nonetheless our visit was inspiring. The church was built into the attics of three merchants' homes and embedded in the middle of the red light district of Amsterdam. The beautiful narrow chapel is a tribute to the religious freedom that the Catholic people sought in the 1600"s.
Another attic, not Anne's. Surprising, filled with history and how people lived in times of oppression. The staff were helpful.

Our Lord in th Attic. This is a must do for anyone visiting Amsterdam. After reading and planning our trip this was not high on my priority list but now that I have been I would tell anyone...for sure see this museum.

Wonderfull chapel built when catholic services were " private ". Like someone already wrote it is a temple of tolerance..... an example for us in our time.You can walk the house of the Catholic German magnate and see how they lived and the things they sherished

Amazing story about tolerance and ... intolerance. Preface by saying I am Roman Catholic which was part of my reason for wanting to visit. Interesting to see how the Spanish Inquisition generated such a (justifiable) backlash. Nonetheless, the dedication and devotion shown by these Catholics...for such a long time... was extraordinary. It is very well done in terms of the technology used to explain what your are seeing. Amazing story.

A gem worth discovering. What a treasure this is. We were unsure if the 10 Euro entry would be worth it to see a church in an attic, but came away so glad that we had gone. The audio guide is fascinating as you walk through the house as it would have been at the time when the church was in use as well as seeing the chapel itself. Be aware though that there are lots of stairs and some are steep and narrow!
Interesting and informative. The phenomenon of hidden churches was unknown to me until I visited this place. Its well-maintained and has many original artifacts.

An Unexpected Pleasure!. We did not know what to expect - but this attraction and the audio guide not only gave us an understanding of the purpose for and history of a beautiful little chapel, but the entire house has an interesting history and gives you a real sense of what it was like to live in one of the Amsterdam row houses 200 years ago. Exceptional information, helpful and caring staff - it was our favorite stop in Amsterdam.

Interesting museum. Interesting piece of history in Amsterdam; hard to find the entrance though as the front is under construction. We only found i because my cousin had been there before. It would be of more interest to a Catholic, as I am.
Hidden Gem. It's a hidden away gem of a place. Surreal. So glad I made the effort to find the place and see it. Must visit.

Hidden museum gem in the Red Light District. A beautiful example of preservation in Amsterdam. A great excuse to go the the Red LIght District without really "going there". A very interesting story of a man who was truly committed to the Catholic Church despite its removal from the country by the government.

Back in time. Vistor functions are concentrated in the new building so the house remains unspoiled. The winding stairs and small rooms seem authentically preserved - a fascinating insight into 17th and 18th century life behind the grand facades of the canal houses. The audio guide briefly introduces each area - you can choose to hear more. Many museums compromise for children - this is a well planned adult tour where learning about the house and its life adds much to the experience of the church at the end of the visit.

Wonderful surprise. Friends had suggested to visit this museum. I went with no expectations...it was such a good experience to have visited this gem. Nestled in the busy streets of the central area, we walked up to subtle entrance. Fee is €9.00. Worth paying because they provide you with an audio guide and also, they are doing lots of construction making the site more accessible and bigger. There's also lots to maintain so money is going to good use.

Interesting hideaway in the Red Light district. I heard about this church while on the city walking tour. The back story is very interesting and decided to check it out. From the outside, you would not even know there was a church hidden in this residence. The church itself is somewhat unique and you are able to visit the private rooms of the house. Well worth a visit if you have a Museumkart or iAmsterdam card.
Hidden Gem in Amsterdam. Great hidden gem in Amsterdam but sad that it was being renovated! Free audio tour as well which is always a plus!

One of our favorite small Amsterdam museums. This museum is very nicely laid out and you get a good sense of what is was like to live in a 17th century canal house and open up your home to other Catholics who could not practice their religion openly at the time. The church at the top of the building is very well preserved and there is a nice audio guide included in the fee that provides helpful information about the church and its founder.
Hidden Gem in Amsterdam. We mapped out Our Lord in the Attic before our trip to Amsterdam, and though it was hard to find, we found it quite interesting.

Humbling Experience but...... Very good for the authentic church in the attic and the story & history behind it, well worth the visit but the 10 euros per person to walk up three modern clinically designed floors of nothing to get there was pointless!!

A Must See. Just finishing renovation. A tribute to Amsterdam. When the Protestants kicked out the Catholics, the leadership in the country agreed to pretend that this secret Catholic church didn't exist. That sense of tolerance continues to this day. Definitely worth seeing.

Hidden church. A Catholic Church constructed in the upper floors of a canal house and two adjacent houses in central Amsterdam at a time when it was necessary to worship secretly. Been made into a small museum. Easy to access as in central Amsterdam. New entrance being built at the moment but access unaffected. Some steep stairs from ground floor to access the church and did not see any lift. We used the Amsterdam museum card to cover the entry fee as this was one of many that the card covers.

Insightful window into the past. This is a must see in a city full of many wonders.. I'm not religious and this had iffy reviews ..but decided to visit it since I had the museum pass and some time as well. It was simply super ! The well presented museum, excellent and insightful audio guide and the overall sense of calm in this place is worth it ! Amazing to see how faith can drive people to accomplish so much! I got a peek into the house and lives ( and even psyche) of the family inhabiting the house and enjoyed myself thoroughly. It was uplifting and enjoyable. Do go and see... Are unlikely to be disappointed.

Unique and fascinating. Recently renovated this museum has an excellent included audio guide, and fascinating story to tell of life in Amsterdam . We were there @ 10 am when it opened and got in right away. Take your time as there are many little alcoves. Lots of steep narrow stairs but a terrific find in a very busy city.

Fantastic museum. Ons Lieve Heer op Solder (Our Lord in the Attic) is a small but fascinating museum located near the Red Light District in Amsterdam. Currently the museum is going through a restoration process, but this doesn't hamper the experience. There are audio guides available at the museum that provide information in various parts about the history of the house, family, and the Catholic Church. The main part to see in the house is the Catholic Church that was built on the top 3 floors of the canal house. The Church was hidden from the public due to Catholics not being able to worship publicly due to Dutch laws. Besides the Church, the rest of the museum is the former canal house that shows you what it was like to live in the 1600s in Amsterdam. Remember to save your ticket receipt because this can give you a combideal for 3 euros off at a couple other unique museums in Amsterdam: Amsterdam Museum, Cromhouthuizen - Bijbels Museum,Geelvinck Hinlopen Huis or Museum Willet-Holthuysen. I wasn't aware of this at the time and wish I would have known.

Simply beautiful. This was as close as you can come to a time lapse. A very well presented piece of historic architecture and ingenuity. But it also provides a view into the past as it also shows living quarters. Highly recommend paying a visit and taking in the sights.
OK, but not a must see. Interesting to seeing a hidden Catholic church in the middle of Amsterdam. Very unique, but not sure it's worth it unless you have an hour or two extra to spend.
Unique church. Very interesting little church. Easy to miss, had some trouble finding it but persisted and it was well worth it.
Great experience . Great place to visit. Excellently presented with the included audio guide. It was a fascinating insight  into a lost part of Amsterdam life.
Even if you are not religious this is amazing. Even if you are not religious this is amazing, a church built in 17th century in the attics for secret worship. Well worth a visit
Special. Read about it and then go. Special place that gives you the idea of how people used to get a place to pray.Magic atmosphere and very nice place. A good idea of old Amsterdam.

Interesting church to visit. This is a interesting church and 2 houses to visit. The church is unique as its been built into the top floors of three buildings and is interesting in how they used the space. You can get some nice views across the canal and amsterdam rooftops from the top floors. You have a audio guide which gives useful information. You cant take your backpack but there are lockers to leave these at next door where you buy your entry ticket and there is also a toilet available. They are currently making access into the third house which was not open. But beware as there are no signs for this attraction on the building that the church is in and so we walked past it and only found it as there was a ticket attendant standing outside.

Very special quiet place in centre of Amsterdam. Church on a never expected location. Beautifull place in the red light district. Church build in a period where these religious groups were not alowed in Amsterdam

Nice bit of history. Lovely little church with a great story. It's not well marked so you will need to look carefully for it. Pay attention to the chairs with their hinged seats so you have more room to kneel.
Hidden treasure. Fascinating. From the outside it looks just like any other house in the row, but inside.............what a surprise.
Week in Amsterdam. Interesting and neat to see. It is a little costly but if you have the museum card it is free to enter. It takes about 45 minutes to go through. It is a self guided audio tour.

Well hidden. Didn't expect to find this tucked away at the edge of the red-light district.
An enjoyable surprise and well worth a visit.

One of the amazing secrets in Amsterdam. Its a fantastic place! An old church hidden in the city center in a typical narrow house. This place used to be a hidden church for the Catholics when in the past they were not allowed to manifest their faith in public places, due to the Reformation. Their faith was just tolerated. Also the house is beautiful, an opportunity to see one of the oldest and typical homes in Amsterdam.

Very innovative worship center.. Very small church built when Catholics were forbidden to have their own churches. Built inside a canal house on the top three floors. Only downside is that ther are renovating the entrance area which will be nice and much better when finished.
An amazing hidden church!. This was a fantastic find! With a very informative audio guide. Some renovation work was in progress but this did not spoil our visit.

Well worth the effort. It took us a while to find Our Lord in the Attic, no big signs, but well worth the effort. The museum is under renovation, but still a very interesting building to go through. You get a great understanding of the sizes of the canal houses that existed at the time this church was built (and hidden) There is an included audio guide which is vey helpful. There are some narrow winding steps but just taking your time will get you up them. We were really glad we went through this museum.
Fascinating. What an amazing building with an incredible story. Restoration work is in progress so there is some disruption to exhibits but it is definitely worth a visit.

A Must See!!!!. One of the most amazing secrets in Amsterdam!!!
Visit this special Historical place. Hundreds of years of saving peoples lives!!!!

Well worth a visit. There are some steep steps but it is worth the climb up them. It is hard to comment on the effect the building works will have - at the moment the atmosphere in this old building gives a real insight into how it would have been for Catholics after the rearrangement of the 17th C
Hidden gem. Lovely place full of history. It is being renovated and there will be a lot more to see when complete.

Interesting place to visit. This is a very different 'museum' to see. It is worth visiting and worth learning the history about the construction of the building. Just be careful of the narrow winding stairs.

Well worth a visit. This museum offers not only the beautiful hidden top floor church, but also the opportunity to tour one of the oldest homes in Amsterdam. Beautiful floors and an original staircase make the visit interesting for history buffs. It is also an opportunity to learn about the reformation and its impact on Catholics. There are many steep stairs, so be prepared. We felt the admission fee was well worth the visit. This is a unique hidden church and a well preserved piece of Dutch History.

excellent museum. This may not be the first museum in Amsterdam on your list, but it's well worth a visit to see how a church was incorporated into this building - I've seen it & im still not sure how it was done! Full of fascinating books & crNnys with a good audio guide. A really good 60 - 90 mins.
Worth the visit. Really interesting, amazing how much space there is in the building. Staff could be more knowledgeable

A place of worship. This building is actually three in one. Theses building were by a wealthy trader in the 1600's at a time when the Roman Catholic religion was not a permitted religion in Holland. The owner a catholic himself wanted somewhere to worship so he therefore built this church within the upper floors of the three houses where his family and other Catholics could worship. A very difficult place to find but well worth a visit.

A never expected stunning church behind a normal fassade.. The history of the church is typically Dutch: Catholics were not allowed to have visible churches, but behind a normal fassade they were tolerated to do all they wanted to. This policy led to this great, unexpectedly nice church worth a visit.
Should go. This museum is in restoration now. It is a place that you should go to know a little bit more of Amsterdam's history
Amazing. A top 10 thing to do , amazing what's inside this little building , it's a tight squeeze but well worth the steep steps , not overly busy either.

Unexpected Gem close to Centraal Station. Looking for something to easily before leaving on our train we spent all the available time here. Very interesting insights on how people lived in Amsterdam and the tiny Catholic Church built in the upstairs of a wealthy merchant's house. Loved it.
A charming place to vsit. This was a charming place to visit. Learning about the history of Catholicism in Amsterdam and seeing this church in the house where it was built was really unique.

Unique hidden church. This unique hidden church is worth a visit if you are interested in churches and in the area. Beware though that if you are walking there, you are likely to pass by some sites that may make many people blush (sex stores, girls in windows, etc.) since you will be in the Red Light District. We visited with an 11 year old boy and found he kept putting his hands over his eyes.
Secret church. Interesting but still under renovation so when it is finished it will be better. It was good to see inside a canal house even if you are not religious

Fascinating glimpse of life in Amsterdam. I much enjoyed my visit here with my teenage son. It shed light on life inside the canalside houses, as well as the church - which was, of course, fascinating.

Beautiful and historical if somewhat strangely located.. Extremely interesting, especially given its location at the edge of the red light district. The audio tour, included with the admission price, does an excellent job of putting this very unusual church in the context of the time when it was founded.

Quirky but very interesting tiny church.. Quirky but very interesting small church hidden in the upper floors of a house in the Red Light District. Great history. Easy to stop in a do a good self tour in about 20-30 minutes.

Not to be missed! Beautiful and historical.. We visited Our Lord in the Attic and loved it. There is a complimentary audio guide that provides tons of great historical information about the church. The church was recently restored to it's original colors and aesthetic. It's a very beautiful and intimate space. Further renovations are being made and a separate visitor's center adjacent to the church is being built. Unfortunately I can't remember a lot of the interesting historical facts (my memory doesn't hold that type of information), but it was really neat! You won't be disappointed.

Hide and seek. Worthwhile finding. This small museum gives an excellent impression on the ideas about religion in the 17th century after Amsterdam made the turn to Protestantism from being a highly religious Catholic city before that. It is called the Alteratie in Dutch and it happened not gradually but with a shock. The Catholics had to go "underground" but were able to celebrate in hidden churches after that date. Only in the 19th. century Catholicism returned on the foreground of Dutch live again. Something that resulted in some exuberant Catholic churches in Amsterdam like Krijtberg on Singel and Jacob Obrecht church in the South of Amsterdam near Van Gogh. But there are many others that reflect the revival of Catholicism as an accepted religion of the higher classes in Amsterdam. However in the days of this church it was still necessary to hide the church behind the front of a normal looking house

Make time to search this out. A surprising gem and very quiet and special. Hidden in the attics about some typical Amsterdam houses, this chapel is a good example of how different religious sects had to hide during certain periods of Amsterdam's history. It makes a welcome break from the seedy side of Amsterdam that it sits in.

A moving Catholic landmark. Hidden on the top floors of this once mercantile house, patiently erected and lovingly decorated by wealthy Catholics, this secret place of worship welcomed scores of believers and their ministers faithful to Rome for a couple of centuries. I found their creativity and piety quite touching and inspiring. I am very grateful for the attentive care lavished on the conservation and restauration of this institution. A true symbol of faith and courage. I never miss visiting it every time I pass through Amsterdam.
Beautiful. Beautiful hidden gem worth taking a look although for the less mobile some steps may be a little steep .
Interesting place, informative. This is a very nice museum in the heart of Amsterdam. The self-guided tour is excellent, and the staff is very informative.

Personally Lackluster.. While this church had a vaguely interesting backstory, and some pretty artwork, I found it - dull. It is nothing against the church, however as a non-religious person I struggled to find too much interest and the visit was mainly for others in our party.  I definitely wouldn't highly prioritize it unless you do have that religious background/interest, or at the least limit it to a quick pop in and out. It's quite a small location.
Interesting but currently under renovation. If you have a museum pass it is great, but it's a bit sparse from the renovation and so perhaps pass if this will not be your only visit to Amsterdam.

Out of sight, but worth the time. This is a small museum in Amsterdam that has some interesting stories to tell. From a good view of historic building styles to the hidden church in the time when Catholic churches were outlawed, this museum will not disappoint.

Hidden Gem. If you didn't know where to look, you might pass this museum/church right by. It's a short walk after visiting Oude Kerk, but a surprise full of information regarding Catholicism in Amsterdam.

Gorgeous little place. We visited many things in Amsterdam, but this was perhaps the attraction we appreciated the most. The church is gorgeous, even more so as you can't see a hint of it on the outside (well, aside from the museum sign). It was a very informative visit, and very much worth our time.

Fascinating place. I expected a small attic church but this is much more than that. A large space with lots of information on the free audio guide really brought it to life to me. We went on a whim and I am really glad we did!

Amazing hidden gem. Sooooo glad we came here. First time visiting this museum after 5 plus visits to Amsterdam and this has been my fave thing to do without a doubt. Not too hard to find. Just outside the red light district by the canals. 9 euros per person (includes audio guide)The museum takes you inside the house and the old rooms and up into the top of the building where there is the most beautiful hidden church. There is an audio guide which teaches you about how the church was hidden as it was forbidden to attend mass at the time. The church is very calming and very interesting. Worth the money.

Ironic that it is now Hidden in the Red Light District. From the street view of the building you would never suspect or believe that a church of this size is hidden inside the attic. The audio tour is very well done and the renovation work really did not detract from the tour. Well worth a visit and another very different reason to visit the Red Light District.

Hidden church worth a visit. A very beautiful and historically interesting building. It was under renovation and so we did not get the full beauty of the inside worship space. Well worth a visit. Is near red light district.

Interesting To See, Even More Interesting To Think About. Hidden by the Red Light District the Lord of the Attic church speaks volumes about the practical approach to making government work for the people that is Amsterdam and the Netherlands. The church is surprisingly large for an attic, depending on your available time worth seeing.

Work in Progress. This is a truly unique and fascinating attraction and an audio visual presentation shows how the authorities are going to great lengths to protect it from the ever-increasing numbers of visitors using an innovative architectural solution; a praiseworthy initiative.However, beware this is a work very much in progress but don't let the renovations put you off visiting as they did not detract from our enjoyment of this time capsule of a building; from the kitchen and downstairs loo in the basement to the confessional at the top of the building via the incredible church.The original oak staircases are narrow and steep.Useful audio tour added to our enjoyment.

A real gem and an important part of Amsterdam's history.. Places like this give you a real sense of what went on in Amsterdam back in the day, when the practice of Catholicism was officially banned. You gain some understanding of the lengths people went to in order to preserve their faith.

WOW!. We had been to so many churches during our Europe trip that we were not expecting much from this little secret church. When we visited we were impressed. We used the audio guide, which worked perfectly fine. We learned about the history of thr city, the owner of the house, the reasons for the existance of the church, and when we entered the attic area where the church is we were shocked. We were not expecting such a beautiful and large church. That visit was definitely worth it snd we are glad we did it.

Uninspiring. My Girlfriend I went and paid the 18 euro entrance fee. It was nothing amazing. Rather bland. Getting up the stairs was a killer. I can think of better things to spend 18 euros on. However it did tap into my Catholic girlfriend's psyche and the notion of the persecuted Catholic. It worked for her on that level.

So interesting - a must visit. This museum is very interesting though do be aware that it involves a number of very steep sets of stairs so not for those who have mobility issues. Staff were friendly and you get a handheld electronic guide to tell you about all the rooms as you go round - can be programmed in a number of different languages. €6 entrance of free with iAmsterdam card. Took around half an hour/40 minutes though you could spend longer.
One of the best hidden gems. Even for non religious folks, this is a great attraction... to see how Amsterdam's Catholics worshiped in hiding. Plus who doesnt like secret doors and hidden houses....

Hidden History... who knew?. This place was recommended by a friend. I have waled by it now for years. While it is currently undergoing renovations, it is well worth the visit! The history of the hidden churches around the city is quite interesting. The museum offers audio tours.
very nicely done. explanative, well kept, not overly busy and architecturaly interesting, great insight into both living and religion history

Disappointed non-visit. We ran through town to get to this site only to find that they had closed 10 minutes early. I was so disappointed. My parents had been here in April and recommended that we see it. It was hard to find, so we had been searching for a while. It was under construction, so that was part of the problem. They should not close early-ever. It is not fair to the tourist who travel 5000 miles to see it.

A lovely little museum. I am surprised by the few reviews. This is a gem of a house museum. In some ways, it is like the Anne Frank House, but it held a different secret. If you like secret doors and rooms, this is another wonderful place to visit.
Incredible!. Our Airbnb host told us about this and we were very happy we saw it. Amazing the effort that was made and the beautiful church that was concealed. Worth a visit!

Fantastic - do not miss. We only found this place due to trip advisor. The museum is under renovation so it was a little difficult to find. An audio guide is given which full explains all aspects of the house. House was very interesting but the church was fantastic- a definite must visit.

A great find in Amsterdam. Such a quaint museum that really captures so many aspects of real Dutch life in the past. No grandiose exhibitions, but just a simple illustration of both how innovative people were to do what they love and, at the same time, how the Dutch thought about religion and commerce.The scope of the clandestine church is astounding. One wonders how all of this was done in a way that did not attract attention. Well worth a visit.

Outstanding clandestine church. A super awesome clandestine Catholic church in Amsterdam, the biggest I have seen yet. The scope of the construction is astounding. The quality of the rehabilitation and tour are excellent. I thoroughly enjoyed my visit here.

Splendid. Once I found this place I was astounded. So small, yet so impressive. The history and the concept of the church inside the house was incredible. With renovations it is possibly more difficult to find. Worth the visit.

Don't miss it!. Beautiful old Catholic church "hidden" in the attic. See a beautifully restored 17th century house as well. We were fascinated. Don't let the remodeling put you off (the entire front was covered with plastic and scaffolding when we were there)

A very unusual and interesting museum. Not known to a lot of people this is a unique museum dealing with the practice of the Catholic religion while it was banned in the Netherlands in their Golden Period. It is as it was, a church built within a traditional home owned by a wealthy Catholic. Once in there and on the second floor you are in a somewhat small, but complete church with an alter, organ and pews. The middle of two more upper floors has been cutout to provide a view from tiered seats. All is beautifully done. The remaining areas of the house are also on exhibit - a very interesting kitchen and private rooms, etc. This is way more interesting than one might anticipate, and certainly not limited in interest to those of the Catholic faith.

Interesting History. The museum is under some renovation, to connect it to the house next door and make it bigger. The church part of the museum was all open, though, and really interesting. Some of the living quarters were also available for view. I would recommend it for history buffs.
Fab. best place in Amsterdam, well worth a visit, good audio system and not over crowded would visit again next time in Amsterdam

Nice surprise in Amsterdam. Restaurated house from the 17th century with the top level used as a church. Great surprise inside, nothing from the outside could reveal the existence of a former catholic church inside.

Wonderfully eccentric museum. No museum more fully captures the unique flavour of Amstterdam. The idea of building a church in the attic would not occur to anyone but a Dutchman. It flies in the face of received wisdom, yet is an entirely practical solution, marvellously carried out. No one should miss it.

Well Worth Climbing a Few Stairs.  It was well worth the star climb. It is amazing that they could build a beautiful church in such a small space. The alter and frescoes were magnificent. It is hard to imagine that such a small church could hold 150 people. We went in the morning and it was not crowded and thoroughly enjoyed our visit.

Very interesting hidden gem. Found it to be very good Value for money it is both interesting and and well maintianed. You can wonder around at your own pace and take in as much or as little information as you choose.

Under renovation. This museum was very lovely and educational. I felt it was a little pricey(especially because of all the reno) but it was nice that the audio tour was included. It felt very choppy and found it confusing on which way to go. One member of our group was talking about an area the other 3 of us didn't even see.

Interesting church. This church is a bit tricky to locate, but once you do it is an interesting place to visit. It is undergoing renovation right now but it is still open and there is much to see and appreciate.

Hidden church from the days when Catholicism was banned. This niche museum in the Red Light District is not for everyone, but tells a great historical story. A businessman built a church in his attic for Catholic worshipers. The museum is undergoing a renovation and expansion, so not all parts are accessible and we initially could not find it due to the scaffolding. Lots of narrow staircases to climb. Original wallpaper, staircases, and other furnishings from the 17th century still survive. Audio tour guide provided. Inspirational and worth one hour.

Interesting museum with small crowds. As of July 2015, the museum was being refurbished on the outside and connected the adjacent building via an underground tunnel. The new building will serve as an entrance, store, and garbroom. For now, the construction makes the entrance a bit hard to find; don't be afraid to ask for help from the workers.We visited on a Friday, and it was not too busy. The audio tour is free, and very informative (and necessary), because there are few boards with explanations. The church has a rich history, celebrating ingenuity, engineering, and religious dedication.

Wondering what all those hooks at the tops of houses are for?. Not only is this an amazing story about church history and people's determination to worship. But you are able to actuallly see up to the very wheel (still functioning) that hauls things up by use of that hanging rope

Well preserved and an interesting perspective. After visiting the Old Church, my wife and I visited Our Lord in the Attic. Together, these two churches tell a story of the view of religion in Amsterdam, past and present.This residential location is also interesting, in that it is in the middle of what is now the red light district. However, given a historical view, it shows that Amsterdam is constantly evolving and changing to fit the needs and desires of the visitors and residents. What was once taboo (the worship of Jesus Christ in a Catholic Church) is now surrounded by today's taboo. The church is well preserved and the audio tour is very interesting. A very professional and educational experience for anyone.
Interesting Place. So interesting to see this church in the middle of the red light district (who knew?) and to hear the story behind it. Pretty amazing.

Exceptionally deceiving in size. The images used to illustrate 'Our Lord in the attic' do not do the attraction any justice. The building is undergoing renovation currently so some parts are hard to see and other things have been removed but disruption is completely minimal! The tour is self guided and an audio device is provided which is of good quality and easy to use. The history behind these types of churches is explained throughout the tour as well as explanations of why Amsterdam actually banned the practice of the Catholic faith, fantastic attraction which was completely unexpected, staff very courteous and friendly, a must do if you have time in Amsterdam!

Wait until the renovation is over. This is a fascinating place to visit, but it is currently being renovated. That means lots of workmen, plastic sheeting and scaffolding. Once the work is finished the museum will take the same format as Rembrandts house, a modern unit attached to the original house, but at the moment it's all a bit messy. That said, I still think it's worth a visit as you can sit in the hidden church, where the renovation is finished, and marvel at how this space was formed out of the top floors of three houses and kept secret. Buy an I love Amsterdam card to get free admission.

How to hide a church in Amsterdam. An unremarkable entrance to a former residence of a wealthy Catholic, who used the top floors of his home to build a church in 17th century Amsterdam. (Catholics were not allowed public worship). You climb stairs (again) and find yourself in a beautifully adorned gem of a chapel. A listening guide helps to tell the story of the church and identify sacred objects. A nice step back in time.

Very interesting historical building. The museum is going through a major change but they have kept the old church in the attic whilst they complete some extensive building work to create a new multi media centre (or something like that). There is an essential audio guide to use as you go through the building which is very informative but it is the "church" itself which makes the visit. I expected to find a church in the attic but was amazed at what actually is there. Definitely worth an hour of anyone's time when visiting Amsterdam.

A hidden gem in the red light district. A must see, if you are interested in our funny city. Imagine a struggle, which led to independence from the Spanish rulers in 1581. It's the time of the Reformation. In the brand new Dutch Republic, most of the ruling class of aristocrates and city-merchants were Calvinists and they prohibited the practice of the Catholic religion. However, while Calvinism became the dominant faith, many Catholics remained faithful. And there were still rich Catholic merchants like 'Jan Hartman. He built this amazing hidden church in the attic. It is well taken care of. Don't google pictures or read to much just go and be overwhelmed by this gem. Mind you, it is not accessible for people in wheelchairs... Unless you being someone to carry you up steep and small stairs.

A piece of history well worth seeing. A Catholic church hidden away in a merchant's house, from a time when only Protestantism was allowed. It seems the authorities turned a blind eye to these. It's not that easy to find - you'll need to know the Dutch for it, to follow the finger posts to ' Ons' Lieve Heer op Solder '. Well worth the hunt. The entrance fee includes a free audio tour on headsets, providing plenty of background on the history and on individual artefacts. Currently undergoing extensive restoration work and should be even better next year. I expected this to be just a quick look, and out again, but we spent about an hour there, so allow time to enjoy your visit.

It was OK if you like churches. A quirky story which is why we went, but churches don't really do it for me if I am honest. Clever way of hiding a church though. It was being refurbished when we were there so not much around and a lot of building works going on.

Very interesting. Possibly the most interesting church I've ever visited. The visit doesn't take long (I'd say an hour) and the location is easily reachable (city centre). Everything in both the house and the museum is extremely well preserved and offers a genuine overview of what life was like in the 17th century. Very good audio guides as well.

Great small hide church. A must see, if you like to know about the history of the dutch people living in amsterdam.
great preserved old small hidden church on the attic, so locals could preserve there faith during the spanisch and french occupation.
Not so easy to find as it is renovated from the outside at the moment.
Good listening devise for guidance.

Fascinating Story. Definitely, this little jewel is well worth the visit - and visit soon as every year more & more tourists are finding it. so, they're in the middle of buying property across the canal as a visitor's center which will probably change the dynamic a bit in this triple townhouse that a rich 16th century Roman Catholic merchant 'hollowed out' on the top 3 floors to make a real live (secret, in then strictly Calvinist Netherlands) Roman Catholic church. Absolutely amazing!
A must. A small but very interesting museum. A catholic church "hidden" up in the attic of 3 houses - very well preserved place. Good audioguides

Intriguing piece of history. As of May 2015 there's renovation work going on but once you get past it, into the chapel itself the place is a real surprise. I hadn't heard of this place before when we'd visited Amsterdam some years ago so was really keen to see it and we weren't disappointed. It's amazing that something so ingenious came from one man's faith and more amazing that it has survived intact after the people were given freedom to worship and rebuild catholic churches. To get to the chapel is up a narrow town house staircase so unfortunately it's not accessible to everyone but if you like seeing inside old buildings then seeing the unexpected, it's definitely worth a visit

Come back again and again. I find myself revisiting this gem time and time again, it has a great audio tour available in multiple languages. Looks small on the outside, amazes in size inside. Watch out for the steep and narrow staircases (more like ladders). Look out for the discount vouchers in your hotel's tourist information point.

Find it and you will enjoy the experience. Not very far from the Central Station is little difficult to find but fully worth looking for it. When It is amazing how a small chapel has been build inside an Old Amsterdam house. The entrance is free with the Musekaart. It is self guided tour and audio guide will be issued free of charge to all visitors.When we were there work was in progress to link the house with another similar house next to it. Don't leave Amsterdam without visiting this place

Hidden treasure. This is a little church hidden between houses that allowed Catholics a place to worship when Catholicism was made illegal. Definitely worth a visit -- much renovation going on, but the chapel is all done and the history of the houses is very interesting.

Unique experience. This hidden church is truly a gem. If you like history and architecture (as I do) there is nothing else like it. There's something about the houses in Amsterdam where churches can be hidden and families can be hidden (Anne Frank House). See both

Fascinating Insight to Dutch History. In a canal side home near the Red Light District, this Catholic church survives as it did from a time when the practice of Catholicism was "banned" (or more likely tolerated so long as the Catholics had the good sense to practice their religion out of the sight of goodly Protestant neighbors). The museum contains an audio tour, is thoughtfully constructed and wonderfully preserved (never mind the restoration work going on now). Well worth a visit.

Good, despite building works. We visited during June 2015 having read some recommendations. People leaving as we entered also praised the visit. Situated a short walk from the central train station it was worth the 9e (I think that was the admission) entrance fee. On the downside they were, (at the time of our visit) extending into an adjoining property to expand the display but this meant that some artefacts had been withdrawn fron display and there was plastic sheetingand barriers here and there. Don't let that put you off though....there's still plenty to see.

Very interesting part of the city. Our Lord in the Attic Church is in a very interesting part of the city with the Oude Kerk and the Red Light District very close. The church is very interesting and well worth a visit and quite unusual. Currently the fascade is under restoration so it is easy to miss. Also very close by is the Oude Kerk (Old Church) which is one of Amsterdam's best kept secrets with its Medieval painted ceilings that were covered for 500 years. A great way to see the museums of Amsterdan is to buy a Museum Card for Euros 59.00. It doesn't take many entrance fees at Euros 17.00 each to pay for itself and you get to go to up to 20 others for free.
A hidden gem.. A little church tucked away...such a peaceful atmosphere and particularly interesting about how people could be persecuted for their faith.
Hidden church. Nice example of a hidden catholic church, although there are more such hidden catholic churches in Amsterdam which are free, and this one has an entrance fee.

A hidden Gem of Amsterdam!. I visited this museum in October 2014 with family. We found this hidden Church on TripAdvisor while researching places to see in Amsterdam. It is a lovely interior, and quite amazing how they managed to get the organ inside! Lovely story about how the Church came to be founded there. Various lovely, interesting rooms to view but main church is he best part and very well maintained. There is an audio guide if you require one. They are building a new extension, which will add to this already wonderful place. Look forward to viewing it on next trip.Visited October 2014

More 17th century life than other open houses; surprisingly informative and worth a visit. Interested in the history of Amsterdam, we went to the Amsterdam Museum (city history) and two canal houses (van Loon and Geelvinck) and Our Lord in the Attic on the same day. The two canal houses showed a pretty grand side of life--each has a lovely garden and a coach house--but were restored to 19th century furnishings. Each is privately owned and the top floors are used for offices and private apartments for the owners. Geelvinck has the nicest garden and van Loon includes a coach in the coach house and more interior furnishings; van Loon has more rooms open. Our Lord in the Attic showed more about life in the 17th century plus it has the remarkable church in the attic and a very easy and useful system of imparting information in the (included in the admission price) audio tour. There's some kind of discount if you visit all three, but we didn't learn about that until late in the day at our last stop (Lord in the Attic). There's apparently an open garden day earlier in June across the city and if we'd known about that, we might have come a week or so earlier. It was June 20/21 this year and would be worth trying. Our Lord in the Attic has a LOT of up and down narrow stairs, including one original 17th century oak staircase that is short and still quite lovely to see.

quaint and unique. This is a very unusual building; worth the visit for its uniqueness. The decoration, of couse, is not really extravagant, but it is nice nonetheless. There were enough information panels in English for us to get some of the history.

Interesting. fantastic old building. The church in the attic is beautifully restored. The building is presently under restoration so some artefacts have been stored, plus building work is taking place. Even with this it is worth the visit. Cost €9 and took about 40 mins. There is an English audio with that. Recommend

Wonderful museum tucked away in the most unexpected space. This is a must-visit in Amsterdam to get yourself a little slice of history, without it taking up too much of your city-wandering time. The museum is compact as that's the beauty of it's history. I won't ruin the surprises, but it's great to explore the space and to imagine what it would have been like to worship here many years ago. Very well preserved and enjoyable.

Fascinating church and history. This church doesn't really appear on the local tourist guides. I only found out about it through Trip Advisor. It is quite hard to find as there is construction equipment around it and it is not prominently sign posted. You need a big map with the map clearly marked. It is on the same street by a canal as the Ould Kirche - just a little further towards the harbour.Yes there is renovation happening but this is mainly connected to the work on the adjoining house where all the support services are going to be shifted to. The First and second storeys of two houses are the living quarters of the Hartmann family and the priest respectively. However it is the church on the third floor that is the real attraction. It is surprisingly large, beautifully decorated and restored. As well as the striking altar and its surrounds, there is a charming pipe organ at the other end. It has rooms connected with Catholic worship - a sacristy with old vestments and confessional boxes. It also has the sacred vessels used for the celebration of Mass. The audio guide is activated at each point and is really easy to use.

Interesting. This is an interesting site. It just seemed like a regular house but then you get to the attic and there is a small church. I say small but I was actually surprised at how big it was since it was a part of a functioning house.

A quaint little attraction. The major reason for why you should visit this small little cathedral established over the attic in an otherwise unsuspecting house is because of the history associated with it. The attic with the cathedral was reminiscent of a time when practicing faith was nothing less than an act of rebellion. In general it is a plain cathedral but it’s the history that makes it interesting

A unique experience. This was one of the most interesting places ever! A small canal house in Amsterdam, but with an amazing history and a secret church. The audio guide was very informative, and the whole experience was really interesting. it's a must see.

Nearly finished and a great story. In the Red Light district - which isn't as seedy as you think it will be! - is this amazing merchants house with a secret Catholic Church in the attic. It is being restored at present but you can still wander around and see the rooms and the church itself high in the rafters. ReLly recommended, good audio guides and in a fascinating, historic part of Amsterdam.

I expected more.... To be honest, I expected more, having read all those excited reviews. They are under reconstruction currently and unfortunately this may influence your overall impression quite significantly. I would expect them to lower the entrance fee or at least warn you what the exposition is looking like at the moment. However, it’s interesting to see the objects of everyday life and also some rooms- like the secret chamber, kitchen or toilet. And the chapel itself, of course.

Really interesting...better when the renovations are finished. Great to see a typical merchants house from around 400 years ago (various ones scattered around Western Europe of a similar design)but what makes this one stand out is the church in the attic and the clever audio system used to tell you about each room. Very interesting overall but quite extensive renovations going on so make sure you are happy to miss out on a few bits or see the odd workman.

fascinating history. Off the beaten path of typical Amsterdam "must sees." Museum is very well set up with recorded info at multiple sites that one accesses by scanning a card. Very unobtrusive and one can listen while looking around. Also, the info is "tiered," so if you want to hear more details you can click another button. Well worth a visit.

A Definite Must See. In 1558 the Protestant Reformation made it illegal to practice Catholicism. Visit Our Lord in the Attic and see how Catholics worked around this. It's an amazing shrine to persistence, fortitude and faith. Non-Catholics will realize the sense of history and dedication it took this German merchant to acquire two homes behind his and connect the three attics creating a church, with pipe organ that could seat 150. Free audio tour with admission. Not far from the train station.
Interesting church with a great history. Saw this church in the Rick Steves Europe show and wanted to check it out. The self-guided audio tour was perfect and allowed me to go at my own pace.

Wow what a beautiful church. It saw 150 people every Sunday for Mass. So well hidden. It was all good, being restored at present. They will open up many more rooms to the public soon. Has a nice self guided tour, sound equipment with your choice of language available.
Staff very friendly
I usually tire of churches. Unusual peek into Amsterdam history in this restored church in the attic. Well curated audio guide and will be even better when they finish their renovations. Glad I went.
Beautiful hidden church in an old canal house. This is a very nice museum in the red light district. A very charming old church dedicated to Saint Nicholas, patron of the sailors.
An unusual hidden church. Well worth a visit. Shows the strength of character to build a church over three houses in the attics. A lot of steps but not too demanding.

Great piece of hidden history. Very well preserved (and reconstructed in places) building with the perfect amount of detail included in the information. The audio guide is included in the ticket price of 13€ which is unusual for Amsterdam. Only takes about 1 hour to get around and is very educational and interesting.

Short on time, glad we visited here. Excellent history of this church explained via the self-guided tour recordings. Spend as much or little time as you like looking at all the rooms and artifacts. We appreciated the explanation that most of the artifacts were being restored and the invitation to return to see them placed once again in their settings. Even so, this was well-worth the 9 Euro fee.
Hidden gem!. We spotted this by accident, but really enjoyed the lovely story & history associated with this. It is being renovated at present, so you may be disappointed .

Interesting Place, so much History, everyone should enjoy it, If you are Catholic you should GO. If you like churches, GO, if you live architecture, GO, if you like history, GO, if you like the ODD, GO, if you like weird, GO, if you are Catholic, you should GO. But if you are bored and just want to to fill up time, you may not like this venue. We enjoyed the house and spent a lot of time going from room to room, you can also revisit rooms, it was so interesting and at times sad. Its a great place for all people, but if you are Catholic you SHOULD GO.

Under Construction/Renovation, so hard to know where to go next. Be aware that you do need to walk through the red light district to get here... (eyes to the ground, eyes to the ground). There seems to be a lot of construction/renovation going on as of May 2015, this will really make the museum terrific, but for now it was a bit hard to know where to go next, even with the audio tour. We ended up missing part of the exhibit because we didn't know how to get there. When you get upstairs to the sanctuary, you are required to put booties over your shoes, these are a bit clumsy, but help to preserve the area. The audio tour provided a lot of information about what we were seeing, but it would've been more helpful if it had included directions as to where to go next as it was often not obvious and there was no one around to ask. Still, we enjoyed our visit greatly and highly recommend it!

Very interesting and well explained. Take the audio-guide with you (for free) because it's really interesting! I liked the house, the church, how they organized the tour... one of the best and characteristic museum-church in the A'dam centre!

breath taking church - literally in an attic. We understood this church was built in such a time when Christians were persecuted for their faith and worship had to be very discrete. If you look from the outside the building the idea that a church is hidden inside would not strike you at all. As you go inside there just endless bedrooms and so forth then suddenly you come to this tiny church with a wonderfully decorated altar at the back. Small but all elements of catholic worship are present - the roman missal, the crucifix, other religious figures - just as complete and elegant as any major church in Europe! It struck us so hard that the builder went to extreme lengths just to provide a place of worship at times of persecution. It's all for a good price and it's free if you have an iamsterdam card, and its located right at the heart of the infamous red light district so it's not difficult to get there.
A must go. They even lend you a free audio guide, with very interesting facts about the history of the church. A very interesting place indeed. Do give it a go.

Amazing church and restoration!. This unassuming house in the middle of the row has a big surprise inside-a church. It's not small either. Although the house was under construction with big plans still to come, it was worth the stop.

A few post Christmas days. What a delightful place this is to visit. Steeped in history and beautifully maintained. The history of the Catholic Church in Holland was a revelation and in many ways exactly what you would expect from this dignified people. The idea of Catholic worship being forbidden and yet allowed in such a beautiful venue as this, and as long as you were discreet say everything about this nation. You'll enjoy taking the audio tour - do it soon.

Insightful. Our visit here was unplanned and I'm glad we went in, it taught me not only about the history of Amsterdam and the strict policies on religion, but how people got around them to continue worshipping. The tour is pretty easy to follow, the audio guide is very helpful in the understanding of what you see and the preservation of original features and objects is great. Seeing a full church hidden within a house is definitely worth a look!

A must!!!!!. My favourite museum in Amsterdam! Such history and all so tucked away which is, I believe to be, the best part of all! Great price (and even better with a museum card), perfect way to spend a Sunday morning! So central and easy to find!

Wonderful Visit. We very much enjoyed our visit to Our Lord in the Attic - one of several clandestine Catholic Churches in Amsterdam that is now a museum as a living testimony to a period when practicing Catholicism was forbidden in Amsterdam. Be aware that the museum is undergoing a renovation that appears close to completion and which did not interfere with our visit. It's a truly amazing place where Catholics secretly built a church in an attic, and practiced their faith for hundreds of years. Well done!!!

Interesting!. We enjoyed the experience of soaking in the ambiance of the 1600's available in this place, the various rooms which lead to and surround the secret church, understanding more clearly the cultural conflicts of the time, the uniqueness of this building and the continuing history of it all. We hope to return!

An excellent insight into the lack of tolerance. This Church was constructed in the attic of 3 houses, as Catholics were not allowed to worship in public. It is very well kept, though the ticket office is cramped, but that is all soon to change with the addition of another house which will have lots of space for all of the peripheral activities.

Hidden Gem. This was a great find and I highly recommend it. The place is undergoing some enhancements but nothing detracted from the visit. This is an excellent opportunity to view the architecture of a canal home as well as see some history. The visit does not take long and is worth the stop.

Hidden Church filled with history. I had heard about this church on Rick Steve's and we just happened upon it. It is not a huge tourist sight, so it was fantastic to just pay admission and go in. It turned out to be one of the highlights! It was such a moving experience to see a carefully preserved church from the 1700's when Catholicism was illegal. You get these personal recorders that guide you through the whole building, so you feel like you are on a private tour. It was a fantastic experience and I would recommend it as a "must do" on your trip to Amsterdam!

hidden gem in the centre of Amsterdam: go discover it!. This museum 'Our Lord in the Attic' is one of the real (hidden) gems of the city of Amsterdam. Who would dream up a plan to build a (forbidden) church inside a house, costing a big fortune in the money of that time. You will learn all about it with the audio tour that is included in the entrance fee. Be amazed and go see Our Lord in the Attic!

Amazing gem in the red light district. I had never heard of this attraction but my husband had read about it. What a fantastic piece of history. The chapel in the attic was beautiful, I would highly recommend this visit.

An religious curio in Amsterdam. Ons' Lieve Heer op Solder ("Our Lord in the Attic") is a touching religious curio, and as a testament to the endurance of secret faith, sometimes seems to offer a faint echo of that most famous of hiding places in Amsterdam, the Anne Frank House. That, of course, is a must-see; this is perhaps a minor attraction, but one that lingers in the mind with its own poignance. The clandestine Catholic sanctuary was built in secret on the upper floors of a canal house in the late seventeenth century, when the Dutch Reform Church forbade public Catholic worship. There is no great art to be seen here (and the surrounding house museum is of only mild interest), but the "nave" and altar are somehow lovely, and surprising in their length, height and ornateness even when one expects them (there's even a tiny pipe organ at the back, which makes you wonder just how secret the services could have been!). Given that Hitler was a conservative Catholic, there are historical ironies at play here that give the visitor much to ponder; yet the overall effect is one of gentle, enduring piety. The faithful might be interested to learn that masses are still said in the space on Sunday mornings.
A must see. What an experience - amazing the work the people had to do to turn this house into a secret church. A must see if your in Amsterdam

A must see.... We went here on an impromptu Internet search and I'm so glad we did. In fact, it was my favourite thing to do in Amsterdam! It's quiet, you have the time to properly look around and the wonder when you first climb the church steps it amazing! The staff were friendly and it was a great way to spend an hour. It's a must see and makes a refreshing change from the hustle and bustle of other museums and attractions.

Fascinating and impressive history. The building façade was pretty unassuming but the secret it hid for more than a century was a fascinating one. A Catholic church in the attic - who would have guessed? A must visit for history buffs as it unveils Amsterdam's Calvinist past. Until today, the church is open for service every first Sunday of the month. Also, you get to tour the interior of a typical Dutch house on a canal and have a glimpse of the pulley system in the house, in a room behind the organ.
Worth a visit- and no queue!. Interesting church that looks like a house from the outside, quite a few stairs to climb some of which are very steep.
Worth a visit. We were so-so about visiting but I'm glad we did. The church in the loft is extraordinary, an intriguing snapshot of Dutch religious and social history. The audio tour was informative.

Good tour, plenty to see. We are a family with two children under 10 and we were surprised at this tour as we were expecting it to be over fairly quickly! In fact it was the opposite, the audio tour was very good and child friendly. The whole tour took about 30min but there was plenty to see. We were also surprised at the size of the church itself and the restoration has been done very well. The only negative was the restoration and conection to the adjacent building. I am sure the visitors center will make a great addition but it did mean the museum felt a little like a construction site in places.
Excellent. Really good and free audio guide. You always knew which path to take. The rooms and artifacts were well explained. A really good use of an hour.

Worth a quick visit. 7 Euro I believe - gets you access to a self-guided tour complete with sensor-driven audio descriptions. Bring your ear-bud headphones. Still under construction in places but worth a visit.
Fascinating history. Amsterdam is known as the most liberal tolerant city in the world, but at one time Catholic services were prohibited. One family built a church in an attic. It's worth seeing.

Unusual Museum. This was an interesting little museum, a less-known part of Amsterdam's history, when Catholicism had to be practiced in hiding - in this case in an attic! An audio guide takes you through the museum and its story.

Very interesting. I have never seen something like this before. it's amazing what people do for their faith. The audio tour was really good and informative. Even my Husband who doesn't like anything churchy really liked it. We used the IAMSTERDAM card so we got in for free.
New history. This was a fascinating insight into unknown history. Although it is being refurbished there was plenty to see and learn.
insanity. This is in the red light district and yet the manager reprimanded my daughter who was discreetly nursing her 4 month old in the corner of one of the rooms. Horrendous!
Surprise, surprise. Sundays and holidays opens at 1 p.m. Super interesting! Unique site. One has to climb quite a number of stairs.

Fascinating small museum. This is a fascinating look at a Catholic church, literally built into a home during the Reformation. Lots of narrow stairs, but a lovely "home-made" church upstairs. Probably takes less than an hour to go through.

An amazing piece of history. WE booked a guided tour and are so glad we did. She was very knowledgeable and made it come alive in the telling. They are currently adding space next door and need to lessen the traffic through the original houses, so visit soon!
Unbelievable. Amazing to see where there is a will there is a way. A must see. Lovely staff especially the guy at the entrance. And yes, they all speak English.

Superb- well worth a visit . A small church, hidden away is not what you expect to find in the Red Light District, but there it is. Very glad we went to see it. It's absolutely fascinating and has real parallels with Wolverhampton's SS Peter & Paul's Catholic Church. Well worth a visit and an opportunity to take a step back time and experience a little peace.
Historical hidden church. Worth a visit ... especially if history is an interest - but would not put it on my priority list.. Nice exhibits. A short visit will do.

Interesting but Quick Visit. We enjoyed visiting this "hidden" church in the red light district. The included audio tour walks you through each floor of the house with stops in some of the merchant family's living areas before climbing the stairs to the church, which takes up the top three levels. You can climb up into the top galleries and explore the priest's living quarters. You must put on booties that cover your shoes and protect that thatching on the floor which makes navigating the stairs even more interesting. Overall, a nice visit. I probably read too much about it in guidebooks because I didn't learn much about the site that I didn't already know, but I still enjoyed seeing it in person. We listened to every prompt on the audio tour and took many pictures and finished in 50 minutes. Included as part of the Museumkaart.

need more than an hour. there is quite a bit more to see than just the church; we bumped up against closing hour and, while they were nice about saying "take your time," I hesitated to make anyone stay late...so we felt a bit rushed to finish all the stops on the audio tour.

Fascinating Place---Must See. You should definitely add Our Lord in the Attic to your Amsterdam itinerary. Even though it is currently under renovation (group tours cannot be scheduled until after October 1, 2015), individuals can see the bulk of the house. Besides the church upstairs (which is thoroughly described and photographed by others), I was especially intrigued to see the original furnishings, decor, and staircases used by this wealthy family from the 17th century. Lovely art and informative audio guide. Don't miss it.

Fine restoration of an interesting site, well explained. Good audiotour introduces this unique-to-Amsterdam church. The church itself, up quite a few stairs with no disabled access, sits on top of a well preserved burghers home, also well explained. The history and restoration are well explained. Takes about an hour to see. Good to pair with Olde Kirke.
Worth a visit. It was a bit difficult to find but worth the effort. Loved the story and this wonderful piece of history. Lots and lots of stairs. Easy listening guide to carry with you.

Interesting visit. One of two hidden churches we visited (Catholic churches were hidden out of the way in Reformed Amsterdam). The audio tour gave interesting commentary as well as the option of hearing more if you were interested in more in-depth commentary. You must be able to do steps since the church is indeed in the attic. It's located in the heart of the red light district not far from the old church.

A historic gem. An amazing building and story to go with it. It would not be suitable for anyone with a physical disability ie quite a few stairs and quite steep at times. The audiotour was really helpful too.
In the middle of renovation. Interesting area for a church, hidden from view from street. Wait for renovations to be completed to enjoy more fully.

Another must see. Very interesting historical site. Interpretation was easy due to the superb and free audio tour. currently unsuitable for any needing assistance as many steep narrow stairs to climb and descend
In the Red Light District. This was a church that was hidden in plain sight! It was amazing to think it could have been built and people attended without being detected!

Fascinating. This museum/church is very easy to miss, and indeed I would never have heard of it but for the reviews on here. It is an unusual experience, and quite breath-taking to finally come across the 3-storey church at the very top of the building. It was getting busier and busier whilst we were there so I would recommend going at a quieter time. It takes almost an hour to see everything on about 6 floors.
Not to be missed. This is an absolutely unique experience for people of all faiths or none at all. You can use your museum card for entry and it is centrally located

Very cool place. This is an audio tour museum that used to house a hidden church. Great explanation. Whole tour lasted about 30-40 minutes. It is currently under renovation, though. So keep that in mind if you're visiting any time soon!

It was a long time ago, but I still remember it. I didn't go in 2014 (I couldn't choose any earlier date!) it must have been about 2010. I took my dad who is very religious and we both found it really interesting and impressive. It's an unusual little museum and doesn't take long to go round.Worth a visit.
Surprise find. Well worth finding, really nice way to spend a spare few hours. Although only for the more agile due to the number of stairs. The staff were very friendly and polite.
Definitely worth the visit. What an unusual place to have a church. Be prepared to climb many stairs, when you arrive at the top it is well worth the climb to see this unusual setting for a church.

Little gem. Fascinating to see inside one of Amsterdam's many lovely canal side houses. Stepping back in time, one can imagine what it was like to have lived here in its prime. Then I advise you to read Jessie Burton's 'The Minaturist' - a lovely story set in a house like this.

Beautiful little gem. What a gorgeous little Church in a hidden, subtle location. Well worth the visit and entrance fee! Not just for the Church, but also the ability to really get in and explore an authentic canal house in Amsterdam. So many little passage ways and steep stairs. Wonderful experience in Amsterdam.

Finding a treasure full of meaning. This hidden place of worship is amazing. Seeing it brings to life the reality of religious conflict that existed in Europe in past centuries. From the outside, you have no idea that there is actually a three level church hidden in this house overlooking a canal. Walking up the well-worn steps inside was very special. A little hard to find, but worth the effort.

Church. Was interesting to see the set up in the attic for a church and rectory. Seems like quite a feat to build. Well restored and interesting history. Steps can be a problem if you have difficulty walking or taking stairs. They can be narrow and twisting. No problem getting tickets.

A little gem and surprise. We learnt a lot about the religious history of Amsterdanm by going to this little gem When you enter this house you are given shoe covers as they are in the middle of doing restorations. There are lockers to leave you belongings which is useful as there is a lot of stairs climbing ! Not for anyone who has issues with that ! Its four floors of very narrow stairs but worth it if you are not the fainthearted ! its right in the middle of the red light district so a drink afterwards watching the people going about their business in that red light zone !
When God whispers. An attic church from a time when people suffered for crime of believing in their religion. Definitely worth a visit.

Great place to visit. So fortunate to visit this fantastic attraction. It was busy but still very manageable no lines. So interesting and learnt so much more about Amsterdam and the Catholics. Price was competitive, renovations happening but not a big problem.

A hidden gem in the heart of the Red Light District. From the outside an ordinary town house, but inside a hidden church spanning three of the upper floors. Current ticket price is 9 Euro, which was worth every penny. The price includes an electronic audio guide, which worked really well - probably the best guide we have used anywhere. Quiet a few steep stairs to negotiate.There are renovations going on within the building and the next door property, but these have reached a stage that means that they don't interfere with the main museum at all.

If you love history, you'll love this.. Be prepared for very steep, narrow and winding steps. But we'll worth the effort. Regardless of your religious preference, you'll enjoy seeing how these believers never gave up!
Very interesting!!. This was very well set out. The narration on recorders is a great idea and enables you to go at your own pace and without a huge group in a small area. Was very informative.
A different history. This is a very interesting small church, providing an insight into parts of history that may not be on display elsewhere. Good audioguide narration.

A hidden gem. One of Amsterdam's smaller museums, but a fascinating look at the interior of a Golden Age canal house. Renovations are under way but I suspect these will only enhance the experience - highly recommended

Worthwhile visit. Regardless of what else is on offer in this brilliant city, you must find time to visit this important and historical place.The lengths and detail in which the orginators went to is a little short of incredible, and a testament that it is still functioning today. You will be surprised how long you actually stay and marvel at what they actually achieved, learning about this city's culture and history.

A touch of history. Don't miss this charming and informative tidbit of times past. A story of religious commitment at its best located in an ingenious architectural creation. An inspiration on how to overcome oppression

Beautifully restored secret church, excellent audio guide, highlight of Amsterdam. This is a simply wonderful experience. Slap bang in the middle of the red light district and quite hard to find - head up the canal from the Bulldog coffeeshop, but if you have indulged there then the stairs in the museum are quite hard to negotiate - is this gem. It is a beautifully restored Catholic church, built secretly in the attic of a canal side house during a period of history when Catholicism was illegal in the Netherlands.I have no religion, but I love this place and we visit it every time we come to Amsterdam. It restores my faith in the human condition, particularly as you have to pass through the deeply depressing red light district to reach it. Stairs are steep but it's worth it. Very good audio guide and friendly staff.

A gem not to be missed when visiting Amsterdam. A real find tucked away in the Red Light District. The audio system is excellent, the best we have used, and even worked well with a hearing aid/loop system. Although there are extensive works going on at present it did not detract from such an historic building.

Hidden Church. I had read about this hidden church in the guide book, and it was covered by the Museum Card. We took the free recommended audio guide which was most informative. Climbed lots of steep stairs up to the attic, where we put on shoe covers. Amazing that this was hidden across the attics of three houses, and the priest had rooms here too. Well worth a visit. It was undergoing restoration work while we were there.
A hidden church in the eaves of a canal house. Definitely worth a visit, which we did on our last day.It's a house with a fairly substantial RC church hidden in the eaves.

Amazing renovations and insight in to history. After reading about this place in our guide book, we deliberately sought it out. It has limited opening so we went back a couple of times, and so glad we did.Despite an ongoing major renovation happening, the 'museum' gives a wonderful insight in to a time in history both as to how families lived and how religion prescribes places to worship. With construction knowledge, we were both fascinated by the original alterations made to the three properties to enable the church to be built. And the research that was/is happening to renovate this space back to its glory is so interesting. The museum is small - and it currently is not suitable for people with limited mobility as it involves climbing g narrow stairs to the uppermost attic and down again. Additionally, I recommend using the audio guides (provided free) otherwise you will miss so much of the background.
Amazing Church. This is well worth your time. Imagine building a church in your attic that seats 100. Doing it all for the freedom of practicing your religion 200 years ago.

Unique museum in transition. This ancient privat house with the secret catholic church in the attic is certainly a unique place. It has an excellent audio guide with stations all over the house. The only draw back during our visit was that it is in some parts rather worn down, badly painted and with cords hanging from the ceiling. They said they were almost done with the renovation which for several parts does not seem true.
