Considering the modest size of the museum and its state the admission fee of 9 Euros seemed exaggerated. Still a must see for everybody interested in the history of Amsterdam!
Worth a visit. I didn't know much about this place, but I found it very interesting even if parts of it are undergoing restoration right now ( you can still see the main bits though) I recommend it
Awesome. Very good restoration work. Very informative. Learnt so much about the development of Christianity in Netherlands.

A Jewel. Don't miss this fascinating church hidden in the upper storeys of three connected houses. It is now a museum with artifacts, paintings and church silver. It has recently been renovated. Good audio tour facilities.

Catholic church "hidden" in a canal house. This year we had the audio commentary and it was very informative. The history of the Catholic church in Amsterdam is very interesting. Catholics were allowed to practice their religion - but not in public. This is why this beautiful church was built concealed inside a canal house.This museum is undergoing an extensive renovation where they are expanding and connecting to an adjoining canal house.FYI, there are no toilets in this museum, but they have an arrangement with a bar a few doors away and you can get a card at reception and present it at the bar to use their facilities.

A Hidden Gem. Visited on Sunday (19 April), the museum does not open until 1:00pm. Beautifully restored and with excellent electronic hand-held information guide. A new visitor centre/reception area currently being developed so outside not quite so attractive at present. Un-intrusive staff. Well worth an hour to take a look around - and well worth the €9 entrance fee to find this hidden gem.

Fascinating "hidden" church. When Catholicism was outlawed, practitioners held services in secret. This was one of the secret locations. Very interesting. If you are interested in religions, this is cool.

An Unexpected Gem In the Old Part Of Amsterdam. We were in Amsterdam for a weekend and did everything on foot. There is so much to see this way. I had learned of Our Lord In The Attic by googling things to see. I was aprehensive to go to this one as it is in the Red Light district area. But we went anyway and I felt safe the whole way. We got there at closing but the nice young man let us in anyway. This is a piece of history not to be missed while there. It is steep stairs up a few levels to this hidden church. The paintings and huge organ are amazing. This church was accessable by 4 homes. When church let out people quiety exited on four different streets to not be noticed. It was illegal to worship in a Catholic way so they needed to be hidden. This is not one of the main attractions when coming to Amsterdam, but in my opinion one of the best. It is living history.
Worth a visit. An unexpected find. Worth the time to visit. A rare chance to see a period home....and then when you get upstairs!

Interesting place. Set in the heart of the red light district, this was a hidden gem with friendly staff. Watch out for the dangerous slippers that you have to wear to save the woven carpets. My son slipped and fell down stairs!

Hidden History. We used a silver ticket from the Holland Pass for this museum, and we're glad we didn't miss it! Climbing up and down the narrow stairways allows you to connect with the era of Catholics who had to practice their faith in secret. The audio guide added context to each room and its purpose. One of our favorite sights in Amsterdam!

Amazing piece of history. Well preserved piece of social history. No good if you can't do stairs, but worth the effort otherwise. Head phone guide to the church, which was huge when you consider it is in the attic. We saw old vestments and the way the building was used by the occupants.

Wow!. A secret world awaits.
There might a few stairs and twists and turns on the way up, but when you get there ... wow!
From out on the street, or from within the house below, you can not imagine such a large and ornate church exists in the rafters.

breathtaking. What looks to be a normal canal house is something akin to the tardis. Very interesting to experience life as lived in the houses.seeing the furniture and decoration is wonderful,The last steep climb is so worth it, to lift your head and see the transformation of the attics to this remarkable church is just breathtaking. I have been several times and the experience is always the same

Well worth a visit. Fascinating place and continuing to be improved. Beyond expectation of what could/had been achieved. Audio guide in variety of languages. Helpful staff. Unfortunately placed in red light district but don't let that put you off as definitely worth visiting. Be prepared for steep stairs however, each floor has a stopping place with things to see.

Clever people. The church was cleverly built inside a house which looked only like a house! If there had not been a banner outside it it would have been easy to miss. An interesting place which, when the extras are added and the renovations completed, will make a pretty good experience. The audio guide is not very interesting and a little confusing.
Dont miss this. Fascinating museum with a 'surprise' at the top. Well worth a visit. Some of the stairs are a bit steep.

Must see. A must see. Complete church in the top of a nondescript house. Unlike some other museums/attractions not to pricey to get in either. Audio guides in several languages. One interesting point... In order to assist in preservation visitors were asked to wear covers for their shoes when in the church. While we were there, there were three obvious 'officials' from the museum wandering around without covering their shoes. Now if you are serious about conservation you should be setting an example....

Worth seeking out. This is a really unusual tourist attraction. Not many places in the world where you see a church hidden within a house. History of it is amazing and the audio guide explains it all. Def worth finding a spare hour to visit. Also get a real feel of Amsterdam in the 17/18th century.
hidden gem. very informative audio guide, located not far from damrak. fascinating to see some history. took about 30-60 mins to see this attraction but definitely worth a visit.

Definitely worth visiting. A real surprise when you walk inside - the preservation of the church in the attic is brilliant considering how long it has been there. The audio guide was very good in giving a broad overview.
A little gem of a place. Stumbled across this place whilst we were walking round. It's definitely worth a look and shows what people will do in adversity

Interesting and different attraction. I was inquisitive about this attraction, as I had seen it listed here. The included audio tour was useful - it gave the brief details, with the option to hear more. There was some renovation work going on, so not all displays were in use. I would rate the attraction as very good, but not amazing - certainly different and interesting though!
Amazing to see!. Highly recommended as its such an interesting sight to see how 3 neighbours turned their attic into a place of catholic worship when it was forbidden to practice that religion.
A cool surprise. I actually gasped when I saw the church. A very unexpected surprise. Museum and audio guide were well worth the time spent there
Worth a visit. surprising little museum with helpful audio tour free of charge - very interesting to see a 3 storey church in a house@!@

Surprisingly enjoyable. The church in the attic is well hidden behind a small entrance from the canal-side of the building. Once inside you'll find that not many tourists make this very worth while stop. The buildings are under restoration at the moment and the tour will probably only get better once they are completed.Positive: good audio guide, interesting history of Amsterdam, cool architecture, views across the roofs of the city, the actual church that could serve up to 150 clandestine worshippers and has been a museum since 1880s.Negative: can be difficult to find on some maps, used to be called Museum Amstelkring.

Very Interesting Visit. Definitely worth a visit when you're in the city!Nice gift shop and friendly service. The church in the attic was serene, beautiful and the accompanying tour provided in depth information and history

Worth the Visit. Even during this time of renovation/upgrades, this is definitely worth a look. The history of the church came to be and how old and well-preserved everything is tells a really wonderful, interesting story. The audio-guide was very good and helpful. You can go through quickly (20-30 minutes) or take your time with the audio-guide (1 hour).

Fascinating gem of a museum!. Really enjoyed this museum - it has a bit of domestic history, a bit of church design and a story of hidden and clandestine life in Amsterdam. The audio tour was well worth it - good on information but not overwhelming. Worth a visit, even if you have to queue for a short time. We were there about 1 hour.
Absolutely fantastic. Canalhouse with a church on top. You have to visit this fantastic museum. Prepare yourself for loads of stairs. You won't regret it.

An OK visit, half an hour well spent. The visit to Our Lord in the Attic was ok, the church is well restored but I wish there were more details about the way people lived, more items on display, more divisions of the house. Maybe after the ongoing repairs are complete things will be better.

Tolerant Calvinism. It's an odd title perhaps, but one of the things I learned in Amsterdam's reformation history is that unlike other parts of Europe, Dutch Calvinists were not much interested in persecuting non-Calvinists, especially Catholics. As long as you were discreet and practised your faith quietly, the local council was content to let you be. The Church of Our Dear Lord in the Attic is a complete Catholic Church of the 17th century built inside a merchant's house in the centre of Amsterdam. It reflects the piety and religious practice of the counter-reformation and also shows that the tolerance of the Calvinist establishment was fact. It is not a small chapel, but a big church on three levels. There are plans underway to enlarge and expand the museum and education wings. I was impressed by the excellence in presentation, the care to ensure that visitors see a well-preserved piece of Dutch Catholic history and the care and good humour of the staff. I left my ear muffs at the museum - the staff ensured I got them back and graciously ensured someone was in the museum when I called back the next day - 20 minutes before catching the train to Munich! Thank you!

Magical. This is an exceptional piece of history from a less tolerant time. It is a remarkable feat of engineering creating a secret Catholic chapel complete with pews and organ in the roof of a townhouse. It is now a very well run tourist attraction efficiency handling large numbers of visitors and is a treat for church lovers.

Surprised by the little church in the attic. Never imagine in the narrow and normal looking building in amsterdam 'hide' a church in the attic. The church itself is small but the paintings on the wall and at the alter is amazing. The kitchen at the lower floor of the building is original and well preserved. The tiles inside are few hundred years old! The free audio guide provided a lot of information! The downside for this attraction is the very narrow yet dark corridor and stairs which we have to walk cautiously. Also remember to use the shoe cover when entering the attic!

Add to the itinerary!. Really wanted to find this place and i'm glad i did. The history of it is unreal! You feel as though you have stepped back, to a time where freedoms where limited. Good information along the way via a free audio guide. Very interesting and just beautiful, fascinating for anyone regardless of personal beliefs. Something off the beaten track and different for Amsterdam. And only €9. There were renovations going on next door, but this did not impact on my experience.

Foreigner local living in Amsterdam. Even though most of the Dutch people haven't been to this museum, I would certainly reconsider if I would be someone living in the city of Amsterdam, or having some spare time. First of all, this is a very light and quick place to be visited. The visitor goes smoothly throughout all the floors of this old house, in which a secret church was build, so the Catholics of the 17th century (if I am not mistaken), could practice their religion. Moreover, one can have a true idea of how a typical house from the Golden Age looks like from its inside. Enjoy your tour through the "Our Lord in the Attic"!

Fascinating, unexpected. I went the day before my teenage son arrived, thinking he wouldn't be interested. It was so fascinating that we both went the next day, and it was a favorite experience for both of us. Triple history of the merchant's house in the front, the amazing church at the top, and the modest house in the back. Helpful audio guide is included in admission price. I hope it retains its humble charm after renovations are complete.

If you only visit one place it has to be HERE. Decided to visit here after reading reviews on this site.......would say this is a must visit!!!! Think if we had not known about it would just have walked by as lots of building work going on so may have missed it was an attraction. Very friendly staff. The audio tour was great explaining the different rooms and the the history of the church. You are able to walk around at your own pace which makes a difference.

An amazing experience. I don't particularly enjoy visiting churches but this is a truly worthwhile experience and shows how versatile early Amsterdammers were to convert three houses into a secret church.

Great piece of history. Hidden church used by Catholics during the time of the Reformation, found in the heart of the Red Light District!! It was undergoing some restoration work while we were there, but this did not detract from the visit. Audio guide is a must as there is very little information available on the walls. Tight landings and lots of steps may be a hinderance to disabled visitors.

certainly interesting even if not a 5 star attraction. quite interesting and the guided comments were for sure very helpful. gives a good idea of the inside of ancient residences . was happy to see it , but i find many of the reviews too enthusiastic

A different type of church. This museum was undergoing expansion and renovation but luckily the building proper is completed and work now limited to the expansion area (the building next door). Located on the edge of the Red Light District it doesn't take much time out of a short trip but is certainly worth a visit to provide an insight into catholicism in Holland during a time when public worship was banned. Glad I spotted it in 'things to do'.

Make the effort to go. Very impressed with this attraction. It still retains it's special feel and being allowed to wander around at your own pace was wonderful. It is a haven of peace in the Red Light District of Amsterdam. The staff were all very helpful and the musuem has been set up to be user friendly which is more than can be said for some of the other more well known attractions. A must when visiting Amsterdam

More to see than I expected. This was interesting without being that exciting. The audio devices provided are very good. They are the ones that do not require a number to be input and do not require headphones (just point at the symbol local to the exhibit). There was much more to see than I expected. Many other areas of the house in which the chapel was hidden are on show and the chapel itself is much bigger that expected. Well worth a visit without being mind blowing.

A must see gem. This is difficut to find but well worth the effort. A small church created in the top stories of three adjoining houses, at a time when Roman Catholics were persona non grata. The museum tells the story in an interesting audio guide, but the star is the church itself. There are a few stairs to cope with but it is well worth the effory. A treat.

Not just another church. Popped in here to get out of the rain thinking it would be just another church, how wrong I was. Fascinated by the history with the aid of easy to use audio triggered at specific, clearly marked points of reference. Highly recommended. Lots of stairs though!!

What a gem. This is the most interesting church visits we made in Amsterdam because of its history.It was here that Mass was held in secret during the time when being a Catholic was illegal in Holland.You imagine that the place will be tiny, but no. The church spans three storeys at the top of a canal side house on the edge of the red light district.The house has been carefully restored and will soon be complemented by a modern visitors centre next door from which tours will start.Well worth a visit.

Very Interesting. I liked this much more than I thought I would. It was fascinating to learn the lengths they went to to practice their faith when it was outlawed. The audio guide was quite good and explained things well.

very interesting place. to say I wasn't expecting much from this is an under statement HOW WRONG WAS I?this place is a hidden gem upon arriving shortly after 10am we went in and was greeted by a very nice man who gave us our audio tours and some information before letting us go on our own, the audio tour is very useful in here and supplies all information required, when you hear why and how this all came about and the history behind it, you could view a picture in your mind on what it was like,reading other reviews yes there is renovations going on but no it'll not affect seeing anything, took just over an hour going around this well laid out place and to be honest in a few years I might return to see the finished product, it is recommended as a must and dont think as it involves religion its a no no give it a try

Small but worth it. After our second trip to Amsterdam I thought I had seen all the major history it had to offer. This place was a unique little gem that gave a great perspective on the clandestine religious lives led in fear and secrecy and was a wonderful testament to the human spirit. Also what an organ!

A Rare Museum. When artifacts of history and real life become one, a unique experience is to be had. This tiny row house unfolds into both an architectural wonder and a response to religious persecution in the Netherlands. What is most touching, and I say this as a non-Christian, is the lengths and efforts people will go to in order to pray as they must. The church itself is beautiful, as are several small spaces devoted to religious life, including the room the priest would prepare in and a small chapel devoted to Mary. Also striking are the living spaces for both the family of the merchant and the priest, illustrating what home life was in those days.The audio tour was great, included in the price of admission, and the staff there were some of the most welcoming we had encountered and we had encountered some pretty nice people. As other reviews stated, this is truly a gem of a museum. For me it was more. It was a moment of reflection and respect for what devotion will create.

Unique piece of history. This odd museum is interesting for history buffs who can see how Catholics in society adapted after the Reformation and the choice of the Netherlands for Protestantism. It's a stunning and lovely church that covers the top of three houses in Central Amsterdam. The audio tour which is included in the admission price was well done and interesting. It takes a bit over an hour to make it through all of the rooms and information.

plenty to see and learn. This is an interesting little place and unlike most Amsterdam museums, your audio guide is included in the price. It has been well renovated/ preserved so there is actually a lot to see in a small space, and there is also a great view from the window. I left feeling I had learned a bit more about Amsterdams place in the religious tensions following the reformation, as well as seeing how ordinary family rooms would be at that time.

Worth taking a look. We stumbled across this gem of a place and were very glad we ventured inside. It was a fascinating place to visit, with the audio guide explaining each area of the tour. Certainly worth taking a look if you're in the area!

Hidden church, hidden gem. The view from the front windows upstairs shows the beauty of the oldest part of Amsterdam. I hadn't been here for 5-6 years and found many new additions to the tour. Excellent explanations at all steps.

hidden treasure. It is a wonderfully ingenious hidden church and a very interesting piece of history. The whole experience was intriguing and educational, while keeping your imagination excited by what had to be done by these people to practice their religion in a place and time that it was illegal. It is an example of what one brave and generous man could do.

A bit like the Tardis. A fascinating place to visit. Much more to see inside than you would think from the outside. Some steep and narrow staircases to negotiate as you make your way up to the church in the attic.The audio guide is good and tells the story well.

Find this gem of a place. This "secret" church in the attic of a private house is fascinating. Spend your 9euros to see it now before they complete their plans to create a formal visitor centre when they could just spoil this unique attraction.

Unique Museum. Liked the actual tour of the small church hidden behind the building. It had a pretty good audio tour, but a little confusing on the pattern to walk. This was a very unique place, that gave a real view of the change in religious freedoms in the Netherlands, and insight into its practical nature.

A real old historic house with a church on the upper floor. You can perfectly see how the people lived in those old days (sleeping rooms, kitchen) and the church is very much worth to see. Also look out of the window; nice view on the canal. (They are building a new part across the small alley and they found some very old stuff, which they expose)

"A hidden Gem". You could easily walk past this unassuming house which has a hidden gem within its attic space. A charming unusual place of worship. The entrance charge includes a hand held monitor that provides enough information to understand and appreciate its history. Well worth a visit.
Little Gem. Lovely building with great atmosphere. Small modest beautifully restored rooms with surprising historic Catholic place of worship hidden in a house, worth going to with Iamsterdam card.

Surprising in all sorts of ways. Surprising that there should be a (large) church in an attic. A surprising history. Surprising that it didn't collapse in the first place. Surprising that it has survived. Surprising that it should be so fascinating, even to a card-carrying atheist like myself.
Highly recommended.

What a surprise - in a good way. We have been to Amsterdam several times but never thought to visit this fascinating building. The story behind its existence is fascinating. The free audio guide is a must! The resilience of communities, like this, under cultural and religious pressure should be celebrated.

Very special place of worship. After living in Amsterdam for 8 years, I finally visited the Our Lord in the Attic church/museum. A very charming church hidden in the attic of an Amsterdam canal house. The audio tour was very informative and walking around this 17th century building really takes you back to a very different time. Allocate an hour and a half so you can soak in the special peaceful vibe of the church. Worth visiting even if renovation is ongoing.

A lovely surprise. This was a lovely place to see and a great surprise to my friends. I had seen reviews on tripadvisor and had planned to visit on our recent trip. We were delighted to have seen this beautiful place. It really is worth a visit. A hand held monitor for you to hear the information about each room as you toured the attic was a great idea as you could visit each room at your leisure.A must see in Amsterdam.

If you like something a bit different, this is for you.. If you like architecture, a good story and something a bit different this place is for you. It was really impressive inside and once in the attic it's unbelievable. You work your way up through the old house winding your way up and down the original stairs. You get a audio device to tell the story which is well worth it.My advise for anyone new to Amsterdam is get a map check the location of the museum and mark it on as it's not the easiest to find. However with the map really easy.
Building development not finished yet. It is an odd concept - a church organ in an attic. Worth an hour of your time for sheer novelty value

Renovations underway. Fascinating place; we visited about one hour before closing time and there were only a handful of people there. Besides the "secret" church there are other rooms showing 17th century living. Some bits are not open at the moment due to major building works to improve visitor facilities.

A one-off museum and memorable visit. This is a memorable museum, currently being renovated and expanded.It is so interesting to understand the context for the chapel, contained in the attic of this canal house.There is an interesting audio tour and the house has recently been restored. We were lucky enough (I would not usually enjoy being there with a student group) to hear secondary school students making presentations about the chapel for an assignment - it provided interesting background for us. There is quite a good little shop, too.However, construction is underway, and there will be a passage to connect it to another house, on the other side of the adjacent alley. The 2nd house will contain the office and shop, plus explanatory exhibits. So, once the work is finished, the current building space will just be for visitors to see the restored canal house and the chapel within.This was a museum like none I've seen - maybe the entrance price was a bit steep for what's currently on offer, plus a few things were off-limits due to renovation work. But ultimately I didn't begrudge it and I'm glad we visited.It's on the edge of the red light district and quite near the central station - so fairly easy to find.

Ok if you're in the area with a museum card. I don't know that I'd pay to go in but it's free with the museum card. If you're in the neighborhood it's worth a quick peek. I wouldn't trek too far out of my way for it though. Free audio tour is nice for the explanations. It's kind of interesting.

Not just for the religious. This bijou museum is an amazing example of a hidden church touched away inside a series of neighbouring canal-side houses. I recommend the audio guide and they work on the principle of pointing them close to an information point, so you can discover the history of the place at your own pace. €9 is a reasonable entry fee and they are currently looking at refurbishing a nearby property which will have a visitors centre etc, so it will be interesting to go back when this is complete. All in all, a little gem, hidden away in the Red Light district.
Beautiful. Although we had read about this before we went, it was amazing to actually see for ourselves the church hidden away inside an ordinary building. Showed the power of people's beliefs.

A real surprise. This should be on anyone's must-do list when visiting Amsterdam. I was expecting a small covert church behind a secret door, but this is a full sized church in the roof space of the three houses below. The tour is self-guided with an audio device giving commentary at key points. Highly recommended.

A hidden gem of a museum to take in!. Not as touristy as the grander museums in Amsterdam, but full of history and beauty. In fact, many locals were even unaware of its presence.Well narrated through a listening device that you use at your own pace (many different languages available). If you enjoy history and learning this is a terrific stop to make. Plan on an hour or so. They are currently renovating and expanding but it did not take away from the overall experience. Note that there are a few staircases that are narrow and steep (as is the case in all of Amsterdam!). If you are not comfortable with navigating those kind of stairs then you might want to pass.

An extraordinary experience. This is a fascinating museum with a hidden church built into the attic of three houses - so much more than you expect from the description - well worth a visit and it does not take very long.
FASCINATING. So interesting. Keep you receipt to get 3€ off various other museums in Amsterdam. This museum is a wonderful example of seeing a Canal House ,as is the Willet Holthuizen house

So Glad I Stumbled Upon This. I was just walking through the red light district and saw the sign for Our Lord in the Attic. I wasn't looking for it, but I'm glad I found it. It's a little piece of history they have preserved. It's a self guided audio tour. There used to be many churches like this one, but most are gone now. They existed back when the catholics weren't able to practice in public. Very interesting museum, i believe it was only 15 euros and maybe took an hour.

Something really different and special. Most people who come to Amsterdam visit the Anne Frank House, Rijksmuseum and the Van Gogh museum, but they should add The Scheepvaart (Maritime) Museum and this one, Our Lord In the Attic (Onze Lieve Heer Op Solder). It's in the Red Light District, which is actually one of the older parts of town and has some very nice architecture (if you can look past all the sex shops). This museum is a double depth canal house owned by a wealthy Catholic in a time when Catholicism was banned in the city. But the burgomasters (the men who ran the city) would turn a blind eye if you practiced discreetly. So this wealthy Catholic built a complete Catholic church on the top floor of his house! Pretty neat indeed!

Simple, but enjoyable. Our entire family enjoyed Our Lord in the Attic. You had a real feeling of stepping back in time. It is a small museum and won't take a lot of time. It is a self-guided tour, so you can take as much time as you want. I would highly recommend it. The people working there were very kind and offered a small cookie at the end, which was a sweet treat.

Our Lord in the Attic. Having been to Amsterdam a few times this was a new 'sightseeing' experience - a Catholic Church hidden in a street house attic. Payment on entry also gives you a electronic tour guide. You press it against the various posts around the house to hear a wealth of information. My favourite part of the trip? Wearing shoe covers as we wandered around the top floors! Interesting and it takes a leisurely 45mins.

nothing special, a little pricey. It was ok, I know there a lot nicer museums/attractions in the area. I think Catholics can appreciate it (I am Catholic and it didnt really blow me away). If you are in the area, with some time to kill, check it out. If not, you wont have missed much. I must say the gentleman at the front desk was very friendly and assisted my wife and I with finding a Catholic church to recieve our ashes for Ash Wednesday.

Charming. An unusual attraction but a most fascinating one. This secret Catholic church hidden away behind an ordinary-looking house is a real delight to explore with the excellent audio tour as your guide. The history behind why the church was built is equally as interesting as the church itself, which is quite peaceful to sit in and admire.
Amazing. I never imagined for one minute that I was about to walk into a hidden attic church. The history in this building was awesome. Again learnt a lot of things about religion and history.

Learned something new!. A wonderful bit of history and an unexpected gem of a museum! You wouldn't think to look at the building from outside that there is a church hidden on the upper floors. There are quite a few steep stairs, so it will be difficult for those with mobility issues. Worth the visit!!

Unusual, worth a visit!. This is a most unusual place, and we were so impressed that this wealthy merchant felt so strongly about his faith that he bought three canal side houses and created a full church in the attic, to be able to attend Mass at a time when the Dutch monarchy had seized all the Catholic Churches and banned the religion. The audio guides are great, and the tour also gives insight into life during those times, and the life of the merchant himself. Amazing building feat, especially during those times!

What Christians did to Christians. This place is a fascinating reminder of the Protestant vs Catholic struggle not only in Amsterdam, but in most of North-West Europe from the late 16th century onward. Here Catholics continued to worship "incognito" after the Reformation. If you find this interesting, don't miss the nearby and equally fascinating Oude Kerk, 800 years old and now incongruously in the centre of the red-light district. Here you can learn how a Catholic church was "inversed" to conform with Calvinistic views of how the interior of a church should be.

Not to be missed!. This was just an amazing surprise! An unassuming town house in the middle of the Red Light District takes you on a journey back in time. By the time you reach the fifth floor you cannot believe what you see!! A real treat.

Interesting use of a few Canal Houses. What a strange church. I loved it all but kept thinking how weird the whole time. Well worth the time and nominal fee to visit. Staff were very nice. I must have walked by it a number of times even thought the location was easy enough to find.
Interesting. Really good - totally different experience, good audio tour, doesn't take long, steep stairs, easy to find.

OMG. We were overwhelmed by this experience, for such a unassuming place, it was magnificent. The audio guide highlighting everything worked very well. This is definitely something not miss, it's very special.

Neat setting. enjoyed going through this home and the attic church. really allowed us to see how the Catholics had to go underground during the persecution. this was included in the I Amsterdam booklet that we bought, but I would have gone here anyway since a friend had also told me how much they liked it. has a functional pulley system in the attic, too, so you can see how that worked close-up, too.

Amsterdam's Hidden Gem. We didn't think we'd have time to visit this museum so had crossed it off our list, but just happened to stumble across it a few hours before our flight home and I'm so glad we did! Although we got in free with our museum cards, it was well worth the price (only €6). The church itself is such an odd concept (a hidden Catholic church across three attics to avoid Protestant persecution) and very well preserved - although it was undergoing construction work to properly connect the three houses, which was a bit loud and irritating, but couldn't have really been helped. The audio guides are free and provided just the right amount of information and then gave you the option to hear more if you wanted. It is very tucked away (which I suppose was the point when it was built) so is easy to miss but it is absolutely worth it if you're a cultural traveller!

a unique insight into an earlier era. I enjoyed walking through history at this very special church/museum. The audio guide is the best I have seen, and is included in the price. The atmosphere it was makes this so special. Lovingly preserved, you can feel the 200 year history of this underground (actually far above ground) church. Truly unique among all the monuments of Amsterdam.

Pleasantly surprised. Quite a good museum if you are interested in this sort of thing (as my boyfriend is). We only went as it was free on the iamsterdam card, otherwise it is €9 which I wouldn't of paid. A good note is that the give you a free audio tour to take around the museum with you which is very informative!
Worth the time!. We stopped in here while walking around Amsterdam. We had the Museumkart and it was included. Very thought provoking. Audio tour was great too!
Take the audio guide and enjoy. Worth of even short visit. Interesting because of the architecture and structure of the whole house.

Great stop!. Amazing place. please stop here and experience what people went through in order to worship the 1600s. You will be amazed at what is hidden in this unassuming home in the oldest part of Amsterdam.A must to really learn more about the history of the city.

Hidden gem in Amsrerdam. I've been to Amsterdam several times so decided to see some lesser known attractions. The tour includes a great audio guide and climbing up narrow staircases. The cathedral was built when the Catholics were hiding after the Alteration. The three story church was built on the third, fourth, and fifth floors of two adjacent buildings. I highly recommend this tour - allow about an hour to 1 to 1 1/2 hours.
Fascinating. This was a hidden gem just behind our hotel. A lovely little museum with a fascinating back story - just right for a visit of about 1 hour.

Well preserved little hidden church. Audio guide was free - great! Love how it's been carefully restored, preserving its heritage and kept its charm through the years. Great little hidden gem in Amsterdam!

Unusual place to visit. I came here on museumnacht. I think this is a nice place to visit that's different from the usual places people go in Amsterdam. Sure it's a church, but a church with a big difference. Go check it out if you are in the area.

Interesting. If you are interested enough to visit, the story - via the free audio guide - will not disappoint. lots of steps.
Building works will eventually creat an annex next door.

Incredible and Fascinating Experience!. Wow. This was a randomly selected museum, and it paid off big time. It was an incredible exploration of living in the time period, and the history of the time was fascinating. The audio guide that came with the entrance was really informative, and an enjoyable way to experience the house. I really appreciated the attention to detail, and was particularly fascinated by the woven rug, which was painstakingly recreated in the traditional method. Highly, highly recommend a visit, the experience goes far beyond offering history about the Secret Church

What an excellent attraction. This visit gives an insight in the history of the Reformation. From the outside it looks like an ordinary 'grachtenhuis', but the inside has been transformed into a church. It is a real gem in Old Amsterdam.
Good to see. Did not go up to the attic as the opening hours were over. Only managed to take photos from the outside and good to know such a worship place exists in the attic.

Hidden gem - nothing like it!. This is absolutely worth a stop during your time in Amsterdam. From the outside it looks like an ordinary building, blending in with everything in the area. Once you step inside and learn the rich history behind the church, however, you are quickly impressed and in awe. Won't spill too many details, but you would be hard pressed to find something like this in other parts of the world, particularly because it's so well preserved and authentic (most everything is original dating back to the 1600s). So stop by and check it out!

Unexpected view. Not expected and very well done with the easy tour, which you will get when you enter the museum. It provides you a wonderful visit and insight into history and religion of Amsterdam from mid 1700 till almost 1900. We were positively surprised and recommend it to visitors, also when you live in the city itself!

Excellent Attraction. This is an absolute gem. There is extensive refurb going on currently which might detract a little but we felt that they were trying to minimise the impact. The workmanship and dedication to build such a place of worship in adverse conditions was remarkable. Visors are left with very favourable impressions.
A must see. an amazing church completely hidden from the outside world, A must see. plenty of items to look at however there are a lot of steep stairways in there so beware.

Great antidote to the red light and coffee shops!. A bit of hidden culture and history well worth seeing. A compelling story and a great audio guide. Some tight corners and steep steps so not for the feint hearted but not too bad. Lots to see from the church itself and the associated house. Protective coverings are necessary for your shoes in one place but they fit over so make sure you get ones large enough. I think the cost was under 10 euros but it's well worth a visit and when we went it wasn't crowded (Wednesday afternoon).

Special .. Unique .. Beautiful. One of the best attractions in the city with an excellent & informative audio guide. This is a must whether you were religious or not. You will be impressed by the spirit of this place. In 1661 the wealthy merchant Jan Hartman (1619-1668) bought a prestigious property on Oudezijds Voorburgwal; comprises a house on the canal and two rear houses, with the third floor of the front house forming a single extended attic. On the first floor he added a lavish reception room to show off his status and receive guests. This salon is among the best preserved living rooms of the Dutch Golden Age, a copy of which can be seen in Japan. In Protestant Amsterdam Catholics were prevented from openly practising their religion. Within years of the Alteration (the transfer of power in Amsterdam to Protestants in 1578) an official prohibition on the celebration of the Catholic mass was issued. Hartman therefore decided to convert the top three floors of his house into a secret Catholic church. For over two hundred years Hartman's attic served as a parish church for Catholics in the city centre. Of course the Protestant authorities knew about the hidden church, but they turned a blind eye. When the large St Nicolas's church opposite Central Station was dedicated in 1887, Our Lord in the Attic was superseded as the local parish church. In that same year a group of Catholics in Amsterdam bought the property on the corner of Oudezijds Voorburgwal and Heintje Hoekssteeg, thus saving it from demolition. A year later, on 28 April 1888, Our Lord in the Attic was opened to the public on weekdays. After the Rijksmuseum it is the city's oldest museum.The combideal gives you a € 3,- discount on the adult entrance fee at the following museums: Amsterdam Museum, Cromhouthuizen - Bijbels Museum, Geelvinck Hinlopen Huis or Museum Willet-Holthuysen. My advice is to visit (Museum Willet-Holthuysen) in order to fully appreciate the typical 17th & 18th century canal houses of Amsterdam.

A hidden gem for history buffs and others. Our Lord in the Attic - A Catholic church which was built inside a private residence during Reformation time so that Catholics could attend church in secrecy. The museum gives you a lovely opportunity to see an Amsterdam house on the inside and an idea how people lived back then but you also marvel at the feat of having a church inside a house complete with organ, murals and pews! Also nice to see an attraction in Amsterdam which isn't completely overrun with tourist (or perhaps we had luck with our timing).Note: Not recommended for those with mobility issues as there are narrow stairs.

Want to return once the current works are completed.. I'd been recommended to visit and wasn't disappointed - interesting building although not too easy to find. They are currently turning the building next door into a visitor centre and it would be good to return once this is completed to see how they've made more of this historic place.

Time your visit. Worth visiting for the grandeur and beautiful interior but as this is a public building and hosts weddings and seminars, etc. it is not always available for viewing. We got lucky and arrived during a tea break in a seminar so got 5 mins to gawk!
Must visit very interesting.. This was a very unique building to go through and look at. The history of the place was so interesting to learn.

One of my favorite parts of our trip. So many great reasons to go to Our Lord in the Attic. This is a real treasure in Amsterdam and I highly recommend a visit. There is a great audio tour which I always enjoy. The church is beautiful and they do a great job explaining to you how it was used. The tour also takes you through the house and discusses the everyday living areas and how they would have been used. This is a great way to see how the narrow homes in Amsterdam look on the inside from a layout perspective. Definitely put this one on your list!There are very narrow steps so be prepared as it is not crowded you have plenty of time to take them slowly.

fabulous under stated museum. we had the place to ourselves which was lovely, the house and church are a fascinating insight into Amsterdam's past. I hope when they've completed the adjoing house that the atmosphere will still be the same,would love to come back when it's finished. Well worth the visit and was one of our highlights.
a great find. Took some time to find this but a superb museum with audio guide. Chapel was well preserved and great view across rooftops

Well run, unique church.. Using an audio guide which is included in the price you get to walk around the whole house/church learning things in each room.Although there were a lot of people there it didn't seem too busy as there are a lot of rooms for people to go off into and explore. The church itself is very unique due to it's setting and was very interesting listening to why it was built.Worth a visit!
Very special museum. A very special museum in an old church. Never have seen something like this before. It is a bit hard to find though.

Very Interesting. This is a 17th Century House Museum that offers a glimpse into a restored Dutch heritage home as well as a preserved Catholic church hidden at the top of the house. The interior is beautifully restored with period furniture and other artifacts and the chapel at the top of the house has also been nicely preserved. It is difficult to believe that a church could be hidden from the authorities and in fact they were aware of it but turned a blind eye.

Awesome visit, highly recommended.. Seen from the street no way you would tell that there is a church inside this house. Once inside first there is the regular house, very nice, then on the upper floors there is the church. Brilliant! Loved it! Easy to imagine how it was back then. What they should do is give classical music concerts there during the night, that would be awesome!

Great insight into the past of Amsterdam . This was recommended to us by a friend of a friend and we weren't really sure what to expect as neither my husband or I are religious, but we found the experience really interesting.Hidden in a house very close to the Red Light District is a church built at a time when Catholicism was banned.The audio tour provided in the entrance fee is brilliant and let's you walk around at your own pace. I noticed they also do this in a number of languages which is very good. We spent over an hour walking around the floors of the three houses that were converted into the hidden church. It gave us a real insight into how it would have been back when it was built.As I mentioned before I'm not religious but I found it a very interesting attraction.

Very impressed !!!!!. If your interested in history, and how things we come to expect as normally accepted in today's society were punishable in olden days, this place will blow your mind!!!!The fact that someone 350 years ago decided to build a full Catholic Church in his house and hide it from the authorities is worth a look - it truly is hidden away and not what you would expect to find in the red light district..... I was personally amazed at what was achieved and the Audio tour is excellent - fantastic little place and well worth a visit!!!
Interesting and just the right length of audio tour.. A bizarre and idiosyncratic museum with good views of the city and a well presented window into its past.

A fascinating glimpse of a Golden Age house - and a church as well. This is a very special place, a 17th-century wealthy Amsterdam catholic's house in which a catholic church had been constructed in the upper floors at a time of toleration that nonetheless forbad public displays of catholic worship. It was fascinating to explore, helped by an excellent audio guide (something we don't normally use but which was indispensible here). It made a fascinating hour and reaching the church at the tope, and exploring it and the priest's dwelling, was a very special experience. There is major restoration work going on, and a new entrance under construction. I don't know how much that interfered with the visit, and I hope that it doesn't become too slick and busy, but even with the works going on it was a marvellous place to visit.
Great visit. Informative and pretty little place. A good short visit in the red light district that is otherwise very seedy!
Don't read about this, go and be surprised!. I loved this small museum. The wooden stairs are amazing, so is the rest. My advise, do not check the museum on the internet, just go and be surprised.

A hidden gem in the heart of the 'hot' district . Tucked away up high in the attic of a 17th century house, this church museum is worth a visit as it offers a glimpse of life for Catholics when Catholicism was forbidden.

Interesting. The audio tour was helpful at this site, and it wasn't too crowded in the mid-afternoon. There is a lovely little Thai restaurant to the right when you exit the museum. We returned there for dinner one evening and it was delicious!

Don't pass up an opportunity to visit!. A hidden gem of a place to visit. Dating back several hundred years, this hidden Catholic church is definitely worth a visit, and conveniently located a short walk from Central Station/Dam Square.

Fascinating - well worth a visit. This is genuinely fascinating - you just wouldn't have thought there could be something so amazing behind a normal house facade. The only downside is that all the museums are quite expensive - coming from London where the museums are free, the constant payment of 9-15 Euros started to grate a bit!

Worth a visit.. We spent a little over an hour checking this out. I real liked the history of it. It was worthwhile to stop by. They have included audioguides. Personally, I'd rather have placards to read, but they were fine.

Interesting tiny church. Most churches on the tourist list are huge cathedrals, so it was interesting to see the opposite: a pretty tiny church. You get to go all around the church, through the secret entrance and up to the sanctuary, around the galleries, and back down through other rooms of the house. It's kind of a neat comparison with the Anne Frank House--two examples of people making do as best they can in hiding. You use many of the original staircases, which are small and worn, so this is not a suitable place for people with limited mobility.

Heavens above, this is interesting!. What an insight into the religious history of Amsterdam. A truly fascinating experience, highly recommended if you have any interest in social history. A Dutch Tardis!

Only if you're desperate. This little hidden church at the top of a little Amsterdam house is cute but the 5 minute visit didn't really add anything to our trip. I thought it would be better with all the favorable reviews but found it rather a waste of time. Little sanctuary and maybe a dozen pews... that's not much to see. Okay, that it was hidden away gives it some intrigue but don't go expecting much!
What a nice surprise!. If you're Catholic, this is a must-see! It really affirms your faith in Catholics who went to great lengths to have Mass when they were shunned to do so.

Return visit. Wanted to see the church after the renovations and was quite impressed,they now have a very good audio tour which is a great improvement and the next phase of work is under way to link to next door and extend the experience. Well worth a visit.

Well worth a visit. Certainly my favorite church in Amsterdam and one of my all time favorites - if simply for the element of surprise. Built when it was illegal to publicly worship as Catholics, this "hidden church" is a testament to people's beliefs. It's lovely, even by "hidden" standards - and well worth a visit. Give yourself at least an hour for a bare-bones visit, two if you want to take your time. There is going to be a new visitor center there soon that you will really enjoy and will enhance the learning experience even more. The various guides are also really helpful. Talk to them; they're bored and would love to chat with you :-)

Fascinating. It's remarkable that the people managed to construct this church in a house without many people discovering it! Fascinating place with an astonishing history.
Definitely worth a visit whenever you're in Amsterdam. We used our museum cards when we were here, so got in for free.

Well Worth a Visit. During the Reformation, the practice of Catholicism had to be done in secret, and that was the purpose of this facility, to allow Catholics to practice their religion. There are lots of rooms to visit, and some of the decorations are interesting. The stairs are narrow, shallow, and winding, which is probably what you would find in any old house in Amsterdam. Some of the rooms have little box beds, beds built into the wall. I think I would have liked to sleep in them. Admission to this attraction is free with an iAmsterdam pass, so if you're going to be riding the tram very much and plan to tour museums, you really should get one. There are recordings to listen to, and these are very good.

Great building. I get bored very easily with museum type places but it's fairly small and interesting, kept me entertained for half an hour anyway. My boyfriend particularly liked it as he is into buildings and construction. Got a spare half hour, go and have a look around.
Must see. Very professionally prepared for visitors and fascinating! Be ready to climb stairs as this is an authentic attraction.

Major surprise in Amsterdam. Tucked away near the Red Light District this church is incredible. From the outside an ordinary dwelling Inside on the top two floors spread over three house is the most amazing hidden church for Catholics at the time they were banned from meeting. Similar to the situation in England in Cromwell's time.Beautifully restored in original colour this should be visited even if on a short visit to the City

Great Stop. Really enjoyed this stop. I had not heard of it before we got to Amsterdam, very glad we walked over there to see it. There was quite a bit more to see than I had expected (I thought just a single room) but there are a number of floors and interesting story. We did the Anne Frank house then this and still had plenty of time for shopping and canal tour.

Anne Frank was not the only person with a hidden secret in Amsterdam!. This museum further shows the unique, quirky, and fascinating history of the Dutch. The Dutch today are famously known for their liberal attitudes on alternative culture, prostitution, soft drugs (marijuana and herbal drugs), and euthanasia. However, the history of this counter culture is only about 50 years old. Before this there was WWII, and before that (150 odd years ago) Catholicism was actually banned in Holland. The Dutch have a history of the terror of what oppression does and how intolerance never leads to good in society. This museum highlights how even though oppressed people still ere willing to risk everything for their faith and beliefs. This unassuming "row house" of a 17th Century Dutch Merchant (make sure to look out for the small and almost mistakable sign) hides a fascinating secret. When Catholicism was banned for a time in the 1700's a congregation of Dutch Catholics built a hidden chapel in an attic. You will first visit the restored mansion of the merchant who allowed the congregation to dwell in his attic. Next you will climb unassuming steep steps up to this hidden gem. The audio-guide will help you understand the history and reasoning behind the congregation and their place of worship. You do not need to be Catholic to grasp the importance of this place. It still has a congregation and the adjacent building is currently being worked on (the admission price will help with this project) for additional museum space in the next year or two. So, some of the artifacts are not on display at the time. However, when they are the museum will be even more informative than it is now. Defiantly worth a visit.

Historical treasure in the middle of the city. This musuem was just amazing. It explains matters of religion as well as social life in the past centuries. The guided tours were just so perfectly organized and rich in details and explanations that we were extremely amazed and happy with this visit and the job that the people taking care of such a mansion have done! The house has been restored and it is kept like you're seeing it by a group of people devoted to this heritage. I cannot help but being mesmerized. It is so well kept and it is worth a visit. This small treasure lies right in the middle of the city, telling part of this city's beautiful story. Definitely deserves a visit.

Fascinating look into the 17th Century. Although I can't say I am a church going Christian this small now defunct Catholic Church is a fascinating glimpse into the past. The audio tour provided allows a casual visitor to understand the pressures born by those who wanted to follow the Catholic faith at a time in Amsterdam when it was banned. For up to 150 worshipper this was the place to be, a church 'hidden' in the upper floors of a city town house.

Disappointing . . .. Wow, the other reviewers must have visited a different place! Another reviewer said the audio guide was sub-par -- that was flattering to the dull, uninformative commentary. The lighting was incredibly poor which made appreciating the exhibits, as well as navigating the narrow steep steps near impossible. Had we had to pay for admission, I would have been quite upset. However, it was included on our Museum Card and cost us nothing additional -- which was about what it was worth.
Beautiful!. A very interesting museum. Around every corner there was more to read and understand about this little church. Such a rich history and the exhibits were well done. Worth a visit.
Must see!. This little church inside a regular house is amazing! The architecture, the construction and location are amazing! A must go to!!!
A tiny bit of peaceful heaven. I loved the history around this little church, where the Christians hid their religion whilst the Spanish were in town.
Out of the ordinary. Very interesting. The information was well presented. I really got a sense of how it must have been when the secret chapel was in use.

Lovely museum house in Amsterdam. I really enjoyed this little museum with a hidden secret church in the attic - a lovely house and you could start to get the feel of an old canal house and how they used to live - tiny beds in the wall and little dark kitchens too. Very sweet

Dusty and fusty. I was curious to see this curiosity but the venue is in the process of renovation to make it more accessible. Until then, it is a bit down at the heel and I felt that the audio information was sub-par. They should have built up in more detail the reason why Catholics had to worship in secret, as it is an interesting aspect of Amsterdam history.

Hidden gem. A great museum close to the Oude Kirke and within the red light district. A free information headset aided the visit and also the small numbers who were present when we visited. One not to miss.

Favorite Amsterdam attraction. Amsterdam is a fabulous city, full of museums and restaurants and things to see and do--the Rijksmuseum and the Van Gogh Museum among them--but this was my favorite. It was a little hard to find, but the search was part of the fun. It doesn't take long to see everything, and there's an excellent audio tour in a variety of languages which is included with the ticket price. Fantastic renovation of this seventeenth-century house, and the church hidden at the top is both beautiful and moving. I would say, don't miss it!

What a surpirse!. Catholic outlawed by protestants for 300 years, in such a tolerant place as Amsterdam. Who knew? The result was so-called hidden churches. You gotta see this! The interactive system included with admission is so informative. Really memorable.

An unexpected treasure. An unassuming entrance for a fascinating building. Views of the surrounding area were also fascinating. An amazing part of history so carefully preserved. So well presented and the audio guide was perfect. One of my favourite 'museums'.
A delightful surprise. This small, beautifully kept museum is absolutely authentic. The staff and facilities were very good. For atmosphere and sense of history, top class.

Fascinating, for more than just the chapel. Most visitors will be drawn here to see the hidden chapel, but the house itself is fascinating and gives a strong sense of the home environment for a 17th Century Amsterdam merchant and his family. It is quite a modest dwelling, particularly compared with the Museum Willet-Holthuysen, a much grander residence on the Herengracht canal, which we also visited. We would recommend visiting both residences and appreciating the contrast. Please be aware that there is currently some noise and disruption from the redevelopment work of the adjacent house, but this will deliver much improved access and facilities for visitors in the near future.
Interesting. To see how a man from germany came from rags to riches, then built a secret church in the attick it's impressive.It is not an expensive museum, but a very interesting one.

Impressively well kept Catholic Church. The history and beauty of this Catholic church will not disappoint. Very impressive, well kept and the self guided tour audio was very informative and interesting.

Very surprising. I guess you need to see this in order to experience the real Amsterdam. Lots of history and also lots of steep stairs, so don't go there if you have mobility issues. Otherwise, this is a great hidden secret and in my opinion a must-see

A real experience!. the church is not located in the best of neighborhoods as it is in the red light district but it's definitely worth your visit. Great appreciation of how devoted catholics were at that time .
Must See. While not on the same level as the Rijksmuseum, seeing the Van Gogh's is a once in a lifetime experience. The museum is well laid out and easy for seniors to navigate. Well done overall.

A hidden treasure. In the center of the Red Light District you can pass by this house/museum without notice it, but in the moment that you go there you start a trip to the past. When the Catholicism was forbidden, this family built in the roof of their house a secret church in order to keep their rituals of faith. Was a big surprise find this hidden treasure in the middle of the city center.

Surprising. Along with the historical context of Catholic persecution, this is a remarkable structure if for no other reason that the engineering that went into building a concealed church for 150 in the attic.

A bit of history on the edge of the red light district. A hidden church in an adapted attic surviving from the time of the suppression of Catholics in Amsterdam.. A short distance from the old church so a good double visit.

Interesting trip back in time. One of the things I enjoy most about traveling is stumbling across a bit of history that you were unaware of and, if you are lucky enough, immersing yourself into a place and time in a way you could never get through a history book. Our Lord in the Attic was a perfect example of this kind of thing. If you have an hour and want to take a trip back in time while learning about a fascinating moment in Dutch religious history, give it a try.

Een Empty House full of stories. That's what you read on the small red square scan in every room. It is true!. Seems that it's small museum but..... 'wrong!'. When you thought that you already walked around and finished, you'll find a stair to go up and you will find another floor again. The best audio tour I've ever got. It's worth visiting.

Fascinating historical insight. This is a fascinating place that can be appreciated in a number of ways, the history of the transference of religious authority, the use of a canal-side house, and the architectural ingenuity of the interior adaptations. The audio-guide gives you jusy enough information without over-burdening you and the design proposals to make future visits more manageable are imaginatieve and clearly explained

Unique . The actual museum exhibit descriptions and displays could use some work but all the history is so amazing. It was awesome and we were glad we went! Would definitely recommend because it shows a unique side of the Catholic Church, not the extravagant display you are use to.

Cute museum - unusual location . Situated in the red light district this small canal house with its secret church at the top was an interesting stop. No need to be Catholic to enjoy - but I'm sure it helps! There was quite a bit of stair climbing, but that's Amsterdam.

Wonderfull museum in the middle of the red light district. A little and very nice church in the middle of the red light district. When you go in, you totally forget where you are. Look closely at the architecture of this building and enjoy the history of the building and the small church. I come back every year to this place, now also with our children.

Wonderful Old Church. Formerly secret catholic church build in the attic of a traders house during the first years of protestant reing in Amsterdam. Have a look at the household of the people that there and walk up to the attic to their secret church. Hard to believe that for many years the autorities did not know about this ... Must see

Very interesting place to visit. The church has an interesting and the site is well preserved and well presented. You'd never guess there was a church inside. The audio tour is nice and once their visitors center is finished it will be much easier to check in and such.

Stunning!. One of the unexpected highlights of my visit to Amsterdam. I stumbled across this building as I was wandering along the canal and intrigued by the story of the illegal church in the attic paid it a visit. The gentleman at the desk was friendly and informative and as I followed the detailed audio tour around the narrow confines of the house I found myself transported back to a very much less tolerant Holland. The chapel itself is amazing and all the better for the story behind it. The museum is currently expanding into the house next door so there is some disruption, but this is such a unique attraction I would put it on an "Must do" list in Amsterdam.

hidden gem with wowfactor. so it starts off as a beautifully refurbished 17th century house (think Rembrandt and Vermeer) but when you wend your way to the very top there's a big surprise in the attic. My friends and I literally got to the top of the stairs and went "wow, wow wow". The secret catholic church in the attic is spread across 3 houses hence the remarkable size at the top of a house with a relatively small footprint. go see this FIRST, before you go to see the paintings of dutch interiors by Vermeer in the Rijksmuseum as it will provide excellent context.

A surprisingly interesting hidden gem. Catholicism was banned back in the 16th and many adherents found support in hidden churches and secret places of worship and fellowship. This church is outstanding example of this clandestine reaction to religious persecution and oppression. While I expected to be underwhelmed, this secret little church is an inspiring and interesting look back to these dark times.

We could have missed this so easily, but are glad we didn't. I'm not a religious person (the opposite in fact), but I'm very glad I visited "our lord". Built across the roof spaces of three typical Amsterdam houses (a small footprint, but very tall) the church was constructed as a clandestine meeting place for those of the Catholic persuasion (although it seems that the then city fathers, having deprived the Catholics of their lavish, decorated former possessions and outlawing them, turned a blind eye to such places just so long as they were out of sight!). The Catholic Businessman who funded and built the place (and it must have cost a bomb) as a result bequeathed to his family substantial debts, but to prosperity a little gem!It's quite amazing: a church on three galleried levels inside such a small place. And well preserved: the place became a museum when it ceased to be a church (in the late 1800s), and preserved alongside are the kitchens and living quarters of priests and subsequent curators. There's a lot of building work going on at the moment to improve access, but in fact the information provided (handsets in a choice of languages that would rival the tower of Babel) is thorough, well-presented and interesting. Access is currently, (given the steep stairs and multi-storey layout) limited to those with the ability to clamber a bit!Don't miss it!

A gem of a museum. This is an incredible 17th century canal - side house ( now a museum) where the rich merchant owner wanted to practise his Roman catholic faith, against all the odds. What did he do? He built his own large Catholic church in the attic of the building. At least 100 people could have worshipped there. Catholics worshipped there from 1663 to 1887. In addition there are old rooms where the merchant and his family lives. An excellent audio guide gives you a comprehensive history of the building. It is a real gem and well worth visiting. It is situated to the north of Amsterdam's oldest church (Oude Kerk) and is known by the Dutch as "Museum ". Ons ' Lieve Heer op Solder"(Our Lord in the attic".)

Wonderful little museum. I took my mum here knowing she would love it and having been told about it on a tour around Amsterdam. It really was quite wonderful to see the effort that had gone into building this church, you can't really appreciate it until you actually go in and see it. It's not expensive for a museum in amsterdam and didn't take too long either, found it more interesting than the old church if you're looking around churches. They do audio tours which work very well and tell you a little but doesn't drown you in information!

Surprisingly interesting attraction. As a non-believer, I was talked into visiting this attraction by my wife. The attic space was created by Catholics during the Reformation when their religion was banned. A wealthy Catholic merchant provided 4 levels of his home for a hidden place of worship in the middle of the city. The ingenuity was startling.

A Hidden Jewel. Tucked away down an alley on the edge of the red light district, this a wonderful place to visit. Its a classic Amsterdam town house looking out over a canal, but at the top of the house is a beautiful chapel. The story about how the chapel came about and has survived gives a fascinating insight into the social and religious history of Amsterdam. There's a major renovation and expansion programme going on, so probably worth checking on access/opening arrangements before you visit.

Hidden Gem, a must see in Amsterdam. After visiting this delightful church a few years ago while it was undergoing renovation, I revisited and found it to be the most delightful and informative museum. It was a hidden Catholic Church when Holland was a Protestant country. A wealthy merchant converted the upper floors of his house to create the hidden church. It is quite beautiful and includes living accommodation all furnished and presented as though the inhabitants of 18th century Amsterdam had just left the room.The staff are delightful and helpful. They are currently rebuilding the house next door which will give the museum more space for visitor facilities which should be ready in September 2015.Although when you look on the map you will find this museum to be in the Red Light District, don't be alarmed during the day the area is very beautiful and not at all disturbing...you could bring your mother or children here! Some of the prettiest canals are in this area.
Nice little museum. Very interesting story, liked the individual sound systems for explanations. Well laid out, though quite a few stairs.

Beautiful Catholic Church which survived the Orange Reformation. The museum pass is a must have in Amsterdam. This is a hidden gem. A full Catholic Church with full statuary which managed to survive the Orange reformation by camouflage basically. Fascinating!

Fantastic little museum - a must see. A really special place that says so much about religious tolerance over the ages - although officially banned, this 'hidden' Catholic Church obviously flourished during the reformation.Excellent Audio Tour - This place is a must see.

A definite must. I was so moved by what this man and his friends did for the sake of their Beliefs. The restoration work is amazing. And to see spartan the family quarters were and then to see this absolutely perfectly comfortable church was carved and done. It is an experience not to be missed!

Interesting to see but not more than that. You will see a church in a house. That's summarized what you will get. Not more, not less. During the visit you have the possibility to hear some information. Can be useful to understand what you see.

A Hidden Gem. Typical Dutch house from outside with no hint of the gem hidden in the attic. Although it is undergoing renovation and conservation work at the moment this does not in any way diminish the enjoyment of this beautiful building.
Lovely and unusual. Worth finding as it's such a little treasure. Art is worth a visit as is the location. Have been there twice as it is so intriguing.

A hidden gem. A wonderful surprise within the Red Light District. A clandestine catholic church, preserved from the times catholic confession was banned in the Netherlands, and now converted into museum. Very peaceful place, which talks a lot about history of this country. Definitively worth visiting.

A gem!. Really worth visiting, this church in the attic of a canal townhouse is amazing! At just 8 euros to enter, it is very good value - my friend and I were there for an hour and a half, it was so interesting and there is so much to see.

Interesting, peaceful, well organised. We visited on a Wednesday in late October. We really enjoyed our visit. It was a very attractive small church, the price was reasonable, and the audio guides informative. Our visit took a little under an hour - a good length. Recommended.

A 'must do'. This hidden chapel in the Red Light District proved a welcome break from the city. It's very good value and visitors are given a nifty audio tour for free. Not only is it an interesting step back in time, you get a good view across the roofs and of the canal below and, if you want, a chance to reflect on the good aspects of religion for a change.
Wow!. What a wonderful surprise and revelation. I learned so much about Amsterdam history here. A real jewel.

Worth every penny. Located in the red light district, we stumbled across this on a walk and returned later to visit. It's small but the audio guide is excellent. It's a hidden Catholic Church in a canal house attic which was in operation for several hundred years. It was built by combining the attics of three houses. From the outside the house is unassuming but the church inside is lavish. The tour also goes in depth into the renovations and day-to-day life in the lower levels. We had trouble paying with a credit card here, although they have a machine. Maybe bring cash in case. Also- it's a little unclear at first but you can climb the stairs to sit in both the balconies of the church. The view from the top is spectacular!

Unrecognized gem. This museum, like much of Amsterdam, is tiny. Don't be put off by its apparent small size, however. After the religious wars, being Catholic was not favored, so the faithful had to worship in secret. This house is a good example of a 17th century townhouse on the main two floors. But the real treasure is above: The upper two floors are a full church, absolutely invisible from the outside. The floors and carvings are in excellent condition, and new grass mats simulate original floor coverings. An addition is underway to add a proper entry area and gift shop. Well worth a visit (after the Rijksmuseum and van Gogh museum, of course.)
The secret church on the 3rd floor.. This was a different experience and a very good one. Your wont see this anywhere else. Easy to find and not expensive. I think we paid 8 euro pr. person.

A little jewel in old Amsterdam. This beautiful hidden church tells a lot about Amsterdam. In the Calvinistic seventeenth century catholisism was allowed as long a it stayed inviible. So some rich Amsterdam families built a church in their own canalhouses, of which this one is the most in tact. To enjoy it, you must face quite a few stairs, but you will be rewarded. It's a unique experience.
outstanding. This is a hidden treasure just loved it beautiful building, great look into Amsterdam's past would recommend this while in the main area

Hidden gem.. Came across this church on Trip advisor. A hidden gem.It was amazing how they got the organ up there.lovely story about how the church came to be there. various rooms to view but main church is lovely and well done. Audio system. Worth a visit. The new extension will add to this place, look forward to viewing it on next trip.

interesting. we enjoyed this "museum" but found it a bit lacking for some reason that I just cannot explain. Of course it is fascinating to see how people had to live and the extent that they are willing to go in order to worship as they pleased, even when it requires to buy 3 houses joined together and secretly adjoining all of their attics to make a place where they can worship. I wouldn't recommend my friends go here, nor would I suggest that they skip it. Sorry I am not more helpful and wasted your time if you read this wishy washy review. I usually have strong thoughts on things, but this is the exception I suppose......?
beautiful hidden church. amazing story, but be prepared to climb some steep stairs. this little gem was hidden in the attics for years

Diamond in the Rough. The juxtaposition of this historic religious site in the middle of the red light district is a bit odd but I would highly recommend stopping in. The site and the very good audio guide encapsulate the tension between Protestants and Catholics in Amsterdam over 300 years ago in a very unique way. The pragmatic Dutch blind eye to its existence also provides insight into the character of the Dutch people. Definitely worth a visit after seeing the Rijks, Van Gogh and Anne Frank house.

Interesting and worthwhile. This is not one of the most famous atttractions of Amsterdam, but exactly that is what made it so interesting. A house, which looks like a regular house, hiding a Catholic Church in the top floors, from the times Catholic practices were not permitted officially.
