It is very nicely kept, and you get a real feeling of what it was like at the time. Definitely worthwile seeing it.
Lovely museum. excellent hide out for local visitors! Great history, lovely staff and tours. Great canal views. Looking forward to their expansion.

amazing. I loved this. How on earth did they get all that marble up to the top floor? The Catholics used it as their church as the protestants attacked Catholics. They must have got this marble in the night so nobody saw. Has to be seen to be believed

Surprising church inside a normal looking house. It's amazing what was done to this house when Catholicism was outlawed. They took the top floors and made a working Catholic church with confessional, pipe organ and all. Be careful going up the stairs - like most old homes built then, they're narrow and steep.

A hidden treasure. Not the easiest place to find - out taxi driver had to consult with a colleague before setting out! Good that photographs were allowed. The chapel itself is lovely and one can imagine the people coming there secretly to worship. If you are also visiting the Amsterdam Museum make sure to get the discount with your ticket here.

Terrific Museum!. Our Lord in the Attic was recommended to us by friends as something worthwhile to see and it definitely was. When Protestants took back the churches from the Catholics (it was not an option to co-exist), Catholics could no longer worship openly. The Lord in the Attic is 3 houses that were bought by a business so that he could create a church for Catholics to worship in. The town council knew that this type of church existed but turned a blind eye - business was more important than principle :) There are lots of steep stairs and 3 floors to tour. Very good job of showing history in a visual way.

Very Interesting. A Catholic chapel hidden away in a house's attic in the days when catholicism was forbidden in Holland is the stuff of period mystery novels. The church has been restored and a visitor's center is under construction. This is a bit of local color well worth your time.

Hidden church, hidden gem. A hidden church in an old merchant house in the middle of the Red Light district, tucked away between pubs and ladies of the night. Definitely worth a visit; the sheer audacity of the creators to keep practising their faith and build this beautiful little church away from prying eyes is a powerful story. Am slightly biased as I was married there in 2001.

Secret jewel. A secret place in a hidden building. Back to the times when religion was a problem for some people. Do not miss this visit, you'll regret it. Free audio guide to help you understand history of the church.
worth a visit. So much to see in what appears to be an ordinary merchants house. Huge and beautiful inside, and very touching.

Worth a Look. If you get a chance to see this museum - it is definitely worth doing so. There is an audio tour which is included with admission. The church was created when it was illegal to practice Catholicism in Amsterdam and they were forced to go "underground" to practice their faith.

Don't bother... Despite the renovations, it was still somewhat expensive at I think 8 euro. Not much to see, maybe 5 rooms, and even with the audio devices there was little historical information surrounding the church- would have liked to have heard more on how, why, when etc Catholic vilification began during the Dutch renaissance. No written aides and no documents/displays on the church.. Don't bother! Unless maybe your Catholic obsessed..

Hidden church in an attic. The audio tour is well
Put together and it's only €8- to go in. You can take it at your own pace , and as with everywhere in Amsterdam the stairs are steep and winding...

free audio provided. If you are down visiting the Old Church, just walk up the block and pay a visit to this museum. Very interesting history and the free audio guide is very useful. Although the museum is undergoing an expansion with the acquisition of another building across the alleyway to be used as a visitor's center once finished, it did not in any way detract from the museum. There are steps but although steep, I did not find this a problem and I am an older female that is not ready to run a marathon by any means. One of the museums included with the museumkart, which if you are a lover of museums and plan on spending more than 4 days in the Dam, this is just ideal and will save you money and time(no standing in lines in most places)

A gem of a church with a great history. I would not have visited this church were it not for tripadvisor reviews. It was worth the time and money €8, which included the audio guide. Three houses that look like individual homes from the outside share an attic that houses The Lord in the Attic church. The audio guides were clear, informative and very helpful. I was amazed at the size of the church which has two balconies and an organ. Some family rooms have been restored and it was good to get a glimpse of how life might have been 350 years ago in Amsterdam. Stairs are narrow and not easy to navigate.

Unbelievable hidden gem. You would have no idea that this place exists for the outside. It is completely hidden within and is utterly beautiful.Audio tour is very insightful and the preserved artefacts are superb.....

Hard to find, but worth the visit. This is a Catholic church created in a townhouse that was hidden from the Protestants. It is small and beautiful and is an example of what determined people can accomplish.

Worth a visit. So many museums in Amsterdam, and so little time, but I decided to visit this one. It was worth the visit. A very unique church that gives you a chance to climb up and down all the staircases and check out all the nooks and crannies. Audio guide gives you details and came free with the price of admission.

Unique place to visit. A visit to this 17th century merchant house would be interesting in itself, but the house hides a secret chapel built in the attic at a time when Catholics were not allowed to practice their religion.A very informative audio guide is included in the admission price.The chapel has just been restored and repainted in the original rose colour; if you look carefully you can see the paint samples in a corner.The house next door is being converted into a visitor centre that will provide better faciities without spoiling the authenticity of the historic house. I look forward to visiting again when it is completed.

Well hidden what a beauty. Wow we loved this place how beautiful and peaceful, we went on a rainy day and spent quiet a while wondering around listening to the auto tour guide about all the history and beauty of this place.A real hidden gem and a definate to add to your tour of Amsterdam.If you enjoy history you will love it here.

Worth a visit if you have time. Very interesting, good history, with good audio guide. The place is quite small so an hour will be enough for this. Warning for those with problems to get up stairs. You will go up and down three floors with very narrow and steep stairs. One wish: more toilets please. I only saw one and can't imagine how it can accommodate guests when it is peak hours.

Historical. This house with a hideaway RC church in its attic is still in a state of refurbishment or to put it another way work is still in process to reinstate it to what it was like in the 1800s although it dates back to the 1600s but that does not distract from it being a worthwhile visit. The new rush flooring in the church itself is from Cambridgeshire.

Excellent and enchanting. I came across this little gem by accident and have to say I really really loved it. To think that the features of the church have survived to this day and it has the same serenity and peacefulness of a normal sized church.
well worth a visit I promise you.

A surprise museum in the red light district. In the 1600's public displays of religion was frowned upon. The owner of three adjacent hours decided to turn his upper floor and attic into a Catholic Church. About 150 people attended Mass on a Sunday entering thru a side door. The family lived on the bottom floors. It is now a museum of the church. It is an interesting piece of history and faith.

A Hidden Gem in Amsterdam. I was shocked to see this elaborate church hidden in an attic in the middle of Amsterdam. This is a beautiful attraction not to be missed. It also provides some history as to why this Catholic church was hidden. Very interesting and well worth a visit!

Hidden secret. Stunning building - an old canal house in the red light district with an extraordinary secret church incorporated into the top few floors of the building. Informative audio tour provides plenty of historical/cultural insights.
Unique. We found this a totally different experience. A museum, church and canal house all in one visit. The audio was well done with good information.

A Gem of a Museum. We searched out this museum, located in the Red Light District, because it sounded worth the visit. We were not disappointed. Inside a regular looking canal house is a small but complete Catholic church. It shows and explains how Catholic Dutch people were able to practice their religion during a period when they were not openly able to worship.
Great Museum. My favorite artist. We had a great time. People were very nice. easy to get to and see if time is an issue.

A hidden gem. This church, near the red light district, is a real gem. It was used as a secret place of worship, and from the street it looks just like another house. Inside, it main room has a proper, and impressive, alter, as well as a choir loft and organ. The whole house is full of interesting nooks and crannies, and the view from the top floor isn't bad either!

A hidden church-gem. Our lord in the attic, is a very well hidden church-gem, not visible from the street. They do a fine audio-tour in the museum/church, though the routing inside is a little confusing. Beautifull place on the brim of "red light district"

A must see when planning your trip to Amsterdam. With your IAmsterdam ticket you can get into Our Lord in the Attic for free. ...I thought that this was a stunning place to visit. The audio tour was really good and explains why and how they created the church. Amazing piece of history. ...A beautiful calm atmosphere in the middle of the hustle and bustle of Amsterdam. .. well worth a visit. ....

Definitely recommended. At first, I was not particularly interested in seeing this and waited outside while my wife went through this hidden Catholic Church. She was so impressed, she convinced me to go through and I'm delighted she did. This is one of maybe two or three hidden churches in town and definitely should be visited. The free audio guides are a must.
NOT SURE WHY WE WENT HERE ON A RAINY DAY?. We happened by on a rainy day and decided to visit. Hefty fee to enter and little to see. Close quarters building. I cannot recommend.
part of the houses on the canal. a unique building. Very interresting from historical perspective. Good audio guide , spend the few euros!covered by museumkart

Oldest Museum in Amsterdam. This is a beautiful little gem of a museum with a fascinating story to tell of Amsterdam & religious freedom in the 1600's. It is a living museum because the church is still in use. Plan on giving yourself enough time to truly sink into the experience. The headsets are very helpful and the bookstore has some very nice items.CAUTION: There are steep stairs and no elevator.

Very Beautiful. I'm glad that the majority of the restoration is now complete on the house; the altar and organ are all reinstalled. They have laid new floor protectors and the audio tour guide is wholesome and interesting. They are currently expanding the museum to a second house next door; as of August 2014, they've dismantled the expansion house to redo the foundations, then they'll put it together again and make an expanded educational area in the second house, freeing up some space in the first house. Would recommend taking time walking around the rest of the house (where the family and the priest lived) to see the intricacy of a compound household built in 3 adjacent buildings.

hard to find gem. been to so many things in Amsterdam over the years but this one had always escaped till now. It hard to find so hopefully during the current renovation/extension they find some money for some signage. Inside it starts off with the lower rooms of bedrooms etc. The audio tour gives decent information without going overboard. Once you get to the attic the realisation of a beautiful church lovingly built to worship a religion over 3 houses with the threat of persecution really is worth it.The church has been restored to a period in the 1600's in a purple colour and it really suited it with the gold a perfect contrast. It is a good place to sit and reflect. The tour continues with more information about how the rooms were used with a nice commentary about Mary and how it is used in the marriage by brides.Overall so pleased this was on trip advisor otherwise a gem would have been missed. Note of caution however is there are very steep stairs throughout.
Interesting. Lovely museum where you can see the inside of a house with a surprise in the attic. A bit pricey but away from the crowds.

Fascinating. An interesting canal house with a good, informative audio tour - included in the ticket price. Quite a lot of information was given, but I did not feel I was back at school in a rather dull history lesson. I enjoyed it too.

Interesting hidden part of Amsterdam history.. We almost walked past it, which shouldn't be surprising considering the 'hidden' nature of it. If you're planning to visit, it might be helpful for you to know the exact address (#40 Oudezijds Voorburgwal).Otherwise, inside has a few dated aspects --and not in a historic way! The audiotour doesn't say much more than you could probably work out on your own, but its included in the price and doesn't hurt to have it.Not a bad visit - worth the 8 euro entry fee, but we'd love to have seen/heard a little more detail and history.
A hidden secret. Go here - it's worth it for a fascinating bit of history dating it the 17th century in Amsterdam. A hidden church built within the upper floors of three houses.

Underground church in canal house attics. When the 17th century Amsterdam city fathers outlawed the practice of Catholicism, the church went underground, or in this case upstairs, as three side by side canal houses had floors removed to convert the upper stories into a chapel. Don an audio set included in your admission, and climb the narrow staircases to a precious piece of history.

Fascinating history. A really interesting insight into the lives of Catholics in Amsterdam and shows the efforts they went to practice their religion. When we went they were still in the process of building an extension on to the museum which will make it an even better experience I am sure. Go if you have the chance.

Fascinating. This small museum has a church placed inside the top floors of a canalside house. Built by catholics when the religion was prohibited. There were no queues and you are able to wander around at your own speed.

A surprise in the middle of Amsterdam. A friend of us, who lives in Amsterdam, promised us that he could take us places that most tourists would probably miss. This was the jewel of the one day walking tour we had in Amsterdam: a beautiful church hidden in the top floors of a regular looking home. Recently renovated, this is an essential place to visit, which tells you an interesting part of the story of the city and the secrets that must be hidden in these narrow buildings.

Museum ons lieve heer op solder. Catholic chapel built on the top three floors of a residence in the 17th century when Catholics were not allowed to practice in Holland. Original flooring and oak stairs. Toured with headset though the residential rooms and the holy rooms. Kitchen and bathroom facilities were interesting. Chapel had services for several hundred each Sunday who climbed up to the attic past the residence.

Little hidden gem. This "hidden" church is an impressive reminder that not so very long ago, there was no freedom of religion in The Netherlands. The church which is hidden in a canal house has been beautifully restored. There are lots of steps in the church and it's quite cramped at times so it's not recommended for very young children. There is a special audio tour for older children which my kids (8 years old) enjoyed very much.

An Interesting Find. This is well worth a visit, despite the renovation work going on around it. It is a beautiful church within the attic, complete with an organ. It is much bigger than the name suggests, and has been lovingly looked after. It also has other rooms to look at, such as the kitchen, parlour and chamber rooms. The entry fee includes a free audio tour set to your country's language, with various information points you can choose to use or not use.Be warned - some of the stairs are incredibly steep (like mountaineering as one of the visitors put it!), so you would not be able to access all parts if you have mobility problems.

Hidden gem: church with great dutch history explanations. Amazing place very well preservedGives you a good idea on how was life 200years ago in this town, the religion...All with a great, included in the price, audio guide very well documented and userfriendly (unlike most audioguides)

Absolutely amazing..... With a bit of a climb up those Amsterdam stairs one can take in and contemplate a bit of Reformation history and begin to comprehend what it is like to not be permitted to practice one's religion freely. Well kept and lovingly restored this bit of Dutch history is worth the time and effort to find....a lovely neighborhood and a beautiful old building.
Interesting walkthrough. Impressive the lengths people went to, to have a place to worship. Very well maintained exhibition with audio guide. Worth a look if you have some spare time.

Hidden gem. This church is a bit hidden away but located in the heart of the city near the Red Light District. Well worth a visit, tells you something about Amsterdam's rich and diverse history. Unique church - literally in the attic.

Second visit - still enchanting. We went back to see the completion of restoration that was underway on our last visit. This tiny space - only 4 seats wide is a testament to the determination of a people to worship freely. Audio tour in a variety of languages make self guiding very easy. Entry is very small so be on the lookout. Steep narrow winding stairs may be a problem for mobility impaired.

A worthwhile place to see. Among the crowded red light district this little gem of a church is an interesting place to visit. The audio guide was informative. It was inspiring to see how the church was hidden in 3 houses and it has retained a beautiful feel.

Interesting and Unusual. I first read about this attraction in my guidebook and was interested. I am so glad we visited. From the outside, the house is easy to miss but from the inside it really is something special. For around €8 for an adult, you get a very informative and well thought out audio guide, which takes you on a tour around the house. Everything is very well maintained, restored or preserved and the story is just fascinating. The tour will only take you about an hour, so if you have some spare time, do visit!

You may possible miss it when walking by. I thought the museum named after the city would be fancy and magnificant, which turned out to be totally wrong. I walked past it and almost missed that. The student ticket was around 5 euro and it came with an audio guide. Was pretty amazed to know the history behind this unattractive building and its secret chapel. However my friend found it boring while i thought it was pretty cool to stand in the rooms same as how they looked 300 years ago.

Very charming. We really loved this. And I think we loved it more as we visited it without prior knowledge of this attraction. A hidden church which is as old as 400 yearsReally enjoyed visiting this interesting hidden church. Though the church isnt lavish and very beautiful but the plain look makes it more authentic. The cost of this attraction is EUR 8.00. It includes free audio guide which is very helpful. The stairs are bit high and narrow, so please be careful. Me and my family were really impressed. Though this attraction was primarily a time-killing site for us. But we were very much engaged upon our visit.

Worth visiting. Really enjoyed visiting this interesting clandestine church. The rooms were fairly bare but this added to its charm and authenticity. Upon entering you are presented with a (free) audio guide which you scan in every room. These audio excerpts were concise while providing interesting facts and a clear picture of the church at the height of its use. I really enjoyed visiting Our Lord in the Attic and would certainly return in the future when renovations are complete(not that these in any way hindered today's tour).

Incredible!. We really loved this, and visited it without much prior knowledge of what lies at the top of these houses. The church itself is spectacular, but when you consider that this is one of many hidden churches, from part of history where Catholics were not able to openly hold mass, and that it lies across three attic spaces in adjoining houses, it becomes more and more interesting. The audio tour (included in the ticket price and available in many languages) was fantastic, and is activated at specific points of interest. Guests are encouraged to wander wherever they please, which feels great.The museum is currently expanding - the ground work for a new building was underway during our visit, so I think this attraction will have even more to offer in the future. We found it very interesting, and would recommend it to fellow history-seekers :)

Church in the attic. A very interesting spot, but quite warm the day we visited. They are doing some renovations which will make for an even better experience. Hard to imagine how they kept the church going for so long.

Well worth a visit. We didn't expect too much but this place was free entry with the I Am card. We were both very impressed.It only takes an hour or so to go around and I would certainly recommend it. Very interesting place and you would have no idea from the outside.

Very interesting church!. This was recommended by a friend and was very interesting. It is in the red light district so be aware of that if you have children with you! The church was built as a result of religious persecution and you would never know there is a church inside the building ! There is an audio guide that goes with it, and there are several flights of stairs to climb,but not too bad!

A must for Catholics. So nice to walk in from the busy streets to find a gem hidden away in a house. The fact that such a church was a secret and hidden left me in awe. The audio guide is a must and very welcome. Spend a few moments sitting in the pews and taking it all in. It can get very hot in this museum and there is no air conditioning. Make sure to grab a fan from the basket as you walk in.

Interesting piece of history. A very interesting overview of the history of intolerance and discrimination against Catholics in Amsterdam -- they give you headphones and as you walk through the three floors of the church, there are stops along the way where you can listen to a couple minutes about the church or its founder.The story of how the church came to be, how the government looked the other way because Catholics churches were illegal in the Netherlands at the time, and then how more tolerant view eventually made the church obsolete. It's been restored to the way it looked in the 17th century, which is simple but still nice.Listening to all the narrated versions takes about an hour and a half, but you could get the general idea in less.

Amazing experience. A truly aweinspiring experience. The restoration work has made this a fantastic place to visit. The church in the attic really makes you see what people had to go through to continue in their faith once protestantism became the offical religion. They are busy renovating a second building to expand visitor numbers and create more space. The building itself has many steep and narrow stairs which might be difficult for anyone with limited mobility. A not to be missed experience if you visit Amsterdam

Unexpected surprise. This museum shows a very interesting part of the history of religious intolerance. A device allows you to listen to the commentary in your own language and to go at your own pace. There is lots of climbing.
Oh God ...one says. whilst climbing the stairs......really it is a so interesting part of all our histories and so worth a visit.
Something worth a visit. Very ununsual place, well worth looking round and they have audio guides to explain what its all about which was useful

Unexpected delight. Highly recommended. Worth a visit even though you can miss it easily. However it was a great experience, much liked both by adults and by children. The audio guide brings the site alive.
nice peaceful colorful. it is surprisingly large. very colorful. you would expect the place to be small because of the location. it is comfortable, quiet and worth a visit if you are into church.
secret church in heart of the city. Amazing what can be done in a small narrow space, especially when hiding a full church. Very well preserved and organized; a trip through history.

Hidden gem in Amsterdam. This is a great little museum/church in Amsterdam that is well worth a visit and not so well known. It gives an insight into the religious history of the Netherlands and the lengths people would go to practice their faith during times of persecution. The audio guides are pretty good. It is well laid out and well presevred with some of the original stair cases in place. The alcove beds were interesting! The entrance fee is 8 euros but it is worth it. A note though if you have difficulty with stairs then this one may be a little hard for you.

Surprisingly interesting. Not for everyone but if you're interested in history and culture then it's worth the visit. A beautiful church hidden in the attic of 3 houses and you really don't expect to see such a big church hidden behind what seems to be a small house. Included in the ticket is an audio guide which is easy to use and really informative. The museum isn't too busy so you have the freedom to explore the different floors and areas at your own pace.

Very Interesting Place . This very historic place of religious significance (Roman Catholic) is well worth a visit. The audio guide is one of the best I have ever experienced, in that it doesn't overload with facts and figures. Although on the small side, it has as it strength its simplicity.

interesting site to visit. If you are wandering thru the Red light district and would like a different type of attraction check out this church located on the top floor of a residence. Admission includes headphones for a self guided tours. Be aware that there are several very steep staircases that you will need to climb...overall anuce place...allow about an hour

Excellent. We visited here on the suggestion of a friend and loved it. Very small attraction that was not crowded. Fascinating little church. Great audio guide (included with admission) really explained the history of the church. Highly recommend.

Really interesting!. I loved this place. It was so interesting learning the history from the audio guides. The ornate church is amazing and it is astounding that it was hidden in the top of the house.

Small but interesting. Having seen lots of amazing baroque churches all over Europe, this was still worth seeing.The church just needed to be not obvious that its a church from the outside to get past the puritan laws. It didn't need to be truly hidden. They are building a bigger visitors center next door, so it should be easier to find.

Interesting church in a townhouse. Very interesting to see. The different levels of the house had been preserved and you work your way up to the church in the attic, which is a sight to see! The audio tour is very informative and I recommend to take an hour to do it.

Worth visiting if you have the extra time.. If you're in Amsterdam longer than the average tourist (or if you're a local), this is worth visiting. The history of this building (that looks like a typical canal house from the outside) is incredibly interesting. They are currently undergoing a few renovations and it smells a little funny, but I still wouldn't miss it. P.S. If you're visiting with younger children, you may want to come on Oudezijds Voorburgwal from the north (i.e. Prins Hendrikkade) to avoid having to explain to your children why there are women in the windows wearing lingerie. :-)

A hidden surprise. I have been in this place for the first time in 2007 before the remodelation was finished and had the opportunity to get back later on a few times.This is a must see no matter what religion you are into. Not only has a great historical value but it is a beautiful hidden surprise.
Hard to find but worth the effort. This is such an interesting chapel. Not your typical church. The audio guide was excellent. One of my favourite attractions in Amsterdam.

Very Impressive. Not to be overlooked while in Amsterdam. It is interesting to see what can be done on the inside of a plain exterior. I visited over 15 years ago and was happy to see the improvements, including audio tour and more rooms.

Hidden chapel. Very interesting building in the heart of the Red Light district. Audio guide explained the history of each room. The chapel was an amazing sight on the top floor of this house overlooking the canal.

Fascinating find in the Red Light District. I read about this in Rick Steves' guide and am very glad we sought it out. Amazing to find a church hidden in the Red Light District...it is still being restored but much has been done and the audioguide is quite informative. Absolutely worth a visit!

Interesting little church in the attic!. Very interesting to hear the history! The area, the red district, makes it eve mire surprising! It is nice to see such a small church, after seeing all the (beautiful) big churches in Amsterdam of which there are plenty!!!

One-of-a-Kind Shrine to Religious Freedom. This 3-story Catholic Church from the 1600's was purpose-built by a rich merchant within the attics of 3 adjoining canal houses in the heart of the Red Light District, while he and his family lived on the floors underneath.. It remains much as it was then, including the purple paint-job. It is still used occasionally for services and is in the process of expanding into the house next door. While not especially inspirational physically, it is a constant reminder of mankind's search for the other-worldly in the face of official oppression. A free audio guide is included with the price of admission. Free admission with the Museum Card.

Well preserved and interesting topic. A small museum but well-preserved building with an interesting (free) audio guide to explain the history. Well worth some quiet time to contemplate that the Catholic church was also persecuted in times gone by, although the religion was tolerated behind closed doors.

fasinating. This is a very different experience in the heart of the red light district but is really fascinating and beautiful , It is easy to miss it as just looks like any other house by the canal Loved it

Brilliant!. We popped in here on our way to the station and were so pleased we did.The entrance fee was 8euros and, really, was a bargain. We were provided with devices which gave us info at various points. The church has now been restored and is beautiful.Well worth a visit.
What's in the Attic?. Worth a visit. Free on the Iamsterdam card and free audio guide. Tucked away on the edge of red light district, this is a great place to spend an hour or so.

Hidden Gem. Hidden is the right word as the frontage to this church is on a normal street in Amsterdam yet hides the fact that it holds a church with the capacity for prayer and thought for many many people.Amazing it stayed intact throughout many troubled years of reformation.Well worth a visit.

A travel to the past. The house is amazing, very well conserved. On the top you have a nice view of the neighborhood. I liked a lot the tiles on the kitchen, and the hide church is amazing. They are building a second house next, to make more confortable facilities.

Awesome surprise.. Great quick sight to see outside of the "museum district". Worth taking the time to listen to the audio tour as it provides a lot of additional insights how the church came to exist in the first place and how it was built.

Well worth a visit!. Wow! This is a gem. I'm so glad I read the reviews before visiting Amsterdam and decided to visit Our Lord in the Attic. First, it's a great chance to see the inside of an old canal house and get some sense of how the people lived in the 1600's. Second, the house and the church have a great story and give you a good sense of this aspect of Amsterdam history. The church built across the attics of three canal houses is amazing, and very well-preserved. The self-guided tour is very informative, engaging, and easy to use. As other reviewers have said, the stairs are steep and narrow, and might be very difficult for the elderly.

interesting view inside a canal house.. Here is an opportunity to view the domestic life of people in Amsterdam during the Golden Age.It is also an opportunity to understand and Amsterdam's sense of religious freedom and toleration.

Neat piece of history. I was surprised there weren't more people here. The audio tour is nicely done and the church is really interesting. One of our favorites. Tip: Admission is free with the iAmsterdam card.
worship. The skill of building a place of worship, keeping Christians hidden from persecution was quite extraordinary.

Our Lord in the Attic. This small church is a testimony to creativity and determination to worship. The church is beautifully preserved. It is another Dutch museum that immerses you in history and culture.

Surprise!. Great discovery, not many people seem to know about. This secret catholic church is upstairs in the attic of a 17C. house, built when The Netherlands became Protestant. There was an excellent audio guide. Despite being banned Catholics were not persecuted, demonstrating the tolerance of the Dutch.Beware very steep stairs.

Not to be missed. After viewing many churches this was an amazingly intimate view into the life of one man and family of faith. The interior has been well preserved and not recreated as in some other places. We found it much more informative of the life and culture of people in a time and culture, than the tours of the old church and the new church both of which are barren, rather meaningless warehouse structures without giving meaning or insight into community life. We almost missed this sight and are so very glad we took the time to find it.

A great museum that many tourists don't know about!. Similar to the Anne Frank House, this is a museum about a religion being practiced in secret. It is a nice sized museum, with a free audio tour. It is very informative, and very immersive as you are able to walk around in the church that is in the attic of the houses. There are not that many people, as tourists do not usually know about this place, so it is a very pleasant, and not crowded, experience. I highly recommend this museum!
Great story and fun to see. We enjoyed this place and the story behind it. There are a lot of steps and maybe not the best tour for some people that have a hard time getting around.

Wonderful insight into earlier times. We decided to go through this museum for something to do. It was way better than we expected. The way that an entire church was constructed into the attic of these houses is itself incredible. The preservation and history is very well presented and the free audio that comes with your admission tells either a brief or more detailed story of the highlights of the houses, church, changing areas, and what happened in the past. A very worthwhile place to visit that is not over the top and is presented as it pretty much was back when it was in use. Fantastic!

A Gem in the Red Light District. Very interesting house with the stunningly simple but amazingly large church on the upper floors. Unexpected in the marvelously tawdry Red Light District. It's one of those memorable places that blends location, history and surprise all in one.

Needs to be better signposted.. Very interesting canal house with a church above!The building is undergoing some renovation,but the church is amazing.werWe did have trouble finding this attraction,the hotel directed us incorrectly and locals were not much better.
Really interesting. Easy to find, free with I Amsterdam card, easy to use audio device. Beautifully restored, interesting and not crowded. Alyse

Incredible little church!. This building was worth visiting, but it was a little difficult to find. The history of the church is amazing and makes us appreciate more the beauty of it. This hidden church is a must visit for Catholics visiting Amsterdam.

Definitely worth while!. We found this museum very interesting from a historical point of view (religious persecution of Catholics) as well as fascinating from an architectural aspect. There are a lot of steep stairs and the audio tour is a bit lacking in directions as to how you should proceed but it doesn't take anything away from the experience.Give yourself about an hour to go through it properly.

A fascinating story. This is a very interesting house, church and museum all in one. It doesn't take very long to go through and the story behind it is fascinating. It offers a very good insight into Amsterdam's history. Well worth a visit. It is included on the iAmsterdam City Card.

Even the non-religious should visit it.... I enjoyed a lot visiting this place. The audio tour is mandatory cause it gives you a lot of info not displayed. Even if you're not catholic or into religions, go for it. Its worthy to see. Its a masterwork of architectonics and a piece of Amsterdam's history that you cant put aside.

Quite interesting. Breathtaking Chapel.. I was a bit meh about visiting this but it was free with the IAmsterdam card and we were close by so I said what the hell. I have to say I was surprised. We got headphones and a device that when you scanned it in each room it would tell you information about it. The highlight was seeing the actual Chapel in the attic which I wasn't expecting. Very beautiful and the history was fascinating. If you're into your religious history or have a free pass card then I would say go for it.

Worth a visit. I wanted to visit here after seeing a documentary once, and enjoyed it very much. It was worth the visit at 8euro, the audio guide was very informative. The church itself is not very big, but it holds a valuable part in religion and history and I'm glad it has been opened up for all to experience and enjoy.

Amsterdam wasn't always a tolerant city. I had never heard about this tiny church hidden in the attic of three houses. Catholics worshipped here when open practice of their faith was forbidden in Amsterdam. Very interesting, good audio explanations. Lots of narrow stairs, but it's worth the visit.

overpriced. 8 euros entrance to see 2-3 rooms and a chapel inside the house is too much overpriced. At least they give you the english audio guide,but the truth is that it doesnt say anything more interesting than the books.

An Amazing house/church. This old seventeenth century house has in its attic a lovely "hidden" church. Due to the fact that Roman Catholicism was not officially a creed you could follow, those people who wanted to remain faithfull to the older belief, they had to come up with places of worship that were not too obvious. Mr. Hartman thus made a church in his attic.

Should be a must-visit when in Amsterdam. This small and beautifully laid-out museum gives a proper feel of Dutch architecture and old living conditions as well as telling fascinating historical tales. There are some steep stairs in parts of the museum so beware with elderly or the very young, but worth a visit for everyone. I bring all my visitors to see it and have not had someone disappointed yet.

Amazing little museum!. This is a catholic church located in the attic of a house belonging to a wealthy man in the 1600's. He built the church so he and his neighbors and friends could practice their faith in a time of Catholic prosecution. Apparently, at that time, there were several of these attic churches in Amsterdam, but I believe this is the only one left.

good place with lot of history. The attic has a small cathedral used a secret place of worship when it was against the law to be caught practicing faith in this country and the chapel has been maintained beautifully and do attract quite a few people. The place is a museum without the usual feel of a museum. There is no extensive information around if you are looking for one but in my opinion the place is self explanatory.

Charming. A very interesting story and well told via the electronic commentary you are given, which is an easy to use device and you can go at your own pace and hear additional information if you wish. It has been beautifully restored and at only 8 euros per adult was a good value visit.
Amazing and beautiful. Our college-aged daughter had read about this Chapel or we would not have known about it. Well worth your time to go visit it!

Amazing stuff. I had no knowledge of this Chapel prior to my visit. It is extraordinary the lengths these people went to in practicing Catholicism. The construction and design was wonderful to see. It really gives you a sense of what these Dutch people endured to practice religious freedom.

Interesting. It might not be that big of attraction but the place is definitely worth checking out. The whole place is a museum and focusing majorly at the church that is in the attic which is a witness to the time when a troubled period in Amsterdam meant no worshipping in public or practicing faith amidst the chaos giving rise to this church. The place is set in the red light district of Amsterdam (yeah ..notice the irony in that) and interestingly have kept the place pristine and plain without much information to go around but then the audio tour is good for that.

What a treat tucked away in Amsterdam. Our adult son recommended that we visit this hidden gem. And it was worth it. A great insight into the religious wars in Amsterdam that came with the Protestant reformation. Worth a visit.

Interesting Place. This was an interesting chapel to visit. I wouldn't put it on the top of the 'things to do while in Amsterdam" but it does deserve to be on the list. It was amazing to see how people were forced to practice their faith during that period of history. The chapel is quite charming and much bigger than I imagined. It's ironic that it is located on the edge of the Red Light District. Please go if you have time.

wonderfully bizarre. This is definitely worth a visit, the house itself is terrifically preserved and with the use of the audio tour (Language of your choosing) and up to date technology you can work your way through the house at your leisure ensuring you don't miss any information. I particularly enjoyed that there was no written information given which gave the house less of a museum feel to it. The chapel section of the house is breath taking when you finally reach it. As usual the staff were friendly and helpful. I didn't feel that this attraction could be improved upon however a video near the end of the tour explains that even more improvements are afoot.

Different experience in Amsterdam. At a talk on Dutch art in Dublin, the church was mentioned as an interesting venue to visit, which we did on our recent trip to Amsterdam. Worth the effort to find and an amazing insight into a period of Dutch history, which resonates with Irish history and Catholic suppression. The narrow steep stairs was difficult for one of our party, but worth the effort for the rest of us. A very unique place in Amsterdam.
Very interesting.. Is what it says. A unique museum. Well laid out interesting story. Good commentary which does no cost extra. Visit will take about one hour.

A Jewel in the Attic. What a wonderful find. My sister was here the week before us and recommended this place. Rick Steeves also recommended it. It is also included on MUSEUMKAART. There are lots of small tight stairs, but not too much if you are used to any climbs. It has been recently renovated inside and they are expanding to the house next door as well. Go...it is worth the time to see how people lived on the canals and how clever the construction is. You will be surprised at what you find at the top of the stairs.

Who knew. This is church hidden in the attic of a home in the Red Light District. Well worth a look around. We got there late but they let us in. You climb stairs to see this hidden church but from the outside would never know it is there-except for the signs.

One of the best museums in Amsterdam. Small but great museum, which I think is a must see while in Amsterdam. It doesn't take long to visit, but I think it's one of the most interesting things we saw there. You get to see an old house and a hidden church. The free audio guide is really helpful and has a lot of interesting information, which adds so much to the visit. A great, small museum, where you can learn a lot about a piece of Amsterdam history.

Hidden away. It took me a while to find this as the street level entrance is a small. Look for the flag hanging from the front of the building. On Sundays it only opens at 1pm. I like real history so walking through a building while hearing its story appeals to me. The church is several floors above what looks like two ordinary houses. Many narrow and steep stairs as you go up and down through the rooms. Currently work is going on to open up a third house as part of the museum.

glad we went. We visited this attraction based on the recommendations on trip advisor. It was worth the visit for us. The one thing that was a little annoying is that they have guided tours coming through while you're trying to listen to an audio guide. This makes it very difficult to hear and you almost have to wait for the group to move on to be able to enjoy the various exhibit rooms. I would still recommend this museum. It gives insight into an interesting period for practicing Catholics in the Netherlands.

Unusual little church. This very unusual church provides an interesting view of Amsterdam's religious history. Very compact, amazing to think that Catholics gathered here in secret to worship. Well set out, with a useful audio guide.

Wonderful!. This is a gem! Much less daunting than some of the enormous, all-encompassing European museums. This museum devotes itself to Vincent Van Gogh and I'd be surprised if anyone -afficianado or not - did of come away with new knowledge or insights.The museum is accessible emotionally and physically; the works on display are astonishing; the information available on VVG is illuminating.I loved it all over again. I think it is a benchmark for small, one artist exhibitors. Just go there and agree its fabulous!!!

have to see it to believe it. wow what a find, was so impressed with this building the way they have kept it just so and the chapel was just amazing you must visit here and area as a whole was lovely too

Something Lovingly Restored. Ons’ Lieve Heer op Solder Museum (Our Lord in the Attic Church), is slap bang in the middle of the Red Light District. Originally this area was one of the smartest addresses in Amsterdam during the Golden Age. It is one of the few remaining Catholic attic churches left, as years passed, the buildings which housed these churches have either been remodelled or demolished.This property has been lovingly restored; in particular the attic church where small patches of the different colours that the church has been painted over the years have been left. After much discussion it was decided to restore it to the original colours. So we have a lovely home, which in typical Dutch style has numerous sets of very narrow steep stairs to climb before you reach the church.From the museum reception I then followed the markers up a set of narrow stairs to the parlour. The room has a fireplace with twisted columns of black marble on either side. There are a number of paintings on the walls, and apparently the painting over the fireplace “The Presentation in the Temple” has hung here since the time of the original homeowner; Jan Hartman. The ornate ceiling; arranged in squares is reflected in the floor, which is white marble bordered by black. Ascend another small spiral staircase to reach the Canal Room”, in here is a black cabinet with the Prodigal Son story painted on it – something a bit different. From here there is a sort of corridor which has small shell font of Holy Water on one wall, continue climbing more stairs, as you exit the stairs you are in the Church. Looking toward the lovely baroque altar which has a painting by Jacob de Wit entitled “The Baptism of Christ” behind it. Although, dependant on the time of year you visit, there may be another painting hanging there as the Church has 3 other paintings which they rotate.Notice the metal rods that span the width of the Church. These are necessary to support the galleries and prevent the walls from moving inwards after part of 2 floor levels were removed to create the soaring height of the Church. This would have been quite and engineering feat when it was completed. The area behind the altar is utilised to house the 3 rotating altar paintings and has a Lady Chapel with a lovely statue of Mary and Jesus dating from late 1600s or early 1700s. Ascending another level brings you to the first gallery; from a window on this level from the right hand side of the church over the rooftops is the spire of the “new” St Nicholas Church. This church was built to accommodate the Catholic worshippers when religious freedom attained. On the left hand side is the spire of the Old Church which was the original main Catholic Church but became a Protestant Church during the Reformation. So at one point in time if you stood in Our Lord in the Attic Church you would have been in the present, and seen the past (the Old Church) and the future (St Nicolas’). I think that’s pretty incredible! On the first gallery level is the original organ, which still works. There is also a collection of ecclesiastical silverware and clothing. Some richly embroidered.The climb to the second gallery is via a very narrow set of stairs. Be warned that there is only one way up and down. Descending from the galleries to the main church level, the stairs which are near the Lady Chapel go down to the confessional. On this level the wooden floors look very old. I do remember being told that there are still some of the original wooden stairs and floors dating from 1660s, unfortunately I can’t remember which ones.More stairs lead you to the Leeuwenberg room at the end of the room a very steep set of stairs lead to the 17c and 19c kitchens. Stone floors in the kitchen made from white Italian marble and black Belgian marble (original from 1660s).I found this a really interesting museum. Although it was undergoing renovations, I didn’t feel that it detracted from the sights and enjoyment of the building. It is wonderful that such a unique part of Dutch history is preserved.If mobility is a problem then the stairs may proved too much of a challenge.Allow about an hour, perhaps a bit more if you really like to check everything out, or would like to have some quiet meditation time.Free entry with Museumkaard, otherwise E9.00 I think. Audio included in price.Lockers available.Photos allowed; no flash.Open Mon to Sat 10.00am to 5.00pm and Sunday 1.00pm to 5.00pm

Well worth a visit. A fascinating place which you could easily miss unless you search it out, which is I suppose what the original builders were aiming for! The entrance is from a canal front house just a few hundred yards along from the Oude Kerk. There is a good audio guide with different segments activated as you enter each room - it would take roughly an hour to go round listening to the whole descriptions. A very interesting building and worth a visit for a touch of culture in amongst the other attractions of the Red Light district.

It's the part of Amsterdam. The museum is located in the center of Amsterdam, where you can come from any direction. Admission is 8:00 euros and includes audio guide. it is very informative for you to know about the history of the museum from the 17th century. go up on the attic by a steep staircase where you will find formerly church

Don't miss this, what a find. We came across this museum by chance while walking in central Amsterdam. When Catholicism was out of favour in the Netherlands secret churches were built which the authorities turned a blind eye to providing they, and their attendees, were discreet. This is one such surviving example. A modern visitors centre will open next year (2015) to lead visitors into it, but we were told this won't change the way you climb the steep stairs through 3 stories of a merchant's house, seeing on the way how his family lived in the 1600s. Then emerging into a soaring church built to accommodate 100 worshippers. We then thought we'd seen all there was only to discover there was even more to see on the way down - so give this plenty of time - it's a 2 hour visit if you like to take your time to look. It's narrow stairs all the way, so only do this if you're good on your feet.

A hidden gem in the Red Light District. This is a very interesting hidden Catholic church tucked into the attics of 3 adjoining houses in the Red Light District. The included audio tour is very informative in explaining the history of how this church came to be over 350 years ago, when, as a result of the rise of the Protestants to power, Catholics were prohibited from the public celebration of Catholic Mass. Do be aware that there are some very steep stairs to climb but it is well worth the effort. Very different from most churches you will see in your travels. We recommend a visit. The admission is 8.00 euro, bu if you purchase the Museumkaart (for the Rijksmuseum and Van Gogh), it includes admission to this church.
A surprise. My friend and I both liked this experience. A nice walk from our hotel and something different from all the art we saw. Well worth this interesting part of Amsterdam history.

If this is the Secret Chapel in the Red light district. If this is the Secret Chapel that is located in the Red Light District, it was a very interesting place to visit. I had no idea what to expect when we went in, but there was a proper church with pews and an organ. You get a recording machine to put round the neck, and as you go round there is some points that you point the little machine at and it tells you the history of the church. Very good and also worth a visit.

Very Interesting Attraction. While walking about Amsterdam, we came upon the Church In The Attic Museum. Entrance fee is 8.00 euro per person. Included in the fee, is the audio guide which we found useful in explaining the history of why this church was a "secret" sanctuary for the Catholics in central Amsterdam. Be prepared to climb and descent rather steep and narrow stairs to tour the museum. The audio guide was very informative as noted previously. Not only do you see the church which is located upstairs in the house, but you get to see the interior of an Amsterdam house and the living quarters allocated to the Catholic priests who were assigned to the church. The church itself is beautiful and has been carefully restored. We recommend a visit to this unique site.

A little gem. We read about this in a travel brochure and it is certainly worth a visit. It is in the middle of renovation to link with the house over the road by underground passage. Every room and twisting stairway brings a new surprise. An excellent audio guide is part of the admission price. Stairs are very steep so not suitable for people with limited mobility.

Significant restoration and renovations. We have been to this "hidden church" a number of times. Since our last visit, they have been restoring the church to its original color - similar to mauve. As they were doing some renovations, they found several layers of paint and this was the oldest one they found. It is quite a change from beige color the walls used to be. They are also constructing a visitor center and an underground pathway which will connect the two buildings.The history of this church is interesting and there is now an informative audio guide which explains it, included in the price of admission. Basically, it was a Catholic Church which operated clandestinely when that religion was not permitted by the Protestant Dutch. This church was included in the price of our Museumkaart.

Surprisingly our favorite church in Amsterdam. We went to the New and Old Church and thought those were very beautiful, but liked this even better! My husband and I got the iAmsterdam card and it rained the whole time so we were glad we had admission to most all the churches and museums. The story is so interesting and it's a beautiful church! Definitely something you don't see every day.
Go!. a really unusual attraction and well worth seeing. agood climb up several flights of stair. Worth it to learn so much about this amazing church in the attic!
Strange place. Being a non religious, for me is difficult to understand why people turn their house into church. I expected more stuff about house. Organ was nice!

A stunner. You are expecting to see a chapel in the attic - don't want to blow the surprise but this is a very enjoyable museum. I need to put another plug in for the Museumkartt - an annual pass for 55 euro. This is the only reason we saw this museum. Once you spend the money you look at the map and pick things that are nearby that you might not otherwise spend the money on.
a must see. what a fantastic place, the best value for money in amsterdam, very interesting and surprised how good it was

Should NOT be missed. This was my second visit to Our Lord in the Attic. As a Catholic, I loved seeing the church and as a tourist, I appreciated learning about Dutch culture and history. As an aside, I experienced something unusual in the kitchen area on the ground floor. As I was about to take a photo of the "inside outhouse" I had a terribly dark feeling take over me and I couldn't get out of there fast enough. Interestingly, when I returned to the States and was reviewing my photos of the entire two week trip, all of the pictures were there except for every single one I'd taken in Our Lord in the Attic. Would I go again? Absolutely! Would I go back to the ground floor kitchen? No, thank you!

Loevly little chapel. I had been recommended this attraction by an old school friend who lives in Amsterdam but I am surprised it does not feature more in some of the attraction books and maps. Essentially, the chapel was built over the top 3 floors of 3 town houses in central Amsterdam at the time when Catholics were not allowed to practise their faith in the open. Visiting it, I was surprised as to how much effort and time, not to mention money had gone into constructing it and was also surprised at its size as it holds 150 people. As well as the chapel itself, some of the other rooms in the building have been restored with original features which makes for a quaint, well preserved interesting museum.

Little gem. This little museum cost about 9euros each and although it takes less than an hour to see it all, it was really interesting. We were admitted just behind a large group so the receptionist suggested we start at the top floor and work our way down. We arrived at opening time and it was great to be in the chapel with very few people about!

Interesting pace to visit with an excellent audio guide that is available. This is a Roman Catholic church that is hidden in a canal house. I entered the house with hardly any knowledge of the place but the audio guide that you get when you enter gives you a very good idea of the church's history and how the owner kept the church a secret till the restriction on catholic churches were lifted. They have maintained the look and feel of the attic and all the places of interest are only accessible via (creaky) stairs. You get a good view of the surrounding canal houses from the windows of the house.

You don't need to be religious to marvel at this hidden gem.. Tucked away in the red light district is the most amazing hidden church. Built to be used in secret when all the Catholic churches were taken away and given to the Protestants the church is being refitted as it was and developed to include toilets and a cafe next door. With an audio tour to explain every area in detail there is a wealth of information to learn about the construction and use of the church and if you are interested in religion, history or just looking at beautiful things then this is a must for anyone visiting Amsterdam.

Definitely worth the time and price of admission!. It is a hidden church in the attic of a row house where Catholics had to go to secretly pray because Catholicism was outlawed in the Netherlands for more than 100 years. You have to look for it because it is very easy to walk right past it. The audio guide does a good job of giving you the relevant history in an entertaining way. It is a very cool thing to see!

Interesting way to see a canal house but beyond that not much. this is a museum based around the fact that the original owners built a church of reasonable size in the attic of a house because Roman Catholicism was forbidden at that time. The Museum staff have done a good job with an audio that explains the house and the Church in the attic and have taken effort to restore the house to its original state. That said you would only rate it average as an attraction. By the way there are only stairs no elevator.
Hidden gem. This was fascinating to see how a complete functioning chapel was made in the attics of three adjoining houses

Well preserved peice of history. I really enjoyed taking a look at this, and the way they have kept it in it's original condition. I didn't even know that practicing Catholicism was banned in the 1600's! It's great to see original tiles/paintwork, wallpaper etc.

A small but fascinating museum. The church is a fascinating secret hidden in this house, with many other little rooms to look through. The audio guide which is given when you pay is brilliant for getting the full story. We visited midday on a Saturday and it was not busy at all.

Fascinating place !. Visited this little museum following mention of it when we took a guided walking tour of Amsterdam. It was fascinating - audio tour very helpful with lots of background information. You would not guess what is inside by looking at the building from the outside - looks like a standard canal house from the outside - definitiely not so inside. They are in the middle of a development programme to provide a new education centre / visitors entrance. Not for the less agile - lots of steep stairs to climb !
Better than expected. Interesting little museum-house. Maybe not worth full admission price but if you are using the IAmsterdam card or something like that, it is definitely worth a quick stop.
Very interesting to go and see. Really like this museum - the chapel covers the 3 floors at the top of the house. While you are in and out in 40 mins or so - still well worth a look.
small, but worth going. It's only a house, with a church in it !! but interesting to see. The church is far from being a little chapel, it has an organ and decoration etc

An unexpected find. We read in the guidebook that this 17th century canal house had a church in the attic and were expecting a room with a few pews. What a surprise! It was huge! It had absolutely everything including an organ. It was beautifully decorated and preserved. Well worth a visit. Would highly recommend.
Have to see this!!. Situated in the Red Light District, what a little gem! You would easily walk past so look carefully when walking down the streett! Soooo amazing. Audioguide available here.
Atmospheric church/museum. Never seen anything like this - a church "hidden" in a house, due to religious restrictions at the time. Atmospheric and charming.

Quite impressive museum. Did not know anything about this museum until our guide, Lee, of the Sandemans walking tour pointed it out to us and recommended we paid a visit during our stay. Enjoyed the story behind it and every room of this impressive house. Not to mention the church in the attic!

Glad we went. This is a remarkable piece of Amsterdam's history. Our Lord in The Attic is a 350 year old church built secretly into the attic of a home. Nestled away in the heart of the Red Light District you could walk past it and never notice it. Reasonably priced, it is a great way to spend an hour of your day.
Worthwhile visit. in the Red Light District- we went in the morning when they opened- very interesting site--great gift shop- i bought most of my Take Home for Me items there.

Amsterdam's best kept secret. My number 1 'must see' museum in Amsterdam - in an unassuming complex of three houses in the heart of old Amsterdam. The excellent audio tour guides you around one of the most wonderful buildings in Amsterdam and has further detail for those interested. The labyrinth of stairs, rooms and passages is both endearing and confusing, so retrace your steps and make sure you haven't missed anything.
A spectacular building tucked away behind a simple facade.. A peaceful and interesting museum with surprising secret a chapel in the attic. This is a small and beautifully restored building.

Interesting visit. Interesting insight into the religious tolerence and intolerence. We had the AMSTERDAM card and makes a stop in every museum "worth" it since they are all on the card. Not sure if I would pay per visit ( not even sure what the fee was).

A House with many unexpected secrets. In the middle of the Red Light district you can find this litle nice museum. The audio guide is working well and tells you all the inns and outs you need to know during the tour. A lot of rooms are still original and this makes it very special.

Interesting little gem. On the fringes of the red light district a 350 year old church in a house. This historic visit is partly about the house and partly the church. Well worth a visit and reasonably priced too!

A unique building. This is a Roman Catholic church built in the attic of a merchant's house. When Roman Catholicism was outlawed in the Netherlands, several of these churches were built. As long as people were discreet, the authorities turned a blind eye. This is the only one that survives intact. A visit is fascinating for many reasons. You may visit the merchant's house, as well as the small adjoining apartment where the priest lodged. The church itself, in the top two storeys of the house, is surprisingly large, with a gallery and an organ loft. One of the most unique places I've visited.

Amazing church. I decided to visit Amstelkting Museum because it's sounds good to me to see things that people do or create in ancient times to express their faith. I'm not a religious person, but I loved the creativity of the merchant who built the church.It isn't a must see place. But it's quite interesting. If you have time in Amsterdam you should visit.

Would have never known.... This chapel is one of those places that you could walk past a million times and never know it was there. Very near the central station and red light district. I enjoyed the history and the ingenuity of this attraction. Its a place you would only want to visit one time but definitely worth it.

A hidden gem. We skipped this on our last visit to Amsterdam as we thought it might not be very interesting. How wrong we were ! This is an amazing house with a hidden and staggering secret. Its definately on my list to go again next time I visit

Well worth the trip. Having dragged the kids literally around the Van Gogh and modern art museum's, they listened to all the sections of the audio guide at this attraction and may have even enjoyed themselves. I would recommend it for families. Our kids are 8, 12 and 14.
Beautiful!. This was an amazing place. So amazing that it was built more than 300 years ago. A must see. Not feasible if you have problems with stairs or cannot fit up narrow staircases.

Atmospheric museum. An interesting story of the work to create this hidden church plus an insight into 17th century onwards Amsterdam life. A peaceful refuge in the midst of busy tourist area. Somewhere to stop and ponder. Part of pleasure of Amsterdam is to lock into the history and this is one of good places to do this.

Unbelievable. This was an amazing surprise. An almost fully restored hidden chapel in a beautiful canal house in Amsterdam. With informational signs in both English and Dutch, the history of this hidden church will astound you in every way. Highly recommend!

Hidden curiosity. Interesting building with audio guide that fascinates telling the tale of a Catholic church built in the attic of an old building and hidden from the outside and non-Catholics during many years.
Very interesting museum. We enjoyed our visit although renovations continue. The history of the museum was very interesting. It will be excellent when the new building is complete.

A hidden gem ... by design. Our Lord in the Attic is a 17th century merchant's house with a Catholic church hidden in its upper floors for secret worship in a period when Catholicism was suppressed in the Netherlands. We were captivated by the whole experience.Those with mobility problems would struggle as navigating many steep sets of steps is essential to be able to see anything at all. It's worth exploring each nook and cranny by climbing every set of stairs that isn't roped off as the signage in the museum is not the clearest.Construction work is continuing on a new visitor centre in the building next door which will be connected via a new underground tunnel. Once complete this will enhance the visitor experience significantly as all the paraphernalia of lockers, giftshops etc. can be moved out of the historic building.It's worth watching the video (in the room at the very top of the museum) about the restoration project running since 2011 and the importance the city council places on this flagship project in reclaiming this area of the city.

Interesting. We enjoyed this small museum. I though before going that it was just a chapel, but there is an entire house to see. It gives you an idea of what life might have been like in 17th century Amsterdam. The hidden church was amazing, and to hear how it was accomplished on the (free) audio guide was quite interesting. There are several steep staircases, so be prepared. Watch your kids because they could easily fall on them if left unattended.

Unique and Interesting. It didn't look like a big place from the outside and as you enter, but there is quite a lot to see and learn about inside. It is amazing how the founder of this "secret" church was able to create a lovely working church in the inside of the houses. Beyond just the church itself, one can also get an insight into life in Amsterdam in that period of time.A unique and interesting experience!

Hard to find but worth the effort. Nicely restored Catholic church that provides a window back into the period when the strict Calvinists made Catholicism unwelcome in Amsterdam. Worship persisted in secret but with all the accoutrements of a typical high mass. Make sure you note the address and look carefully.

Very moving experience. I loved this little church that is now a museum. Actually it's not that small as it's like a tardis, bigger on the inside than it is on the out. It lacked the sleekness and sterility of the larger museums and art galleries. They have done a wonderful job of restoring this church to it's original state. It has some very steep winding stairs and I can imagine gets a bit intrepid during the busy summer months, but during the winter when I visited there weren't too many people and this enhanced it's specialness. You really could imagine all the people coming here to worship in secret. It isn't quite finished yet but it was still worth coming to see. Wonderful

Worth a look. If you go to Amsterdam you must go here. Excellent Art gallery crowned by Rembrandt's Night watch, which you can't get near for people. As expected main place to sit down is the over priced cafe for which you have to queue

Church in the attic. Imagined only an altar and a couple of seating benches. But the 3 upper floors of a perfectly normal canal house contained a whole church, that could accommodate 150 catholics going to church in secrecy. Very fascinating!

Audio tour was not working well. Located in the red light district this old house has a hidden catholic church inside. The audio tour did not correspond with places and the english version kept cutting to Dutch. If you are on a museumkaart or a Iamsterdam card then it is worth popping in.
Amazing gem in Amsterdam. Well worth a visit - have never seen anything like this anywhere. Beautifully restored and very interesting commentary. Included with the Holland Pass.

amazing. right in the middle of the red light area, this museum is well worth a visit. Three merchant buildings combined to create a chapel on the top three floors. the chapel is now restored and although building works continue you can also see the original merchants room as well.audio tour is one of best I have seen and very informative of this buildings history and that of the catholic community

Amazing museum. You will be awed at how worshipers at that time were able to keep this church/ chapel a secret. Tucked beneath this seemingly small house is a church. The layout is great and thy were able to preserve it so we can see it. Highly recommended!

Unique!. We planned to visit the museum early in our long weekend stay in Amsterdam just before Christmas. The visit was first class and well worth the time. Fascinating story behind its development, beautiful decorations and stunning views over the surrounding canal and area. Well worth including in your itinerary.

Wonderful. Amstelkring is an oasis in this seedy city!! I don't think I can add much to the glowing reviews.Well worth a visit. There is a fair amount of renovation going on at the moment but it didn't detract from the interest and peace of this unique museum.

Remarkable. This museum is based in the house of an Amsterdam family of merchants. As they were Catholics and the religion had been banned in the city they family created a chapel within their own house where they and their family and friends could worship. From the outside this museum appears to be just a house in a wealthy area of the city. However once inside there is a very interesting layout to the house which somehow manages to appear perfectly normal until you get to the top floors. I was expecting there just to be a small altar in an attic room but the chapel stretches over 3 floors and is very elaborate. Highly recommended.

Great back story. Located in the middle of the Red Light District, this is a Catholic Church that was built in the attic of a home when Catholicism was banned in The Netherlands. It's a fascinating piece of history with a really well done audio tour.
Not worth it unless you get free admission with museumkaart. Not worth it unless you get free admission with museumkaart, which is a great deal. You can easily see everything is well under an hours

a hidden gem revealed. I am not religious but I appreciate that others are, so... and the Catholics that were not allowed to publicly worship back in the 16th century certainly were ingenious in their persistence. I visited just for the novelty and ingenuity of their accomplishment. This tiny chapel is spread across the attics of three (I believe) canal houses - even knowing you are in the right place does not mean you will be able to discern it's presence even now in the 21st century! The old tiles in the rooms below are also interesting - as are the maps of the old city.

Small but interesting house-museum with a chapel hidden in the attic. My husband and I visited this small 17th century house-museum for the first time in december 2013. On the outside this museum looks like a typical canal house with the steep stairs, corridors, alcoves, rooms and kitchens typical of the period, until you stumble upon the cosy Roman Catholic church hidden in the attic. This church dates from 1663, and was installed there by merchant,Jan Hartman, at a time that the celebration of Catholic masses in public was forbidden. An audioguide is included in the entrance fee, and museumcard holders can get in for free.In one of the rooms there was a small exhibition on Saint Nicolas, the patron saint of Amsterdam and of the chapel.The museum also has a small museum shopAt the time we visited the museum, some renovations were going on in order to link the house of Jan Hartman with the museum by means of an underground passage.
Fascinating and uplifting.. We visited this chapel today and found it a lovely humbling experience. I took loads of photos which I'll post after I get home as this is well worth a visit.

Interesting. The story is quite interesting although the delivery is some what lacking. The church its self is stunning and hard to believe even in person. Many photo opportunities or just sit back and let the venue wash over you.

Very interesting, lovely church and artwork; period home. The church is very pretty with the paintings, hand worked interiors. The home seems intact from that time period with lovely porcelain tile walls, kitchen and sleeping accommodations. When you hear of the Alteration, you have this memory firsthand of what it was like for Catholics afterwards.

Of Limited Interest. I simply do not believe that the protestant authorities in Amsterdam in the 17th century were not aware that an RC chapel existed in this building. They simply turned a blind-eye to it, as it was not visibly obvious from the outside.The chapel itself is not very interesting. The secret synagogue in Princelet Street London is more interesting.
Hidden gem in the middle of the Red Light District. Entrance fee €8 but the history is amazing! Lots of stairs, but secrets behind every corner. Great views of the canal and neighborhoods
Beautiful!. My husband and I really like museums; and we spent about an hour at the Chapel, and we loved it.Very fascinating history of the Dutch!

A hidden gem. Lovingly restored and with colourful Christmas decorations when we visited, this was a surprising addition to our list of places to see. Even more interesting that the house is next to the rather austere Oude Kerk.
