Not worth it. After reading the reviews on trip advisor I was really looking forward to seeing this. However, I was disappointed. It was so dark, and the actual chapel was really stuffy - the air was so stale. I don't think it was worth the entrance fee.
A real find. This museum is being extended at the moment so there was some building noise in the background but it is a very original spot and ipod guide is excellent. A place not to miss.

Fascinating. Not easy to find but is Found along side a canal. Inexpensive, small gift area. Audio set included in the price. Several sets of very small steep stairs that if at all disabled would not manage. Restoration nearly completed. Great to see inside a traditional Dutch house and then to see the wonderful church in the attic. Also great views from the upstairs windows onto the canal and bridge below. When we visited the organ was still covered in bubble wrap which was a game as it would have been lovely to see.

Amazing it survived. What a wonderful little place - the obligatory 5 flights of steep steps but well worth hearing the where and why of the building- and they're planning to expand into the next door property so facilities will only get better.

Hidden gem. Well worth seeking out - thanks to TA or I would never have known about it - good audio presentation gives the background to the beautifully restored living tribute to a desire to practise one's religion despite the edicts of the time.

Interesting and inexpensive. Inexpensive museum, worth seeing. Took about an hour to go round, liked the audio guide but could have done with more information in each room as well. Interesting look inside a traditional canal house and of course the church in the attic is wonderful.

Still under renovation but worth the visit. Although there are signs about the renovation, I didn't see any activity going on. The only disappoint was that the organ was covered to prevent dust from getting into it. This really is an out of the way, secret place. I had to ask twice where it was but was glad I found it. It is an amazing place carved out of the attics of three adjoining homes. There are lots of stairs to climb and tight places but worth the trouble.

A good place to visit. The museum is undergoing a big development project at the moment, with lots of work going on outside. This doesn't spoil the inside experience though, and the chapel in the attic is lovely. It is a big contrast to the red light district that you walk through to reach it! There were very few visitors when we were there, so there was plenty of time to soak up the peace and atmosphere of the chapel and to enjoy the ingenuity of its creation.

Wow. This was AMAZING! walking through the house was interesting but then you get to the attic its a big WOW moment amazing to see what people have done so that they can continue practising their religion. Fascinating.

Nice and peculiar small church. By means of an audioguide you get a great idea of why and how this small church came into existence. It is small, but still has most of the features of a much larger and purposely built church. Certainly a place you will remember.

Definitely worth a visit!. Catholic Masses were conducted as an open secret in private homes during the persecution by the reformation in the Netherlands. The dedication of an entire, large home in what was (and still is) prime real estate in Amsterdam was unique and therefore worthy of a visit.

Lots of info and fun.. Wonderful museum. The Catholic church was on the top floors, a secret meeting place when Catholicism was frowned on by the Dutch. Great audio tour included in admission price. Lots to see in the whole house, bedrooms, kitchens, etc.

Don't Miss this Gem. Several of my friends who've been to Amsterdam missed this hidden church. It's one of my favorite things in the city. It doesn't take very long to seek and it's right in the heart of the Old Town near the train station. Don't miss it!

I was annoyed at the lack of progress here. Having visited the museum 2 and a half years ago when it was in the throes of restoration, I expected it to be up and running now. I even took the precaution of emailing them a few weeks before our visit to check and was told, and I quote, ' there is much more to see than two years ago.' Er, no there isn't, unless you think putting down a carpet and doing a bit of painting constitutes 'much more to see'.It's a delightful little piece of Amsterdam history but they are being very slow about getting it finished and I don't like being lied to.

A gem of a museum. This was a very interesting small museum. I enjoyed having the audio guide discuss and provide information about how they build this hidden Catholic church. Everything has been restored beautifully.
A little hiden treasure. Very interesting little museum. As most people, not expecting much, but getting lots. Liked the way the audio tour was done.It is a must when you visit Amsterdam

A Jewel in the City. We found this almost by accident and it was probably the best attraction we visited while in the city. We had plenty of time to walk around the rooms and the audio tour was a real bonus. There were lockers and cloakroom facilities which made the visit more comfortable and relaxing. There weren't too many other people visiting at the time which meant we could appreciate the space and atmosphere. It has been recently renovated and is an outstanding place to visit. However be warned this is in the red light area which may put some off visiting but don't miss it.

Round out your impression of Amsterdam. My husband and I spent an hour at the Chapel, and it added greatly to our understanding of Amsterdam and its history. It's a beautiful little place, reminiscent of the Tenement Museum in New York, and being inside it really brings the history home.

My favourite museum in Amsterdam. I often take visitors to Amsterdam here. This hidden catholic church is a gem. You'll not find anything like it elsewhere. The main room on the first floor is so typically Dutch. You find yourself in a Vermeer painting. The pastor's bedroom is so quaint. The church on the top three floors is surprisingly spacious and as lopsided as most Amsterdam houses. Downstairs is the old kitchen and even an indoor loo. The clever way the windows as ground level let light even into the basement is an education in itself. The museum has been undergoing renovations for some time. Not sure when it will be finished. If you want to understand something more of the Dutch culture of tolerance, this museum provides a suprising insight into just one aspect. Definitely worth a visit!
Unique. A must go to for Amsterdam. House under renovation, but attic church is beautifully restored. Worth the time.

nice museum. I recommend checking out this museum/church, very interesting history. Located in the Red Light District, Catholics in Amsterdam during the 17th century were forced to worship here in secret after religious practice was outlawed. Admission was free with 'IAmAmsterdam' card, and it was a well worth hour long visit.

Amazing: You'll not see anything like this anywhere else!. After four days in Amsterdam we had already ticked-off all of our "must-dos" and found ourselves looking at what else we could visit for free with the "I Amsterdam" card.We found ourselves in the red-light district entering an old canal house which looked broadly similar to the neighbouring buildings. We were given a free Audio Guide and a free locker for our bags.After climbing some very steep stairs we found this unique place which was created so that Catholic people could continue to worship in secret when it was forbidden by the state.We are not very religious and have no affinity to Catholicism but you have to admire the ingenuity and determination which went into creating this church. Not only have they knocked three attics together, but they have also removed floors on two levels to create a secret church.We came to this place with little or no expectations and left in awe.Well worth a visit but unsuitable for anyone with mobility issues owing to the nature of the building
Worth a visit. We didn't expect much from this museum, but we were very impressed and surprised with what we found. This is well worth visiting.
Beautiful . Entry was included with the I Amsterdam card. Was a beautiful church and it is amazing that something that grand was hidden so well. Very interesting.
amsterdam. very interesting!! Off the beaten path. Audio tour included with admission price. Excellent complement to the Anne Frank House

Interesting museum and well run. The chapel in the attic of this very old house is pretty astounding given what it would have taken to create it. Seeing the remainder of the house was very very interesting.
amazing!. Cunningly located in the red light district, an amazing church hidden on top 2 floors of canal house. A must visit!

A remarkable and unexpected chapel. Well worth a visit and a reminder of the days of proscription of Catholic worship. This is a beautiful place of worship located a stone's throw from the old red-light district.
Don't miss this gem. What a beautiful church hidden in this house. Don't miss visiting this. The history is fascinating. Tight steps to climb but worth it.

Secret gem in the heart of the city. Absolutely must see. It is describing important part of Dutch history - the exactly opposite situation which we know from Catholic Europe. Small but very nicely prepared museum with good audio-tour. In 2013 is being reconstructed and another house will be added to the museum.

Hidden gem in Amsterdam. Interesting, beautiful, moving. The self-guided audio tour works well, there is just the right amount of detail. The clandestine Catholic chapel reflects a time in Dutch history when Catholicism was officially banned, but the authorities turned a blind eye to the 'old religion' as long as they were discreet. Even for the non-religious, the preserved and renovated house gives an interesting picture of life in a traditional dutch canal house in the 17th and 18ht centuries.

Amazing chapel within a house. Even if you're not religious this is a good stop for story about the faith of families during the Reformation and history of the times. They need to do more restoration of the rest of the house but the chapel is amazing since it was "concealed" within a home.

Beautiful Hidden Chapel.... If you like going on pilgrimages, this is one place that might interest you. I am amazed at the beauty of this little chapel that is hidden for so many years. It also amazed me that people in those days have so much wealth to have something like this built. The stairs are steep and narrow, but houses in Amsterdam are mostly built like that because of the time. They are in the process of renovating it and I am glad that we'd seen it just the way it was. The next time we go see it, it will be modernize to accommodate the tourists.
The hidden church. It was interesting and self guided through audio tape. Meaningful if you have ever been a banned religion in life.
Interesting. Very interesting and good value for money. The tour is very good and you actually want to listen to everything that they say. Definitely worth a visit.

Something Different. This was an interesting and different attraction to visit, and nicely done. It is an interesting piece of history--to see this church that was hidden from the rest of the world. It's inside an old canal house, which was nice to see in its own right.

Interesting and beautiful!. This fascinating museum is a unique glimpse into a little talked about time. It is free if you have the iAmsterdam card, and I feel is worth the admission if you don't have it.Does not take half a day to do, as another poster mentioned, though going early or towards the end of the day are better time wise. If you listen to all the items on the audio guide, and if you don't walk too fast, I still can't see it taking more than two hours. We did it in about 40 minutes, not listening to all audio guide items, but most.Note: There are lots of stairs, and most are steep. Not a good attraction for those with mobility concerns.
Fabulous. Terrific historic event not to be missed. Will take half the day but well worth it. Go early as gets very busy

Remarkable hidden church. Amazing story. The renovation is in its final stages. We were able to see the home and the chapel above that occupied the upper two floors. From the front of the church you can view the canal and houses across.
Moderately interesting. ...but not worth the cost. Interesting story of religion in late 17th century Holland, but not much to see.

Very curious place. This is a curious place and out of the ordinary.
I liked allot the accompanying audio tour and everything was well organized and very well displayed.
It worths a visit.

Unexpectedly fantastic!. So very unexpected - more than just a church in the attic, it told the story of a glimpse of 17th-18th century life in Amsterdam. I really liked it a lot! You'll be surprised!
Interesting place. Catholic church of the XVII century in a private home owner. There was almost an irregular situation, as to be a Catholic in Protestant Amsterdam at the time was not safe.

Amazing history!. When you arrive, the museum gives you a booklet in your native language, with a scancode on it. At each of the "stations" in the museum, you scan the code, and a movie plays with a short history lesson in your native tongue-what a fascinating history this city has!
Stunning. One of the highlights of our trip. Go early if you can to avoid the crowds and you will be rewarded with history, ambiance and memories to cherish of a very special building.

a very interesting visit. The museum is small but very interesting. An audio guide is included so that you can learn about the history of the building and how and why it was used. There is a little bit of noisy building work going on at the moment (they are building a tunnel through to the next building where a larger visitors center will be opened) which meant that at points our audio tours were useless, but we enjoyed our visit regardless. The church itself is beautiful and they have gone to great lengths to capture the way it would have looked to worshipers in the 17th century. A different and highly atmospheric way to spend a few hours in Amsterdam.

Great for children (and adults). Lots of things for a child to see here because it combines the house with the church. Makes history interesting too. Must go back when they have added the house over the canal as new entrance and display to make museum bigger.
Great experience. Small but great museum. We definitely felt like we learned something new during our visit. Such a unique location and such a fascinating story.

A little gem of the city. This Church holds the story of the religious and social evolution of Amsterdam, it was built in secret because of a historic religious change, and it was built by an Amsterdam broker, which took part in Amsterdam's Golden age. Beside the Amsterdam museum, this museum is also an historical gem that will tell you the story of the city.

Amazing History. This museum is filled with fascinating personal history of Amsterdam, but the piece de-resistance is the church, with the two story Organ and the walnut wood throughout! Don't miss it!

Somewhat intriguing.. The Amstelkring church is beautiful and has a very interesting history. I enjoyed the audio tour and seeing the church and other rooms of the house. Still, I felt like the tour and museum was a bit bland.

Well worth the visit. This was pretty hard to find, and I guess during the Nazi occupation, that was the idea, as it was a hidden church, so from the outside it just looked like a house. From what we remember the outside sign just said 'Our Lord in the Attic Chapel', and not Amstelkring Museum. We enjoyed visiting and really only takes 30 minutes or so. Free with the I Amsterdam card, which in itself is worth it if staying a few days and you plan on visiting museums and galleries.

Hidden Gem of a Museum about a Hidden Church. Great, uncrowded museum that holds a hidden catholic church from when they couldn't hold services publicly. Included audio guide allows you to see and hear as much as you want. It has some religious artifacts but it's the whole setup that you just gotta see. Biggest pleasant surprise of my journey. I highly recommend.
worth visiting but not essential. This is an interesting attraction which will be better when they conclude renovations in a few months. I would only recommend if staying more than 3 days

Hidden Church. This was a good example of what good people (this time, Christians) must do to service their bona fide faith in the midst of oppression and real religious suppression. The 'make-shift' church is quite impressive when considering the clandestine methods needed in the oppressive Nazi occupation. Outside views give away nothing to suggest such a prohibited activity during the occupation. Worth the small fee and well worth the support that such visits show!

enjoyable visit. Lovely and unusual museum.I am not a fan of information overload museums and this one is just right.We had the bonus of 2 musicians playing in the church on the day of our visit.Took us us a while to work out how to do the audio tour so staff could have explained that when they handed us the gadgets.Overall -definite worthwhile attraction to visit

Appreciative. I read about it first and that helped. I could feel the determination of the people to be able to worship in spite of the stairs and confinement of the room size. Then to go on and live in such small quarters. My daughter had an experience in the lowest room of the house and her pictures vanished from her camera!!!

Fascinating. A fabulous hidden gem!! From the outside looks like an ordinary house but inside is really unexpected. Real quirky little place. Audio available and essential, explained in detail the reason behind the hidden church. Wasn't too busy, really enjoyed this place, much better value than bigger churches in the area.

Must-see in Amsterdam!. This is a fun museum to visit in Amsterdam. It is reasonably short (1 hour?) and packs a lot into that time. The cathedral itself is impressive (considering it is in an attic) and the audio tour does a great job of giving the background and context.Also, this museum isn't very crowded and we didn't have to wait in line more than a few minutes. Recommended!

Really interesting museum. We visited this museum last week during our short break to Amsterdam and found it really interesting. I liked that the audio tour was included in the entry fee and found this to be really informative and it pointed out things that I would have missed otherwise. It was good value for money and a good spot to while away a few hours on a rainy day.

The unexpected highlight of our trip.. My partner and I came across this place on tripadvisor and just decided we would go there if we had time/happened to come across it. We did come across this place by accident one afternoon and were so glad we did! The museum/house/chapel was beautiful and very unique. It was also a lot quieter than other museums we had been to that day (Anne Frank), therefore we could walk around at our own pace - and the quietness helped create a sort of tranquil atmosphere. You are also given phone like devices which you scan against certain information points and hold to your ear to hear extra information about different rooms - again this can be done at your own pace and in any order. To us that was a great thing to have, rather than have information points on walls etc. where everyone is trying to crowd around. The history of the place is very interesting, and there are so many different stories to different rooms. It was a lot bigger than we had expected. For us, it ended up being the highlight of our trip and was great value. I would definitely recommend.

A revelation. This house certainly achieved its plan, as you’d never guess the treasure that is under the roof. But before one gets that far there are some interesting rooms to view. These include the living quarters, bedrooms and one with a fine stove plus chimney. Some rooms have displays of fine clothing. The chapel is spectacular. Its impressive size over two levels meant it could take a sizeable congregation. Its restoration incorporating colours similar to the original is attractive. The old style lighting is very evocative. The altar area is highly decorative with beautiful columns, much statuary and a large painting. On the top level is an organ that looks well used. From the balcony a great perspective of the sheer scale of the church is available.Leaving the chapel on the way back down it was intriguing to see the quarters where the priests lived. This includes a basic kitchen.

Unbelieveable. This is one of those places you have to see to truely understand. If you are into churches or history this is a must see. We were given an audio tour device that you pointed at signs around the house/church to hear information about that room. It wasn't full of people and you could explore at your leisure.

fascinating place. we had already visited rembrandt house, which was interesting, but thought that this was better - not just for the church, which is fascinating, but thw whole house. It is in the red light district, but when you come out turn left back to Zeedijk, not right and your blushes will be spared!

Very nice museum. The red light district was the last place I thought I would find a museum. This is a small and quaint place. The audio guide that comes with the admission price is wonderful. Very nice and doesn't take much time to go through.

One of the best sights in Amesterdam.. Very interesting, definitely worth visit. Lots of historic information about that time period in Amsterdam. And the German merchant who bought the houses and why he converted the top floors into this beautiful church. A neat view from a couple of the church windows looking across the old roof tops of Amesterdam. Went up narrow and very steep stairs, NO HAND RAILS, to reach it. We were told, they are planning a easier way up. However I would find out before going, if stairs are a problem for you. This was one of the best things we did and saw in Amesterdam. Surprised you do not here more about it before hand!!

A different sort of church. What do you do if your Catholic faith is banned and your church is closed? You buy three houses, knock them together and take out the floors on the top two stories so you can build a hidden church in your attic, that's what. And it's an extraordinarily beautiful church, too, lovingly restored. The rest of the house is interesting and the free audioguide is excellent.
Do not miss this gem!. Wonderful canal house with a gem of a hidden chapel in the eaves, beautifully restored and glorioulsy explained. One of the top 5 Amsterdam

Massive and impressive!. We came here by accident, but so happy we did! It's massive inside, hard to believe it was essentially a hiding spot when it's so huge. Very cool if you're a history buff. Definitely make time to go! Make sure you're thorough in making your way around, apparently I missed that there was a kitchen downstairs.
Very Interesting museum. This was a little bit hard to find at first - watch the house numbers closely. We found the audio tour worthwhile.

Quirky little place in a typical Amsterdam house. We were unable to get tickets for the Anne Frank House, but this was a stroke of luck, by all accounts, as the queues are horrendous and there is little to see. We went instead to this delightful museum which occupies three typical old houses joined together in the upper storeys to form a secret Catholic chapel from the time when Catholicism was proscribed. Apart from the historical interest of the chapel, this is also a very good way to see a 17th c Dutch domestic interior.There is an excellent audio guide (also in English), and a small gift shop with some lovely postcards, coasters, etc. based on Dutch tiles.Be aware that the stairs are very steep and narrow.

Fascinating insight into history. Firstly, you do need to be able to cope with stairs, but if you do, you will get a fascinating insight into the golden age of how a wealthy Amsterdam merchant would have lived in his family home. I visit this museum each time I visit Amsterdam, and I always find it interesting. The staff also are very friendly.

Worth an hour to view. SOme may think this is too religious a museum to visit, but it is more historical than you realize. The living rooms of the family are prosperous, if not completely furnished, still evocative of the times. The church portion of the home is interesting as a mark of the societal change in the Dutch government, as it was in England when Henry VIII changed religions. Good audio tour. If you have a hard time with steep Dutch stairs, inquire directly as there are many levels here. Small but nice giftshop, easy to walk to the museum from Centraal Station.

Religion in hiding. When some religions could not be practised in Amsterdam, those who wanted to worship went underground This museum is one of the oldest in Amsterdam and gives a very good idea of life in the 'Golden Age'
Incredible. Very special place, interesting from the historical point of view. An experience. Be aware of the stairs. Do not miss it!

Well worth a visit, a hidden gem, like a tardis inside. You would never know what is inside from the outside of the building. So interesting, they give information on handsets to explain each area. Well worth a visit.
really worth to visit. it is a "hidden" church out from the time Catholicism was forbidden in The Netherlands. It is well conserved and does have a very special atmosphere.
Impressive. A real Amsterdam gem! Now in renovation but precisely interesting to follow the work and results. A unique witness to the XVII century and the particular religious life in the time.

Hidden catholic church in the attic- a must see. This is a very nice museum to visit. not very crowded. it takes you back to the 17th century. Lots of creaking stairs, stories, paintings, statues,....
Hard to FIND but worth it. This museum is on the edge of the red light district and is a tad hard to find. Narrow stairs throughout; no handicap access. Fascinating place.

Beautiful house and surprising church in the attic. I first went here in the 80's and I always the recall the house with its beautiful decor. Its recently been restored and is even more magical. The chapel in the attic is stunning too. Our only disappointment was that there was a display of student textile work (which was fine) but it was draped over and obscured the historic exhibits and the rooms . Given that the most people will only visit once in a lifetime we thought this was intrusive and unacceptable. We work in the arts so understand the idea of showing contemporary work in historic settings but it was imposed on a historic building rather than adding a new interpretation and lessened our enjoyment considerably.

Unique Site. I first saw the museum on the Rick Steves episode on Amsterdam. It was tricky to find as it is located on the start of the Red Light District. This was part of our "I am Amsterdam" card so we got in for free and they provided a thorough audio tour. I thought it was fascinating to see an entire chapel built in these small, canal houses.

Hidden Treasure. Seeing this Church and hearing how and why it was built most interesting. Good self guiding audio tour device allowed looking at the speed you wanted to go.Building is being restored and Museum enlarged but that is not a problem. Most major work is done now. Would have liked to hear the organ or be able to buy a CD of it playing.

Worth a look!. We visited the Amstelkring museum to check out the hidden church and the period rooms within the canal house. We weren't disappointed! As Catholics, we found the history behind the hidden church very fascinating. The sanctuary is absolutely beautiful. The tour was educational and provided a glimpse of 17th century living. I loved the pocket beds! We visited about an hour before closing and practically had the place to ourselves and enjoyed a quiet moment to pray and reflect before the altar. I recommend a visit, especially for Catholics or those interested in religious history.

We were amazed. It took us a while to find it but it was worth it. The house part was quite dull but the church in the attic was amazing. We were expecting a tiny chapel but it is quite a big "church". It was much bigger than we expected and with an organ, confession box, a side chapel and the place where the priest gets ready (can't remember what that is called). It was hard to believe it all fitted up there! They have done a beautiful job restoring it to it's orginal glory. So glad we persevered to find it.

Lordy! Almost missed it. This is a fascinating insight into what it would be like to worship when your religion is banned. A bit confusing at times try and figure out the layout with the 3 houses, but go with it. Fascinating history.Look out for the sign protruding from the building, it's not immediately obvious it's a museum, but that's kind of fitting.

Little Gem in the heart of Amsterdam. From the outside you would never in a million years imagine that there lies a triple volume Catholic Church. It's a lovely, quaint museum away from the bustle and crowed tourist sights! It is really worth a look and the audio guide give you a lot of insight to how the people would have lived in the olden days.

Worth a visit. Interesting place, worth a visit. Not easy to find. Lots of tight and steep stairs to climb.Free lockers are available for your stuff. Look for the flag out front with the museum name on it.
Fascinating. Fascinating "hidden" church which was constructed inside three townhouses. Now in process of final renovation. Audio tour was quite interesting. A great little find.
Great experience. It is a must if you go to Amsterdam. A church in a building so small that is divided in four stories. You must go!

You should visit!. This place we didn't plan to visit but finally we ended up there and it is worth the 8 euros. In addition with the receipt you get a 3 euros discount on i.e. Willet-Holthuyisen (or how do you write it) house (worth visiting!!!) and you pay only 5 euros for that one. But this place of Our Lord in the Attic Chappel is very interesting and although I am not a fan of museums etc. this was very interesting and they offered in the same price a good audiostory so you get to know better the rooms and the history. I think this is worth of visiting - never seen anything like this before. Remember to mind your step, there are many steep staircases and steps but with time you can manage (but unfortunately I think no wheelchair access is possible).

a little secret church. was disappointed because the house wasn't furnished, and it was recommended as a good place to see an original amsterdam house, but still, the whole idea of secret masses and how the top of the house was converted was interesting.

Worth a look if you have an hour to spare. This was highly recommended to us by our guide so I think we were a bit disappointed as it is basically just what it says on the tin - a hidden church in a house from the time that Catholicism was forbidden. We found it enjoyable enough but, unless you have a specific interest in this field or have lots of time, there are probably more interesting things to do.

One of the most special Amsterdam museum. This museum offers a dive into Dutch history. The museum is very original and special to Amsterdam. It shows roots of Dutch rational tolerance, how Dutch authorities closed their eyes on certain things (Catholics in this case) because there was no practical reasons to prosecute them, There is excellent free audioguide in the museum.

Worth a visit. We almost bypassed this attraction because of its name change. It was listed in our guide book as The Hidden Chapel in the Attic and on the map as the Amstelkring.We did not buy the I Amsterdam pass, but at 8 Euros, it was well worth it. Amsterdam is a very walkable city and we found that by paying for each attraction separately, it was more cost effective.

A bit of a surprise. I'd never heard of this hidden treasure but it was quite intriguing. Although it is a bit of a rabbit's warren, you get the impression of how ingenious it must of been to build such a church in such trying circumstances.

A must-see - as long as others don't. An amazing piece of seventeenth-century ingenuity. It's had a makeover and features good talking expositions that can be tapped at each location - no need to go around in a headset. The church proper across the top floors of three narrow town-houses was sufficiently well hidden that the Amsterdam authorities could deny all knowledge of it. It's visually am imaginatively striking. But beware of the stairs: the Dutch of that period must have remained ace climbers into advanced old age.
A little jewel. Fortunately a friend recommended going to this Museum or we probably would have missed it. If you are interested in history, this is a must see.

Gets better. I have been here three times over many years, and I have such high memories, eah time I worry it will not live up to expectations. This visit did not let me down, with my teenage daughter totallly enthralled too.
Lovely museum. This chapel is hard to find as tucked away in the red light district but well worth the effort, so beautiful when you get there.Put this down as a must do when in Amsterdam.

Include in your Itinerary. The Amstelkring Museum is definitely worth including in your visit to Amsterdam. The journey to the attic up narrow, steep and now very old stairs left me wondering at the foot traffic it once carried as parishioners regularly made their way to the church to congregate out of the public eye. The free audio-guide naturally enhances the experience, though for those of us ignorant to the workings of organs, I recommend they include some reference to the lever upstairs, of which there is no mention, despite its size and obvious presence.

Awe Inspiring--magnificent!. This museum was incredible! The museum has done a wonderful job in reconstructing and recreating the Church as it was when it was last in use. The colors, the majesty, the history are all awesome. Rarely do you hear about Catholicism being the minority denomination having to hide itself from the protestants. The audio tour is excellently done and gives you a great perspective on the Church, the way it was created, and the restoration.This was one of the highlights of our trip!

A must-see when visiting Amsterdam. This is a place to visit when in Amsterdam. It is a bit funny that the church is located in the Red Light District ;) You get a free audiotour included in the ticket price which gives you a great background and history of the church.The church can be a bit difficult to find, but it is worth the visit (we spent about an hour there) and had the church almost to ourselves.

An extraordinary building. This is a gem of a museum, recently restored although there are ongoing plans to extend the museum. A fascinating insight into the religious turmoil in Europe as Protestantism usurped catholicism in the netherlands. After the former outlawed the latter, and took over their churches, an enterprising businessman over two years built a catholic church upstairs in his house (incorporating a couple of adjoining houses as well). Excellent audio guide. A must see.

A Must See while in The Red Light District. This museum was recommended by our Dutch host as "one of the best places no tourists know about" and she was right. The chapel has been so well preserved, and you get a free audioguide included in the cost, which really helps you understand Amsterdam's history. We wish we had allowed ourselves a little more time (about 2 hrs total) because there was actually a lot of information on the guide.

An interesting place in a interesting location!. This museum is actually a Catholic Church that is at the top of a house. It was developed during the time in history that Catholisim was outlawed in Amsterdam. You start out seeing the house itself, which is quite interesting, especially the box beds. Then up about 4 stories is the church itself. It is well worth seeing. The only downside to this museum is it is located on the edge of the red light district and you do see some interesting "sights" on your way to and from the musuem!

Don't miss it!. When you live in a country with religious tolerance, the need to hide a 3-story church with pews, altar and organ is barely imaginable. This well designed museum with audio guide reminds us of the importance of religious freedom, while providing a view of Amsterdam life on the canals. This really is a must-do.

Who Knew?. It's almost a miracle to enter this ordinary looking home along the canal in the Red Light District...to find a 3-story church with columns and organ and all the accoutrement tucked inside and out-of-sight. A MUST see for anyone interested in Amsterdam history and architecture.

This is a must!. I won't go into too much detail as it would spoil the overwhelming sense of surprise when you see it - but basically it's a secret church constructed in a house at a time when Catholics were forbidden to worship in public.

History in stately environment. The Netherlands is an odd mix of historical tolerance and bigotry. The museum is a relic of days when Catholics could not say Mass. A church in an upper room that was designed so well is something one does not visit often, so if in the area, visit the site.
8 Euros. We really lingered to get every bit out of the experience. It was OK - I wouldn't have wanted to pay to bring a whole family through.

A hidden surprise. This church in a canal house in the middle of the Red Light District shoud be on your list of must see places. It has recently been restored and the house next to it is being turned into a reception area.

Noting from the number of reviews, this church is no longer undiscovered. I have seen this church many times and I have brought along many visiting guests.I like unusual attractions, and this certainly is one of them.It gives a flavor to the often puzzling history of the Dutch and Amsterdam.Duke de Buena, an aristocrat and ambassador from Spain wrote a book "The Dutch Puzzle".This church shows one aspect of tolerance.After the reformation from 1568 - 1648 Holland fought a war against Spain over religious rights.The Catholic religion was banned, so the followers of the Roman Catholic Church had to go "underground", and this church is a beautiful example.From the outside it looks like any other mansion on the canals in Amsterdam.But it is hard to believe that with such a large pipe organ, the location of this "underground church" was unknown to the authorities.

Don't miss this one, fascinating. This museum is really worth visiting - we had a Museumpass so we were going into everything we could, but I'm so glad we went to this museum as it was a real highlight of our time in Amsterdam.

a hidden masterpiece. So interesting - a beautiful old canal side house anyway and at the top, an extraordinary church. As in Elizabethan England, open Catholic worship was banned, so a rich merchant built this church through 3 of the top parts of houses in this row.It really is magnificent, and you have to pinch yourself you are essentially in an attic. I'm not usually a fan of audio guides but this podcast one is v good.I'd definitely recommend the climb to see this - tho you go up in easy stages and get to see some other restored rooms as you goIt was also amusing to hear that it wasn't really such a secret, even tho worshippers went in through a door in an alley - but if you were discreet & contributing to the city economy, the authorities didn't bother you too much! Money has always talked ....
THE BEST. I have to admit this museum/house/church was the best thing I did in Amsterdam in the whole week I spent there.

A Hidden Treasure In the heart of Amsterdam. this attic church was used by Catholics during the 17th century when they were banned from worshiping after the Alteration. It's been beautifully preserved and is a must see while in Amsterdam. it is like stepping back in time and shows you how life was back in the 17th century for Catholics in amsterdam. Im not really religious but i appreciated the detailed history you received from the audio guides and the sheer beauty of the place.

Very unique and interesting. Definitely worth a visit!. We loved our visit to this unique and interesting chapel.The Amstelkring Museum (Our Lord in the Attic), located in Amsterdam's Red Light district, is a 17th century church hidden in a wealthy merchant's house. It is one of Amsterdam's oldest museums and gives you a good impression of how wealthy merchants lived duing the Dutch Golden Age. The top floor was converted into a Roman Catholic church when, during the 17th century, Roman Catholic worship was banned in Amsterdam. Catholics continued to worship in hidden churches ... of which “Our Lord in The Attic” is the only surviving example.Location: Oudezijdsvoorburgwal 40 (Red Light district)Open: Monday to Saturday 10:00 am to 5:00 pm; Sundays and holidays 1:00 to 5:00 Admission: Adults - € 8,00 (includes audio tour)

Dutch toleration in a beautiful package. We visited this museum before we visited the Portugese Synagoge. Great to see some of the roots of Dutch tolerance and toleration. Don't pass up visiting this "schuilkerk". It has been beautifully restored and gives you a real-life feel for Dutch toleration policies, a Catholic church in "hiding" at the top of a canal home with full knowledge from the protestant mainstream, an interesting and pragmatic model to deal with diversity.

A hidden gem. This hidden church was a wonderful surprise in the Red Light District. They have done a nice job with the restoration and preservation. The audio tour is worth doing as it provides a nice background on the outlawing of Catholicism in Amsterdam and the impact it had there.
Really interesting place!. A very unusual church in a very unusual location (Right in the Red Light District in Amsterdam). Great story behind the origins of this beautiful little church!

Thoroughly Worth Going. This is a small site but at the top of my list because of it's uniqueness and the original state of much of what was there. It was very beautiful but stairs are steep so it may not be good for the disabled or elderly.

it is much more than what you'd expect of it!. We wanted to try some new things and when we heard about the "hidden churches" as a concept in Amsterdam, we said "why not?!". And from the look of it - a small door which appears to lead in a very tiny house - we thought we'd be in and out. Well, yes, but no!The whole thing is like 3-4 floors high, couple of houses connected, there is a real church on top of it, right - as the name says "in the attic". VERY well presented - with an audio guide included in the price (i think it was 8 euro per person), telling you the story of the church and some interesting facts about how this type of churches came to being in the first place.Excellent exhibition and audio guide. Exceeded my expectations - very nice museum, highly recommended!

Well worth a visit. It was a pleasant surprise and the church in the attic was a lot larger than I expected. The audio guide provided gave good commentary, and it was nice to see what life was like back in the times the church was constructed.

completely refurbished, just great. Museum "Ons' Lieve Heer op Solder" is a Dutch museum in Amsterdam which one should not forget to go and see. Behind the front of the former house of the rich catholic merchant from Amsterdam Jan Hartman are many surprises hidden. Apart of the beautiful 17th cent living rooms, arranged with art objects, the Amsterdam Renaissance `Sael (reception chamber), cosy bed cities, curate chamber and kitchenette breathes a particular environment.The largest treasure is on attic! On the full depth of attic deepening Jan Hartman accepted in 1661 a Roman Catholic housechurch with 150 seats to be build. An ingenious solution then after in 1587 an official prohibition came on the celebration of the catholic religion. For over two hundred years church services were held here. The chapel has just this month be reopened renovated in the 16th cent. style and colors. www.opsolder.nl/‎

Not much to see. When we went to see this museum, workers were re-constructing the chapel flooring. There just wasn't much to see beyond the upstairs chapel. In hindsight, we could easily have skipped this site for other more interesting venues.
Surprising museum. This was a pleasant surprise. To think that the owner built a church inside his home was quite remarkable. Make this a must see on your visit to Amsterdam.

Simple looking church of historical import. This church / museum goes by other names and is also listed here in Tripadvisor as Amstelkring Museum or Church of our Lord of the Attic. Admission is EUR8,00 and comes with an audio guide.The typical Dutch exterior belies its unique interior. Of course, the highlight is the well-preserved Catholic church. However a few of the rooms in the main house have been nicely restored to give a unique perspective of the living standards back in the 18th century, as well as the preferences for symmetry in interior design. There are a lot more attractive churches in Amsterdam and Europe and while the church and altar appear rather simple, the audio guide offers a good explanation of the complexities of building this church and its galleries, as well as its relevance in Amsterdam's history. Visitors are free to roam on all floors of the house, even the galleries. At the time of visit, renovations were being done however this did not hinder the experience. Note that this attraction has steep stairs and has no wheelchair access. Overall, Museum Ons' Lieve Heer Op Solder is worth visiting for its historical significance. The admission fee is a little pricey for the amount that can be seen however the costing seems to be comparable with other attractions in Amsterdam. Allot at least 30minutes for visiting. Amsterdam's oldest church, Oude Kerk, is an easy walking distance.

Very interesting history to this canal house. Audio guide included in the ticket. Just enough information, not too long. Could move around the museum at own pace, turning on audio guide when needed. Attic chapel is astonishing.
Steep stairs steeped in history!. Nice to have a chance to see inside one of the canal-side houses and the beautiful chapel in the attic.

Our Lord in the Attic Chapel. I had difficulty fining this place but that was just me. It's right near Oude Kerk.Very historically significant church, why hidden and who build it. The audio tour is a must. Otherwise you'd miss 75% of the description of this church. It seems large tour groups do not visit this museum and thus very quite and you can stroll through with your leisure pace.

Great balance of museum and reality. This museum is gives a fascinating glimpse into a particular aspect of Dutch life in the early modern period. From the outside it doesn't look like very much, but that was the entire point of the building. The museumy elements are kept to a minimum, leaving just the church to shine. The audio guide is easy to use, and I really appreciated that it explained particular restoration decisions that had been made.There are a lot of little rooms and corners, and all are open for the public to poke around in, with fairly good signs pointing you on to the next stop through the house. Well worth a visit, you'll be surprised at just how much of a church it is!

Don't miss this church!. It looks like a typical canal house in the RedLight district, but as you work your way upstairs, you find a three storey chapel in the upper floors, carefully restored and quite lovely. Audioguides are free and quite detailed.

Quiet little gem in the heart of Amsterdam. Just round the corner from Oude Kerk, on the edge of the Red light district is this little gem of a museum that tells the history of this Catholic Chapel, built into the top 3 floors of an Amsterdam townhouse. Really good audio tour takes you round the different rooms and floors up to the covert chapel in the attic. Not very busy, but very interesting.
Our Lord in the Attic. The musuem was nice, right near Oude Kerk, in the heart of the Red light District. The chapel was nice. It is worth a visit
Very interesting!. This was one of our favorite attractions in Amsterdam- truly unique. There's no reason to skip this one, especially if you have the Amsterdam Pass or something similar.

Glad we visited!. It took a bit to find it, but I'm glad we finally did. It's on the edge of the Red Light District on a canal. The renovations are almost complete, and they've done a good job. It's definitely worth a visit just to see the inside of a building of that age. The Chapel is beautiful and the audio guide is very helpful and interesting.
Very cool. Only downside is, it's located in the red light district. If you go in the daytime you're safe enough, just beware of pickpockets, or so we were told by locals.

Find time to visit Our Lord in the Attic Chapel. On our last morning we had an hour to spare, and I am glad we found this little gem to visit we had a voucher left in our Amsterdam Pass.Luckily we had looked for it the night before and it took 3 walks up and down the Red LIght District, asking a policeman, a cycletaxi rider and a local resident before finding it.It's just passed the Old Church in the Red Light District going in the direction of the station.Not only do you get to see a beautiful chapel, but also an Amsterdam House, and learn about the history attached to the Chapel.We didn't allow ourselves enough time - I would say to really take it all in and really enjoy the feel of it allow 2 hours.When we went it was very quiet, but I would imagine that during busy times it could feel very crowded.Enjoy

Newly renovated so time to go. well worth a visit now that the renovation is almost complete. The building itself is a marvel just to see how it was put together. Make sure that you follow the route signs and don't go back the way you came as you then miss some rooms out. There are steep stairs so be aware of this.

Great little museum!. I had heard about this museum before my trip to Amsterdam but didn't really have plans to visit it. However, one day while wandering the streets, my mom and I came across this place. We had some time and decided to go in. It was well worth it!

A surprise in the attic. My wife and I had found information on this sight on the net, just before our recent visit to Amsterdam. I most say that fullfilled all my expectations and more. It is a strange fealing to go arround in the small rooms in this house to end at to the Attic to find a church.
cute hidden gem of a museum. I went there in 2011 and it's a really interesting and surprising place. The chapel itself is quite extraordinary!

A very surprizing place.. The restoration is almost finished and the restorers have done a good job. It is a wonderful place to come to rest and think about religious turbulent times that Amsterdam in its history has known.
You Gotta See This. We loved this place,it was amazing. The audio guide was excellent.Even looking out the windows here was great.

Hidden treasure.. What is not to like about this beautiful hidden gem. The idea of having a full size church hidden in the top of your house is just wonderful and the restoration work they have one is just great.

One of our favorite museums. This "hidden" church is facinating. It is not easy to find and you have to walk through the red light district to get to it, but it is well worth seeking out. It is housed in an old canal house and the bottom floor still has its antique furnishings. It is included in the Museumkaart.

Well Kept Secret - Even Today!. Situated along a very ordinary street, the very ordinary facade masks a church that was kept hidden for hundreds of years. Despite the fact that it had seats for a hundred people, an organ and a resident priest, the church operated in secret until St. Nicholas Church was built and Catholicism was no longer discouraged. We visited early on a Saturday morning and there were very few others - a nice change from the craziness of Amsterdam. The audio tour was very good. Highly recommended for a nice diversion and a look at historical Amsterdam.

Interesting little museum. The front desk staff (female) was rude and most unhelpful. Just plain rude when we bought our tickets, did not bother to tell us about another part of the museum we would have missed entirely if her colleague had not been kind enough to do so.However, fascinating place worth visiting.

Upstairs Downstairs Amsterdam Style. A remarkable building, fascinating Merchant's House downstairs, wonderful secret church upstairs just restored. Great views over rooftops too. Gives a real sense of 17th century Amsterdam.

Learned a lot. Very interesting "hidden" church with audio tour. Much more ornate than we expected. We are not practicing members of any religion but found this tour and story very interesting. Would recommend.

Something a little different. This church was recommended to us on a walking tour the previous day. This is a beautiful, very recently restored church situated in the attic of a canal house....used for worship when Catholicism was officially outlawed. An audio tour is included in the price of the admission, which makes the visit much more interesting. It really is a very beautiful church ad worth seeing. .
A hidden gem. Very unusual attraction very interesting and will only get better as still being restored. Well worth a visit and buy a combined ticket and visit the Canal House too - very good value

Worth searching for. This old church at the base of the Red Light district was one of the highlights of our trip to Amsterdam. It is not easy to find as it is located in an old row house and is easy to miss. The self-guided tour is easy to follow and highlights the history of the church, and the people who established the church and kept it going during a time when catholicism was "illegal." The entry price is very reasonable and it took us just over an hour to complete our visit. The audio guide was also worth renting to get more information. We easily shared one amongst the three of us. You will not find the crowds here as in other Amsterdam museums. Hours of operation can be a little tricky so check this out before planning the visit.

A must see.. This place closes at 5pm (unlike most other places we visited) so that was a surprise, as was the fact that we were out by 5:02pm! We did have time for a quick look around and this was greatly enhanced by the electronic guide (not clumpy headphones) that you get at reception, and the many strategically-placed information mini-posters and visual displays. The staff were very nice too.Looking from outside, you will just never believe there is a 3-storey church inside this building. So when you see it, you will be amazed. There is lots to see and learn about inside the house and chapel.I rate this far higher than Anne Frank's empty house and the information is conveyed far more professionally here, plus there was not 45-minute queue to get in. Excellent! I will certainly go again when I am next in Amsterdam.

A hidden gem in many senses!. Back in the days when being a practicing Catholic was frowned on but tollerated, this stunning chapel was built in the attic of a 17th century house owned by a rich merchant. The idea was that if nobody knew it was there, nobody could complain. Very 'Dutch' and tolerant. Over the years real Catholic churches were once again built and worship was moved from being secret to being fully open, but this jewel was preserved for posterity. You can use your Museumkaart here too. Highly recommended!
Great. Amazing to see a church 'hidden' in the loft with many of the original items and features. very informative guidance which was language specific as you walked round
really pretty. Very interesting and beautiful with a great insight to amsterdams golden age. Well worth a visit for an eye opener about a period of history that I did not know about

A True Hidden Gem. Amsterdam is great for so much more than what people tend to associate it with. The Amstelkring Museum is case in point. This 17th century townhouse gives one a firsthand glimpse into the golden age of Holland. It is truly a must see!

Charming hidden gem. An upper floor Catholic church tucked away in the Red light district seems an unusual find. Google the history of the church and visit.There has been a really good restoration done and as yet visitor numbers are a lot less than for the big name sites.Takes about 60 mins for a liesurely visit.Nice friendly unobtrusive staff.

Nothing like it I've ever seen. Located in the red-light district, this museum is housed in three connected townhomes. The first two floors contain the former living area of the family who owned it. The true magic is ascending to the third floor where a Catholic Church the size of aa big living room appears with full altar, pews, and organ. Due to persecution in the past Catholics were not permitted to worship. Their answer was the creation of this most interesting house of worship. Given its location also, it is a surprise worth experiencing.

The Church in the Attic-hidden gem!. My wife & I visited the Church in the Attic on Wednesday March 13, 2013. What a fantastic place this turned out to be. I would strongly suggest the audio guide since there many stops along the self guided tour. Stairs to climb up & down and the church's interior is stunning. Hard to imagine the place full and having services but it happened. A must see for anyone interested in history or architecture.

Beautiful church in the attic. From the outside a 17th century house. On its upper floors inside is a Catholic church, hidden when Holland became Protestant. A chuch, with galleries, on 3 floors. A really good audio tour where you just point the handset at various points around the church and then just listen to the handset. Well worth a visit and good value at €8 per person.

WOW!!!. Outsanding people.Find this place tucked away in the corner of the red-light district. A catholic church hidden in the attic of an Amsterdam house with an oustanding history which will really leave you with breathtaking memories.Go see!

A hidden treasure in the middle of the redlight district. If you are into history, this is a great little museum. Be prepared to climb loads of steps to get to this hidden treasure. Interesting and a fascinating insight into Amsterdam history.

Amazing. I'm not religious but this place is inspirational insofar as the human spirit is concerned. If you truly believe in something you have to practice what you preach, in this case literally in a time of persecution. Free entry with the I AMsterdam card..........you've got to go!

Hidden treasure!. Absolutely loved visiting this strange building. I would never have guessed what this normal looking building would have inside. I don't want to give too much away because I never knew this place existed so I will let you find out what its all about when you find it. There is an audio tour available which is good because it explains a lot more about the architecture and the history as to why there is a church in the middle of this building. Very interesting and definitely worth visiting.
Very interesting. Good audio guide and lots more to see than 'just' the Church. Definitely worth a visit. Should be even better when the new part of the museum opens later in the year.

Fantastic view into the history of Amsterdam's churches.. Very interesting story behind the building, anyone interested in interior design or architecture will find this museum very interesting. Beautiful building and very informative audio guide.

A solemn place by the red light district.. This "secret church" is a must visit for Catholics and for those who love religion history. A great piece of history on its full glory. I love the fact that this sanctuary is still in use on Sundays for masses.It is a 3 museum in 1. The house of the rich catholics 200 years ago, the hidden church and the basement with some religious relics to see.If you still have an hour to spare before heading back home, go here and enjoy an educative and solemn place next to the red light area.

The best way to experience the history of hidden churches in amsterdam. The best way to experience the history of hidden churches in Amsterdam. It's in The Red Light District. On the first and second floor is a former 17th century patrician's house with a classic 17th century interior. The church is on the 3rd and 4th floor and surprisingly large.
Unique. Not a Catholic but this was amazing to see how a chapel was added to the top floors. Museum minimal, extension to facilities underway. Not sure cafe will be an improvement!
staggering, worth a visit. Amazing, the whole story behind building a chapel in the attic. Good audio accompaniment which is active in each room as you go around the museum.

GO VISIT NOW BEFORE ITS EXTENDED/CLOSED. Located in the red light area; but dont let that put you off as its one of the most historical houses in Amsterdam. The church on top floor across 2 buildings has to be seen to be believed. Fairly compact so go early to avoid any crowds. To be closed later in year for total refurbishment and extension to next door.

Great find with excellent audio tour. The Rough Guide recommended this church and it was well worth hunting out.The museum takes you through the history of this hidden catholic church which has just been renovated. Something which really worked was the free audio sets which you zap at various points as you tour the church.Would recommend as something different.

Unbelievable place. The visit to that hidden church is much more than a visit to a place, going there you understand the real behavior of Amsterdam people, how the tolerance to religion is an example of real integration of people with different thinking, unbelievable that church was in function for hundreds of years in a country where the Catholics were banned after a religious war. A lesson to the world.
Unique church. The church is unique in how it was established and how it is built.The rest of the museum is less interesting.
Definitely worthwhile. The church is very well maintained restored and gives a real sense of historical Amsterdam. The audio guide was informative and added to the experience. Covered by Museumkaart.

Amazing place. This place was an amazing experience which we discovered thru trip advisor even tho its not that famous in amsterdam however its very worth of checking the stories behind the rooms are really interesting!

A church like no other. Covered by the museumkaart, with audio-guide included. The latter is pretty comprehensive, giving you a detailed history of the church. We went late in the day and some areas of the church are pretty dark, so it may help to go during the day time.

Fairly interesting and well preserved site if you're in the area. This is quite near the top of town and creeps up on you after you've gone past a few smoking cafes and the like. The building is very interesting and well preserved and the tour is conducted in a choice of languages via a handset which you hold to your ear like a mobile phone after touching points in various rooms. Worth a look although I probably wouldn't go again.

A hidden gem. What a wonderful museum in the very center of the city. This catholic church, housed circumspectly in response to the reformation in the 1600s, is lovely. The information provided in the self-guided tour is very good. I challenge any visitors to find a way to get there without passing through the red light district - not possible but as always gives for a few chuckle-moments.

Well worth a visit. One of the great things about Amsterdam is the way completely different experiences sit check by jowl. And this is a superb example of that with this amazing little church hidden on the top floors of a building in what is not the red light district.It's an easy one to miss, but well worth the trip

The BEST Hidden Gem. Truly one of my most favorite places in Amsterdam. I read the reviews and decided to look for this church, which was a fun adventure. It is difficult to describe the beauty and the amazing history of the little church, you really must experience it. I expected a small church in an attic and was surprised by the size and the details of the church. It was constructed as a hidden Catholic Church where many worshiped during a time when being a Protestant was politically correct. It gives you some insight and a feel of Amsterdam at that time in history. You can also tour the rest of the building, it is undergoing some restoration but don't let that stop you, it is amazing, you must see it for yourself. They have good audio guides that explain the history of the church and you can go through the building at your own pace. Don't miss it!

Good place for a quick visit. We had limited time on our last morning in Amsterdam and needed to see something close to our hotel so came upon this little "Our Lord in the Attic" museum. This is a canal side house which belonged to a Catholic merchant at a time when Catholicism was outlawed. What he did was to convert the top part of his house into a church for worship. You might assume you'd be in a smallish space but, in fact, he made quite a large space by opening up several rooms. It's an interesting place to visit, being renovated but with quite a lot in place to look at, but I must admit my overriding question to myself was how he managed to "smuggle" what must have been a large number of people into and out of his house each week(?) without getting caught! I can only assume the locals turned a blind eye!Hint - you need the audio tour!

Amazing. This is a church in the top part of a canal house. They have spent the last few years beautifully restoring it to its former glory. Audio tour was included in price and was informative. Also could see rest of building. Well worth a visit.

Worth fifteen minutes. In the middle of the red light district, this is an interesting building worth stepping into to understand the Catholic situation after the Protestants took over. It is particularly noteworthy to see how multiple neighboring buildings were combined into one decently sized house of prayer.

Interesting audio history guide. Fascinating piece of history. We really enjoyed this unexpected gem. Neighboring building is undergoing renovation so it can be connected to existing museum and expand space. A must see while in area.

A Special Place -- don't miss. Having been to Amsterdam many times, I somehow managed to never know of this little gem. This time I discovered it and the visit really made this visit to Amsterdam among my most memorable. The building (and the church) is over 350 years old. Even the staircases are original. The main draw is to see the Catholic Church occupying the top 3 floors of 3 adjacent buildings, and it was used for nearly 250 years until, in the late 1800's a large Catholic Church was built nearby. The church, no longer in routine use for the last 100 years, was one of many "out of site" Catholic Churches which were tolerated as long as they could not be "seen". The church seated hundreds, and over the years well over a million people climbed the steep stairs to attend. In fact, the wooden stairs have been worn down by 1 cm. Much of the building (really 3) is well preserved from various periods of the last 350+ years. If you have even been to the Lower East Side Tenement Museum in New York City, this is similar in that it shows the way of life of the people (albeit without the stories of the family that lived in the house). The audio guide (free with entrance) is terrific. Just enough information, with great supplemental material. Do check this out, and after go 1 block away from the Canal towards the Hotel Krasnikovsky, and delight in a gelato.

The single best thing in Amsterdam. I'm a Brit living in Holland, although I've been coming here for years. Had a little time to kill, whilst escorting a vistor round so we popped in here. I won't spoil the surprise but "wow - didn't see that coming".

Top sight - a gem. This beautiful 'hidden church' was a highlight of my visit to the city. The audioguide helps to paint a good picture of what it was like back in the day when it was a functioning church for Catholics who had to worship in secret. You also learn about the man who owned this house and built the church in the attic. A special place.

Our Lord in the Attic Museum. This museum is a must-see on any trip to Amsterdam. I'm sure a lot of people miss this museum because it's not one of the better known sights but for me it was one of the highlights of my trip. It's an amazing insight into life at the time when it wasn't advisable to be Catholic, and the house just oozes atmosphere with it's narrow, steep stairs and bed tucked into an alcove. The house itself is wonderful but the last thing you expect to find in the attic is a church, and a pretty sizeable one too. Other reviewers have mentioned the renovations taking place, but despite these it didn't spoil my visit. It will be interesting to see the museum when renovations are completed.

THIS is Amsterdam. Forget about Oude Kerk and that sort of places, Our Lord in the Attic is THE place to visit. My friend told me about this place and I absolutely loved it- small and quite, makes you feel welcomed. Staff was very helpful and audio guide was highly informative, so the history of the chapel could be better understood. A bit off the beaten tracks, but definitely worth seeing.

Good Experience despite restoration. Other reviews here will give a fair idea of what it is like. Easily covered in an hour. The audioguide was very intelligently done because obviously parts of the chapel were missing but a good presentation of what a restorer needs to consider when performing this type of work lets you see through to the skeleton. More information on what it was like to be a clandestine catholic would have been useful. i shall certainly return when it is fully repaired

Undergoing restoration, but fab. LovEly small museum and an architectural sight to be seen. The church is currently undergoing some hefty restorations, which somewhat ruins the atmosphere, but its still pretty excellent.

Amazing!. When we went to the museum I expected to see a small room dedicated to Catholic services somewhere in the house... What you get is to see an authentic old house, walk its stairs, see the rooms and furniture and then find yourselves in a church, which is actually larger than some of the churches and chapels we have in my hometowns. Impressive! The audio guide (included in the fee) is very helpful and provides all the info you need. As a result, there are no information displays or stands in the house, which helps keep an authentic atmosphere. A must-see. Free of charge with IAmsterdam Card.

A must see!. This little museum rests in the heart of the red light district, however during the day it is perfectly safe. They have nearly completed a very extensive restoration of the chapel. In my mind it was going to be a small room in the attic, but this was a big space taking up the top three floors of the canal house. There are five floors of stairs to navigate up and down and they are steeper than the stairs now being built. However, this is one place i would recommend that you do not miss when visiting the city.

Probably the neatest chapel you can visit in Amsterdam. The story of the chapel is deeply rooted in history and tells the story of religion in Amsterdam. Its a neat chapel and the exhibit is done well. Its not crowded and they have a free audio tour.If you check out one cathedral/chapel/church in Amsterdam, I would recommend this one.

Surprised. We went there on a Saturday afternoon, but it wasn't crowded at all. Loved the hidden church, it was surprisingly big. It was also nice to be able to walk around in an old Amsterdam canalhouse (grachtenhuis). The entrance fee probably will go up when they finish the restoration. They have very ambitious plans with this museum. I'm sure the result will be even more impressive.

Very inspiring. We visited the museum as we heard about it on TV some years ago. It is in the old part of the city in the Red Light district (but don't let that put you off). I was surprised at the entrance fee eur 8 each however it was worth the money as it was very interesting & the headphones presented a good historical background to the building of the church but also the layout & working of an old house in the 17th century. As we had older teenagers it proved to be educational for them & I was surprised how much they enjoyed it. It was not over religious in presentation & was a genuine hit with the whole family.

Far exceded my expectations, DON'T MISS IT. We went as a group of four and i must admit this probably wouldn't have been top of my list. It is not very big and doesn't take long to do maybe an hour. Well worth the very reasonable entry fee. There is a lot of stairs with the moving around so good mobility is important worth remembering before you start. Amazing to see how it would have been hidden away at the top stories of the unique style of the Amsterdam houses. Showing the way the Dutch houses architechture made it more possible to hide it away. We used the headphones and commentary to do the tour with and it explained everything very clearly. Very impressed with it and i like visiting these places and am maybe getting jaded with run of the mill attractions, but this one stands out and you don't have to be religious to appreciate here. Also small tip if you leave any large belongings in a locker as they aren't allowed due to the narrow parts of the tour. Take the camera OUT!

Quite interesting and not crowded. We had planned to visit this site as we found the history interesting. Although it is being renovated and furnishings removed, it is still interesting because of the history. It is hard to imagine all the persecution the Catholics experienced. I get more out of the sites that are less crowded because you can take your time and have a better experience. We purchased a reproduction tile as modeled after those in the kitchen and, as we have found before, did not find this in any other shops. Makes a great souvenir.
interesting. an interesting glimpse into the protestant-catholic conflict in Holland. This museum was good both for the church aspect, but also for seeing the insides of very old amsterdam residences

Unique church. Very unique church in the attic of a canal house right in the heart of the Red Light District. Lots of construction work in the museum limited access to some areas but it was still neat to learn why a catholic church like this was needed and built to avoid persecution.
Real gem. Brave the red light area to see this gem. Amazing history. Pity it's being restored and we didn't get to see it in all it's glory. Children found it interesting and no major queues.

Great place to visit while discovering Amsterdam. My partner and I went to Amsterdam for our anniversary. A friend of ours recommended few places and Church in the Attic was one of them. Not only the actual church makes a great impression but also the building which have been kept in its original state (rooms etc). Great place when discovering more of Amsterdam, not your 'usual' places. Highly recommended.

Impressive site. The old building (17th century?) does not differ from it's neighbors in the world heritage downtown Amsterdam area. But once you enter the building, you'll almost spontaneously start to praise the lord who has made his home in the attic. The old catholics who where not allowed to practice their religion anymore a hundred years ago went out of their way with this invisible church. When you like history, curiosities and surprises 'Our lord in the attic' is definitely worthwhile a visit.

Say a little prayer. This museum really gives a view of a family house living here in the16th century. On the highest floors there is a 'hidden catholic Church' whencatholics were not allowed to practice their religion openly when the protestants took over the city in the 16th century

Very unusual.. We went here to visit today and I'm glad I did. Its under renovation just now but was still amazing, if I ever come back to Amsterdan I will come back to see it finished in 2013.The church is lovely and its hard to believe that they managed to build it.

A must-see, whether under restoration or not. This building, a clandestine church for Catholics built in the 17th C when public Catholic worship was not legal, is all the more remarkable for being decorated in the florid Baroque style. I visited this place first in 2001, and then in December 2011 when it was coming towards the end of a multi-year restoration project. I actually found looking at the process of restoration fascinating, and the contrast between the interior now and as I remembered it is truly striking.
Under renovation. We visited in 1970. Now it's under renovation, so I would suggest you hold off for a few years.

Double Attraction---An Amazing Church and Dutch Home. The Amstelkring Museum or Our Lord in the Attic Chapel affords not only insight into the creative efforts of Catholics to continue their clendestine worship during the Protestant Reformation, but it is also a visit to a typical Dutch house of its day. Hard to believe that this miniature church is tucked away in the upper floor of a private home. We were surprised at the spaciousness and furnishings of the chapel. It would accommodate a surprising number of worshippers. The alter is beautifully carved and the balcony and pew areas are what you might see in a church as well. The house also had a permanent seperate living quarters for the priest. It is currently being renovated but is open during restoration. The house is in a scenic residential area along a canal not far from Centraal Station. It was a private residence and is a good example of the home of an affluent Dutch family of its day, complete with kitchen and other living areas. Not only is it interesting to view the various floors and rooms of the residence, but the windows also afford an opportunity to see the rooftops of other surrounding homes and give visitors a "birds-eye" view of the clustered placement of the homes. Something that cannot be seen from the street. As with all old Amsterdam homes, this one encompasses multiple stories and the stairways are very steep, winding, and wedged, so people with disabilities or those who cannot safely navigate such stairways should pass on this attraction. Same story with the Rembrandt House. However, if you can navigate the stairs, both attractions are worthwhile. There is a small gift shop near the entrance.

The best place to visit!. I don't want to say much about it. It is better to just go with little knowledge. I have been to Amsterdam several times and if had to recommend one cultural activity other that the Anne Frank House (which I think should be compulsory!), I would recommend here. It is currently being renovated but this should not put off anyone wanting to go.
