Surprisingly enjoyable. great opportunity to see inside a canal house as well as the chapel aspect
Church in the Attic. So glad that we found it, enjoyed the visit and the tour.

Quirky and different museum. When we visited they were in the process of doing this museum up and so the church was just painted purple rather than the gold and multi coloured colours you see in the photos. But that does not take away the spectacle of the place especially when you get to the top floor. There's various bits to see on each floor - a very good audio guide explains all. A recommended museum.
Hope to see it when restoration works end.. The museum is open but in restoration works, so there is a lot of material hidden waiting for another visit, but it´s historically interesting.

Our Lord may have been in the Attic - but nothing else was!. I was charged over 6 euros to get into this house in a pleasant part of Amsterdam. The young man at the desk strongly encouraged me to use an audio guide (which I loath) and I refused. But then I found out why. There are three essentials to this attraction: the front room of the wealthy burger who owned the house; the altar and tabernacle in the loft where the chapel was; and the organ at the rear of the chapel. None of these were there! All of these - repeat - ALL of these - were being renovated. There was nothing but a series of holes, gaps and empty spaces. It was bad. I highly recommend you avoid this "attraction" as it was a total waste of money. It should be closed until everything is back in place.

Well worth the visit. Although currently the restoration is going on , it does NOT detract from this beautiful chapel . I found my visit to be incredibly thought provoking ,and found myself looking out of the windows at the beautiful scenic views of Amsterdam. Fascinating building from top to bottom.

Stripped bare, but still interesting. Like most of the attractions I visited, this too was having a refurbishment (2013 seems to be the finish date of them). All of the furniture and decorations had been removed, but there was a hand held audio tour which incorporated information about the refurb. Lovely house and still very interesting despite being bare. Lockers with key (free) in reception so you didn't have to carry anything with you. As with most houses, lots of stairs to go up and down, so not very suitable for people with mobility problems. I would love to go back again when it is finished.

The chapel is beautifully preserved and very well hidden in the home.. Our Lord in the Attic is undergoing renovation. Because of this, all of the furniture and priceless paintings that were in the home have been removed. That was a disappointment to me,but the church is completely intact and it is possible for the visitor to walk around the church and even behind the altar. The church is very pretty and painted a pink color with a balcony and pews just like a Catholic church anywhere in the world.The museum provides earphones that give a commentary in each room. That compensates somewhat for the lack of furnishings. When the renovation is complete in 2012, I would recommend another visit as it will be a true masterpiece.

Worth a visit even with the ongoing restoration.. The Amstelkring Museum/House is widely considered to be one of Amsterdam's top attractions and rightfully so. It has a little bit of everything from history to architecture to religion to... well, at least as of January 2011 an ongoing restoration.The entrance is easy to miss, a small flag and sign tip one off to an otherwise nondescript canal house just a stone's throw from the Old Church. The key here is that even with the restoration the museum has made an attempt to make this a worthwhile experience for a visitor, with a fairly detailed 12-point written handout describing the house and adjoining rooms. You can even learn a little about the restoration along the way as many of the signs describe what is going on in quite some detail. I guess I just took it as another opportunity to learn about how old houses and paintings are restored although I do see how some people could be a little frustrated by the current layout.It takes about an hour to walk through as is, although I am looking forward to returning in a few years to witness the results of what is obviously a lot of hard work.

Wait until renovation complete, unless you have Museumkaart. We were walking around the area (RLD) and since it was on the Museumkaart list, we decided to check it out. Unforunately, the attic church was under renovation. Had I paid the entrance fee, I wouldn't have been pleased.

favourite small museum in Amsterdam. Unfortunately there's a lot of construction going on here right now but I remember it from a previous trip. It's my favourite little museum in the city: go see the Rijksmuseum, Anne Frank House and Van Gogh but absolutely include this on your list too! There's a whole Catholic church hidden in the attic from the years when they had to go underground. You also get to see a 17th century merchant's home and some 18th and 19th century rooms as well. It's on the edge of the Red Light District so there's lots of bars and cafés nearby too although the museum really is a peaceful oasis of tranquillity. It costs about €7 but get the Museumkaart if you want to see 3 or 4 museums and it will pay for itself.

Interesting Museum, but under remodel until 2011 (but you can still tour). The very interesting museum is a church that was hidden in the top 3 floors of this canal house. I had heard about the incredible artwork and silver collection, but unfortunately it has been stowed away during the remodel. they are refurbishing the rooms to their original state. What this means is the artwork and silver will be moved into a building next door, and it will not be available to view until 2014. BUT do not let any of this stop you from touring the museum. It is still really neat to tour, and I believe th price of admittance has been adjusted accoringly. It only cost 6 euro to tour currently, but I had read it was 7 or 8 in my tour books.

Make sure they are done with construction!. The main reason I went here was to see the church but it was under construction so it was not worth the trip. Fortunately I had the iAmsterdam Card so it was free. If I paid the admission price and not be able to see the main attraction I'd be really upset. I'm not sure why they are even open during the renovation.

Don't go for another few months. The church is currently being renovated and is in a bit of a state at the moment - wait until the renovation is finished before going and it will be a whole different experience. (It didn't help that the people renovating it were having a very loud and dare I say disrespectful discussion while we were there.)

It is hard to believe how wonderful this hidden church is!. This exquisite hidden church is located in the center of the famous Red Light District. It is open Mon-Sat 10:00 - 17:00 & Sun & Holidays 13:00 - 17:00. Around 85,000 visitors tour this site each year. It is 7 euro for adults, 1e for children 5 - 18 & 5e for students. For more info go to www.museumamstelkring.nl  From 1578-1795 Catholicism in Amsterdam was illegal, but tolerated. Catholics were forbidden to worship openly so they gathered secretly to say Mass. In 1661 Jan Hartman, a wealthy merchant from the German town of Coesfeld built Our Lady in the Attic. This 150 seat 3 story church was above the home of the man who built the church. There is a back house that was rented to another family. The emergency exit door in the alley was the hidden churches main entrance door. You will see the parlor, canal room, Chaplain's Room, Lady Chapel, lower balcony, upper balcony, Confessional, Jaap Leeuwenberg Room (theses rooms were rented out to other families), the 17th century Kitchen & the 19th Century Kitchen. The hidden church fills the attics of three 17th century merchants' houses. You will be astonished at how beautiful this church is. Put it on your list of "must see" attractions in Amsterdam. I hope my photos will give you a glimpse of how the interior looks today.

Worth the effort. I am not a museum type of person, but I read about this attraction and thought it might be worth a visit. It was.Nicely presented, informative and just about the right amount of artefacts etc to view without getting boring.They are apparently going to modernise, shame, its the character that makes this special and I think it will detract greatly from its appeal.

Amazing!. As one who is Catholic, this was an amazing sight. Not only did the tour give a great insight into everyday life, it was just inspiring to think that one man, realizing religious persecution, would build this.

great museum- a historic home and a church!. This was a great museum, there were good written descriptions in all the rooms. It packs a lot of daily -life history into a space that is much bigger on the inside than you would would think from the outside. I did get the feeling of what attending a service would have been like in the attic church during that time period. An hour is sufficient, a must see. Covered by Museumcaart .

The secret Catholic Church in the Attic. This Catholic church in the Attic is an amazing museum visit while in the city of Amsterdam. The tour costs €7 per adult , which you make with your brochure to explain each level. You get canal views from the merchants house all the way to the top floor where you come out into a beautiful Catholic church which was hidden for secet masses, as that time it was forbidden to celebrate mass in Holland.Its incredible to think that in a city now where anything and everything goes, people had to hide to practice the Catholic faith.Its beautifully maintained , and well worth a side visit from the "big" venues in the city of Amsterdam.Its just a short walk from the Centraal station/Damrak.

Interesting and Historical. An interesting opportunity to see how p[erspectives changes on oppression, discrimination and power. Plus, it is beautiful, interesting, offer the opportunity to see the rest of the house and how people lived then. Short, interesting, fun. Offbeat, quirky, but cool.

worth a visit!. I've been to Amsterdam four times and have sampled quite a lot of its museums. The Amstelkring was very interesting. I have studied history so perhaps I am biased. My sister however also enjoyed it and she does not normally find history enthralling. It does not take much time, maybe one hour if you're efficient. When you buy your tickets you are handed a little pamphlet with info about each room. Then you climb up and down all through the house and you get to see the chapel (the main attraction) but also a traditional kitchen and other restored rooms. There are free lockers and a coat area for bags and other belongings.

A Hidden Gem. Very Interesting and impressive. Bang in the middle of the red light district and with a simple "Museum" sign outside you could perhaps expect very little from this tourist attraction. However ,inside there are various floors and "in the attic" a real ornate and impressive catholic church (accommodating hundreds of worshippers)I went to Amsterdam for a boozy music trip but this was very different, peaceful and a very pleasant change.Good for children too (say 4 upwards) who will enjoy all the rooms and steep narrow stairs in the house.Not recommended for elderly if not able to climb lots of stairs. Photography but not flash allowed.Give yourself at very least an hour for this excellent attraction.
